revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Philip Clemo | image = Philip Clemo profile pic..jpg | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = Philip Clemo, Glasgow 2012 by Colin Gray | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Philip James Clemo | native_name = | native_name_lang = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1964|08|03}}{{cite web|url=http://www.philipclemo.com/|title=Official Website|publisher=Philip Clemo|accessdate=30 April 2014}} | birth_place = [[Insch]], Aberdeenshire, Scotland | origin = | death_date = | death_place = | genre = Classical, [[jazz]], [[atmospheric]], [[ambient music|ambient]], [[electronic music|electronic]], [[experimental rock]] | occupation = Composer, film maker, artist | instrument = Voice, guitar, piano, keyboards | years_active = Music: 1997–present
Film: 1989–present | label = All Colours Arts, Metier | associated_acts = [[Ysanne Spevack]], [[Arve Henriksen]], [[B J Cole]], [[Byron Wallen]], [[Evi Vine]], [[Cleveland Watkiss]], [[Henry Lowther (musician)|Henry Lowther]] | website = {{URL|www.philipclemo.com}} }} '''Philip Clemo''' is a British composer, musician, producer, sound artist, filmmaker and visual artist, described by Propermusic.com as one of [[contemporary music]]'s most innovative artists. ==Early life== Philip James Clemo was born on 3 August 1964 in [[Insch]], [[Aberdeenshire]], [[Scotland]]. In his teens Clemo learnt guitar from singer-songwriter Iain MacDonald who introduced him to the works of [[Nick Drake]], [[Tim Buckley]], [[Van Morrison]], [[Jimi Hendrix]] and [[Bob Dylan]]. He began performing in North East Scotland [[folk club]]s. ==Developed style== Moving to London in 1982, influenced by the works of [[Robin Guthrie]] of [[The Cocteau Twins]] and [[Tom Verlaine]] of [[Television (band)|Television]], Clemo began recording his own work. He put together a short-lived [[experimental music]] band Box in the Sun, but left to explore his solo projects. He developed a complex and multi-layered approach, creating music which always sounds fresh to the listener.{{cite web|url=http://tingen.org/interview-philip-clemo/|title=Philip Clemo|author=Paul Tingen|publisher=Paul Tingen|date=2011|accessdate=30 April 2014}} He builds soundworlds from diverse sources including field recordings made in locations such as: the crowded streets of New Delhi; the dense insect soundscapes of the Malaysian [[rainforest]]; Sydney building sites; [[Iceland]]ic [[mud pool]]s; and glass and metal workshops.{{cite journal | last = Royle | first = Nicholas | date = 2009 | title = A profile of Philip Clemo | journal = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = The Guardian & Nicholas Royle }} In the studio Clemo builds complex and densely textured compositions, developing them through a process of composition and improvisation, with contributions from a diverse group of musicians. During the final stages he extensively reconfigures, interweaving instrumental, vocal and recorded material, disguising origin and cultural references. The result is a mix of musical genre, which crosses between [[jazz]], rock, [[contemporary classical music|contemporary classical]] and [[electronica]], described as "finely crafted shimmering matrices of sound"{{cite journal|title=Philip Clemo – The Rooms|publisher=[[Jazzwise]]|date=October 2008}} and creating something which is "mesmeric and completely addictive".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/artists/71181549-1f31-4550-a76d-94d9f2d2c9d5|title=Philip Clemo|publisher=[[BBC Music]]|accessdate=30 April 2014}}{{cite journal|title=Philip Clemo – The Rooms|publisher=The Wire|date=October 2008}} ==Musical career== ===Sound – Inhale the Colours=== [[File:Philip Clemo live, 2017.jpg|thumb|Philip Clemo live, 2017]] Clemo's first two albums were collaborative works with violinist [[Ysanne Spevack]], aka Mee. The pair shared the composition credits, but used Clemo's multi-layered approach to creation and composition. ''Sound – Inhale the Colours'' was created in 1996/7 largely in Sydney, Australia, featuring contributions from an additional eleven musicians. Well reviewed by critics on release, it remained a question for them as to whether it was [[jazz]], [[ambient electronica]] or [[World music]].{{cite journal|title=Sound – Inhale the Colours|author=Tony Marcus|publisher=[[Mix Mag]]|date=1997}}{{cite journal|title=Sound – Inhale the Colours|author=Andrew Rawnsley|publisher=[[XLR8R]]|date=1997}} ===Soundzero=== A second collaborative album ''Soundzero'' was completed in 1999, but only released in March 2008.As stated in the [http://www.chaindlk.com/reviews/?id=4992 Chain D.L.K. review] Both albums featured, amongst others, Phil Slater on trumpet and Tarlochan (Bobby) Singh on [[tabla]]. On ''Soundzero'', Jazz singer [[Cleveland Watkiss]], often heavily processed, made a guest appearance; whilst the album was also the first appearance of a British [[rhythm section]], consisting of: Mark Sanders (drums); John Edwards (double bass); and [[Pete Lockett]] (percussion). ===Ambiguous Dialogues=== Clemo's third album ''Ambiguous Dialogues'', the first under his own name, was released in 2004 on Metier Jazz. Featuring 12 musicians, as well as the British rhythm section it involved contributions from [[Clive Bell]] (reeds), and Tom Chant (soprano saxophone and [[bass clarinet]]). Clemo toured the work post the album's release, which was well reviewed and received.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2006/mar/28/jazz|title=Philip Clemo – 93 Feet East, London|author=John Fordham|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 March 2006|accessdate=30 April 2014}} During the same year, he became a judge for the first time at the British Composer Awards for the [[British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors]], which he has since undertaken again in 2005, 2006, 2010 and 2011. ===The Rooms=== In October 2008, Clemo released his fourth album ''The Rooms''. A musical progression through different sound "rooms" or "spaces", it featured 22 musicians including: Clive Bell; [[Theo Travis]] (saxophone and [[flute]]); Simon Hopkins (electric guitar); [[B.J. Cole|B.J Cole]] (pedal steel); [[Henry Lowther (musician)|Henry Lowther]] (trumpet and flugelhorn); and a [[Prague]] [[string quartet]]. Clemo credited legendary sound engineer Phill Brown, who has worked with [[Jimi Hendrix]] and [[Bob Marley]] among others, for his invaluable contribution to the recording process of ''The Rooms''. The album was critically acclaimed, and reviewed as floating somewhere between [[jazz]], rock and soundtrack,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/mwzf|title=Philip Clemo – The Rooms|author=Chris Jones|publisher=BBC Music|date=October 2008|accessdate=30 April 2014}} with critics describing it as intelligent "fourth world" [[Electronic jazz|electro-jazz]].{{cite magazine|url=http://musicians.allaboutjazz.com/musician.php?id=17571#.U2EOL6LqXpd|title=Philip Clemo|author=Chris Fortescue|magazine=[[All About Jazz]]|date=October 2008|accessdate=30 April 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/oct/17/jazz|title=Jazz review: Philip Clemo: The Rooms|author=John L Walters|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=17 October 2008|accessdate=30 April 2014}} ===Mesmer=== Up to this point, one of Clemo's key instruments of choice to compose with was the guitar. But having become quite bored with what he was playing on it, he moved for his next album to the piano. For a year he created improvisations, charting a deeply personal journey through significant life experiences and environments. These were then given to pianist [http://www.kevinpollard.com/ Kevin Pollard] to interpret and expand, with Clemo then adding additional guitar pieces to shape the compositions. With the basic structure laid out, he then invited 14 additional musicians – one at a time – to "blindly" add their response on top, including: Oren Marshall (tuba); [[B. J. Cole]] (pedal steel guitar); Byron Wallen (trumpet and flugelhorn); Emily Burridge (cello); with [[Thomas Bloch]] ([[Radiohead]], [[Damon Albarn]]) contributing ethereal tones on three instruments (glass harmonica, crystal baschet and ondes martenot). Clemo then heavily edited and shaped their contributions. The album was the first on which Clemo added his own voice, using multi-layering to create harmonies. He finally added additional recorded sounds from places which have great significance to him, including: the river and woods at the end of his childhood garden; his first school; [[Aberdeen railway station]]; [[Redwood National Park]] in northern California; and Plum Village [[Zen Buddhist]] monastery in France.{{cite web|url=http://www.mannersmcdade.co.uk/composer/philip-clemo/|title=Philip Clemo|publisher=Manners McDade|accessdate=30 April 2014}} As with ''The Rooms'', most of the sessions were recorded by Phill Brown, who Clemo sees as crucial in both building powerful creative environments, and capturing a high level of sonic detail in the sessions. The end result, ''Mesmer'', was well reviewed by both the music{{cite web|title=Philip Clemo – Mesmer|website=[[All Music Guide]]}}{{cite magazine|title=Philip Clemo – Mesmer|magazine=[[The Wire (magazine)|The Wire]]|date=October 2012}}{{cite magazine|title=Philip Clemo – Mesmer|magazine=[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]}} and mainstream press,{{cite news|title=Philip Clemo – Mesmer|newspaper=[[The Observer]]|date=October 2012}}{{cite news|title=Philip Clemo – Mesmer|newspaper=[[The Times]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/5d288272-05dd-11e2-bce8-00144feabdc0.html#axzz300MeX88B|title=Philip Clemo – Mesmer|newspaper=[[Financial Times]]|accessdate=30 April 2014}} described as a form of contemporary [[chamber music]] with "improvisation, multi-level musical dialogue and sound design at its core."{{cite web|url=http://www.propermusic.com/product-details/Philip-Clemo-Mesmer-144514|title=Philip Clemo – Mesmer|publisher=propermusic.com|date=October 2012|accessdate=30 April 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303214529/http://www.propermusic.com/product-details/Philip-Clemo-Mesmer-144514|archive-date=3 March 2016|url-status=dead}} ===Dream Maps=== With contributions from 21 musicians including [[Arve Henriksen]] (trumpet), Evi Vine (voice), Byron Wallen (trumpet, flugelhorn), Oren Marshall (tuba), [[Thomas Bloch]] (glass harmonica, Ondes Martenot), Emily Burridge and Peter Gregson (cellos), Dream Maps was released on 9 September 2016 with a live launch with an 8-piece band including Arve Henriksen and Evi Vine at [[Kings Place]], London, UK on 14 September. The concert was described by Richard Williams on [https://thebluemoment.com/2016/09/14/philip-clemo-at-kings-place/ thebluemoment.com] as "Artfully mixed together with recordings of heartbeats and water by the sound engineer [[Phill Brown]], the music washed gently but insistently over the clearly beguiled near-capacity crowd in Kings Place’s Hall 2... this was Clemo’s first live gig in 10 years; its success should encourage him."{{cite web|title=Philip Clemo King's Place review|last1=Williams|first1=Richard|url=https://thebluemoment.com/2016/09/14/philip-clemo-at-kings-place/|website=The Blue Moment|date=14 September 2016 }} Dream Maps was well received by the media with Selwyn Harris in [[Jazzwise]] describing it as "Meditative, trance-like stillness… symphonic ambience… echoes of… Brian Eno and David Sylvian. Miles’ Sketches of Spain reimagined by Jon Hassell."{{cite web|title=Philip Clemo Dream Maps review|last1=Harris|first1=Selwyn|url=http://www.jazzwisemagazine.com|website=Jazzwise}} Grant Moon in [[Prog (magazine)]] said that “Philip Clemo gets close to the edges on his extraordinary sixth album… utterly transfixing”{{cite web|title=Philip Clemo Dream Maps review|last1=Moon|first1=Grant|url=http://teamrock.com/review/2016-11-02/philip-clemo-dream-maps-album-review|website=Team Rock|date=2 November 2016 }} and George Farbey in [[All About Jazz]] said “Mesmerising… irresistible and idiosyncratic. Within a jazz context, could even be regarded as a new kind of third stream” ****{{cite web|title=Philip Clemo Dream Maps review|last1=Farbey|first1=Roger|url=https://www.allaboutjazz.com/dream-maps-philip-clemo-all-colours-arts-review-by-roger-farbey.php|website=All About Jazz|date=13 August 2016 }} Philip Clemo discussed the making of Dream Maps on the [[BBC Radio 3]] programme [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07z6f3q Jazz Now] on 24 October 2016.{{cite web|title=Philip Clemo Dream Maps radio interview|last1=Ryan|first1=Al|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07z6f3q|website=Jazz Now}} ==Film-making== [[File:Philip_Clemo_filming_in_Norway_2013.jpg|thumb|Philip Clemo filming in Norway 2013]] Having started out professionally as a production film editor, including working on the BBC's ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'', since 1989 Clemo has made a series of [[short films]] which have been shown at festivals around the world. One of his early films was ''From The Morning On'', a [[travel documentary|travelogue]] based on a day in the Indian sub-continent. He has since travelled extensively throughout South East Asia and Australasia, with both film camera and sound recording equipment. Having used video projections of his film work extensively in his live musical performances, he filmed his first major project, ''The Air Holds Still on My Breath'' in [[Iceland]] in summer 2008. Shown at Cannes Short Film Corner in 2009, the film, a series of [[abstract art|abstract]] "mood paintings" mapping the "[[Seven Ages of Man]]", features music from ''The Rooms''. It was shot using specialist camera technology to capture extreme slow motion details of geothermal activity and waterfalls, and from the air using a gyro-stabilised camera mounted on a [[helicopter]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arri.com/news.html?article=1258&cHash=4ff2ab275077a959e16e3f3fdd6bd773|title=ALEXA, Alura and aurora borealis|author=Kieron Seth|publisher=[[Arri]]|accessdate=30 April 2014}} Shot using the same technical combination as ''The Air'', Clemo made the short film ''Melt'', which was shown at 2009 Reykjavik International Film Festival 2009 and 2010 London Short Film Festival.{{cite web|url=http://www.reverbnation.com/philipclemo|title=Philip Clemo|publisher=[[Reverb Nation]]|accessdate=30 April 2014}} In late 2013, Clemo developed ''The Breath Project'', encompassing film and art installation, produced by perfectmotion and Animal Monday. ''Breath'' illustrates the dramas of human life through the metaphor of landscape, from isolation and turmoil to exhilaration and transformation. Moving through the seven phases of human life, through ageing human forms and across different terrains of the human body, we see comparisons with the environments of planet Earth. Clemo has presented TEDX and TED talks about his work on Breath. He is currently working with Dr Thomas Moors and the charity Shout at Cancer on 'From Silence Into Song' which honours the legacy of the survivor trees of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, hooking them up to sensors exactly 75 years after the bombs were dropped, and an extraordinary choir of cancer survivors who have learnt how to sing after the removal of their voiceboxes. ==Live performance== Since 2016, Clemo has been performing with his '''Dream Maps Live''' band, working with a diverse group of musicians including [[Arve Henriksen]] (trumpet), Byron Wallen (trumpet, flugelhron), [[B. J. Cole]] (pedal steel), Evi Vine (voice), Simon Edwards (bass), [[Martyn Barker]] (drums, percussion), Emily Burridge (cello) and Steven Hill (guitar & keys). ==Discography== * ''Sound – Inhale the Colours'', 1997, with Mee ([[Ysanne Spevack]]) * ''soundzero'', 1999 (but only released in 2008), with [[Ysanne Spevack]] * ''Ambiguous Dialogues'', 2004 * ''The Rooms'', 2008 * ''Mesmer'', 2012 * ''Dream Maps'', 2016 ==Filmography== * ''Box in the Sun'', 1990 * ''From the Morning On'', 1990 * ''Objects and Observations'', 1993 * ''Thieves – Unworthy promo'', 1994 * ''An Altered Perspective (Journeys in the East)'', 1995 * ''Metal on Water'', 1999 * ''Separated by Shadows (shown during 2005/6 UK tour)'', 2005 * ''The Air Holds Still on My Breath (Iceland Journey)'', 2009 * ''Melt'', 2009 * ''Sigur Rós – Fjögur Píanó'', 2012 * ''The Mesmer vignettes'', 2012 * ''Return'', 2013 * ''Wide-eyed'', 2013 * ''Orchid'', 2013 * ''The Memory of Objects: Château de Rochebonne, France'', 2014 * ''Water in the Flow (with Evi Vine)'', 2016 * ''Shadow Seas (with Evi Vine)'', 2017 * ''Breath (Journeys Through the Landscapes of Life)'', 2018 * ''Lark'', 2018 * ''Evi Vine: My Only Son'', 2019 * ''Hayley Ross: Dernier Baiser'', 2019 * ''Magnetic (with Arve Henriksen & Evi Vine)'', 2021 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.philipclemo.com/ Official Website] *{{IMDb name|3083132|Philip Clemo}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Clemo, Philip}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Aberdeenshire]] [[Category:British experimental filmmakers]] [[Category:British composers]] [[Category:Scottish composers]] [[Category:British record producers]] [[Category:British experimental musicians]] [[Category:British sound artists]] [[Category:British installation artists]] [[Category:British video artists]] [[Category:British filmmakers]] [[Category:Scottish contemporary artists]]

{{Short description|Canadian-American actor}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox person |image = |imagesize = | name = Steve Mackall | birth_name = Stephen James Mackall | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|12|09}} | birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Voice actor, voice-over announcer, comedian, director, screenwriter, songwriter <!-- as listed on his website --> | spouse = | children = | yearsactive = 1980s–present | website = {{URL|http://www.stevemackall.com}} }}
'''Stephen James "Steve" Mackall''' (born December 9, 1959) is a Canadian-American voice actor, voice-over announcer, comedian, director, screenwriter and songwriter.<ref name="Los Angeles Times"/> He was known as the voice of [[NBC]]'s [[Must See TV]],<ref name="Los Angeles Times"/> and performed voice of the lead character of [[Marsupilami]] in both the [[Disney Television Animation|Disney]] animated [[television series]] ''[[Raw Toonage]]'' (1992) and ''[[Marsupilami (1993 TV series)|Marsupilami]]'' (1993).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/person/340369/Steve-Mackall |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103060905/http://movies.nytimes.com/person/340369/Steve-Mackall |url-status=dead |archive-date=3 November 2012 |department=Movies & TV Dept. |work=[[The New York Times]] |publisher=[[Baseline (database)|Baseline]] & [[All Movie Guide]] |date=2012 |title=Steve Mackall |accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref>
==Background== Mackall graduated from [[Padua Franciscan High School]] and [[Ohio University]].<ref name="Cleveland Plain Dealer"/> After having won a trip to [[Los Angeles]] as first prize in a 1986 [[HBO]] [[comedy]] contest in [[Washington D.C.]],<ref name="Cleveland Plain Dealer"/> he decided to leave Washington and live in Los Angeles, working as a [[copywriter]] while pursuing his comedy career.<ref name="Los Angeles Times">{{cite news |last=Morin |first=Monte |title=A Voice For All Seasons |url= |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=December 26, 1997}}</ref><ref name="Cleveland Plain Dealer"/> He began doing voice-over work in commercials in 1989.<ref name="Los Angeles Times"/> Representative samples of his commercial work include being the voice of the cereal box for [[General Mills]]' 1993 [[Fingos]] promotion campaign,<ref name="The New York Times 2">{{cite news |last=Elliott |first=Stuart |title=THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; General Mills Tries to Position Cereal Beyond the Breakfast Table. (page 2) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/08/02/business/media-business-advertising-general-mills-tries-position-cereal-beyond-breakfast.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm |accessdate=September 1, 2012 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 2, 1993}}</ref> and products and companies including [[CompUSA]] and [[Froot Loops]], as well as being voice-over announcer for [[NBC]], [[The WB]], and [[Fox Kids Network]].<ref name="Cleveland Plain Dealer"/>
He is also recognized as the voice of Hyperman in the ''Adventures of Hyperman'' [[CD-ROM]] game released in 1995 which was followed by the [[Hyperion Pictures|Hyperion Animation]]/[[CBS]] Television Series, ''[[The Adventures of Hyperman]]'', that aired from November 4, 1995 to August 10, 1996.<ref name="Washington Post">{{cite news |last=Moore |first=Scott |url-access=subscription |title=Old, New and Out of the Blue |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/19405940.html?dids=19405940:19405940&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+10%2C+1995&author=Scott+Moore&pub=The+Washington+Post+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Old%2C+New+and+Out+of+the+Blue&pqatl=google |accessdate=September 1, 2012 |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |date=September 10, 1995}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hyperionpictures.com/user_files/anim_archive/hyperman.php |title=The Adventures of Hyperman |publisher=[[Hyperion Pictures]]|accessdate=16 October 2010}}</ref>
==Filmography==
===Television voice=== * ''[[Raw Toonage]]'' (12 episodes, 1992) as Marsupilami * ''[[The Pink Panther (1993 TV series)|The Pink Panther]]'' (2 episodes, 1993) * ''[[Marsupilami (1993 TV series)|Marsupilami]]'' (13 episodes, 1993) as Marsupilami * ''[[Duckman|Duckman: Private Dick/Family Man]]'' (1 episode, 1994) * ''[[The Shnookums and Meat Funny Cartoon Show]]'' (1 episode, 1995) as Husband * ''[[The Adventures of Hyperman]]'' (1995) as Hyperman * ''[[Quack Pack]]'' (1 episode, 1996) * ''[[Mighty Ducks (TV series)|Mighty Ducks]]'' (26 episodes, 1996-1997) as Nosedive Flashblade * ''[[Timon & Pumbaa (TV series)|Timon & Pumbaa]]'' (4 episodes, 1995-1999) as Happy Dog * ''[[Digimon: Digital Monsters]]'' (1 episode, 2001) as Fox Kids' Digimon Announcer * ''[[Totally Spies!]]'' (1 episode, 2001) as Macker, the Safecracker * ''[[Mon Colle Knights]]'' " (2001) a Fox Kids' Mon Colle Knights Announcer
===Film voice=== * ''[[All Dogs Go to Heaven 2]]'' (1996) as Short Customs Dog * ''[[Mighty Ducks the Movie: The First Face-Off]]'' (1997) as Nosedive * ''[[Annabelle's Wish]]'' (1997) as Owliver * ''[[The Secret of NIMH 2: Timmy to the Rescue]]'' (1998) as Dr. Valentine * ''[[Dead Man on Campus]]'' (1998) as TV Show Host (live acting) * ''[[Disaster!]]'' (2006) as V.D. Johnson / Astronomer
===Screenwriter=== * ''[[Avenging Angelo]]'' (2002)<ref name=Variety>{{cite news |last=Rooney |first=David |title=Avenging Angelo |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=October 17, 2002}}</ref> * ''[[Stealing Cars]]'' (2015)
==Theater== * ''Wherever I Go, There we Are''<ref name="LA Weekly"/> * ''The LAF Supper''<ref name="LA Weekly"/>
==Recognition== ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' writes that "Mackall is one of a small group of Hollywood artists who have achieved a faceless fame..." "probably best known as the voice of [[NBC]]'s [[Must See TV]]",<ref name="Los Angeles Times"/> and ''[[Cleveland Plain Dealer]]'' wrote that he was "valued as an artist who can improvise voices for anything from animals to inanimate objects."<ref name="Cleveland Plain Dealer">{{cite news |last=Feran |first=Tom |title=Parma Native has A Voice to Remember |url= |newspaper=[[Cleveland Plain Dealer]] |date=July 10, 2001}}</ref>
Of Mackall's one man show, ''Wherever I Go, There we Are''. ''[[LA Weekly]]'' wrote that his "wealth of experience as a voiceover artist and comedy scribe manifests itself in his artfully layered, near flawlessly timed and often funny solo act." They noted that his personal enthusiasm connected with the audience in a manner that reminded of [[Will Rogers]].<ref name="LA Weekly">{{cite news |last=Crogan |first=Jim |title=stage review: Wherever I Go, There We Are |url= |newspaper=[[LA Weekly]] |date=August 14–20, 1998}}</ref> In their review, ''[[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage West]]'' wrote that when recounting the nine stories which made up his performance, "Mackall is a strong performer" whose "speaking ability commands the attention and carries the audience through captivating and well-detailed portraits of near-otherworldly scapes."<ref name="Backstage West">{{cite news |last=Neil |first=Ken |title=theater review: ''Wherever I Go, There We Are'' |url= |newspaper=[[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage West]] |date=July 30, 1998}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{IMDb name|0533111}}
{{authority control}}

{{short description|British musician (born 1960)}} {{distinguish|Johnny Marr}} {{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2021}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = John Maher | image = | caption = | image_size = | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|4|21|df=y}} | death_date = | origin = [[Manchester]], England | instrument = Drums | genre = [[Punk rock]], [[New wave music|new wave]], [[post-punk]] | occupation = Musician, photographer, engineer, car racer | years_active = {{hlist|1976–1992|2012–present}} | associated_acts = [[Buzzcocks]], [[The Invisible Girls]], [[Wah!]], [[Flag of Convenience (band)|Flag of Convenience]], The Things, [[Penetration (band)|Penetration]] | website = }}
'''John Maher''' (born 21 April 1960)<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title=JOHN MAHER (21 aprile 1960): batteria |encyclopedia=Enciclopedia della musica rock : 1970–1979 |first=Cesare |last=Rizzi |publisher=Giunti |year=1996 |isbn=978-88-09-21523-8 |language=it}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Frame |first=Pete |authorlink=Pete Frame |title=Pete Frame's Rockin' Around Britain: Rock'n'roll Landmarks of the UK and Ireland |publisher=Omnibus |year=1999 |isbn=978-0-7119-6973-5 |chapter=John Maher, 21 April 1960 (Buzzcocks) |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/peteframesrockin0000fram }}</ref> is a British musician who was part of the [[Punk rock|punk]] and [[New wave music|new wave]] scenes in [[Manchester]], England, most notably as the drummer with [[Buzzcocks]].<ref name="NME Rock 'N' Roll Years">{{cite book | first= John | last= Tobler | year= 1992 | title= NME Rock 'N' Roll Years | edition= 1st | publisher=Reed International Books Ltd | location= London | page= 352 | id= CN 5585}}</ref>
==Music career== Maher's father and mother were from [[Castledermot]], [[Athy]], [[Kildare]], Ireland.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newhormonesinfo.com/category/the-full-story/ |first=Justin |last=Toland |year=2008 |title=Indie Originals: The New Hormones Story |website=Newhormonesinfo.com |accessdate=13 March 2016}}</ref> In 1976, still a 16-year-old schoolboy from [[St Bede's College, Manchester|St Bede's College]], [[Whalley Range, Greater Manchester|Whalley Range]], Manchester, he joined punk band [[Buzzcocks]], then led by [[Howard Devoto]], who was the lead vocalist. After the first Buzzcocks dissolving in 1981, he collaborated with [[Pauline Murray]] of [[The Invisible Girls]],<ref name="NME Rock 'N' Roll Years"/> and formed along with [[Steve Diggle]] (also of Buzzcocks) a band called [[Flag of Convenience (band)|Flag of Convenience]], in 1982, but he quit shortly afterwards. In 1981, he was drumming with [[Pete Wylie]] in Wah!<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nkvdrecords.com/buzzcock.htm |title=Buzzcocks |work=NKVD Records |accessdate=18 January 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221024356/http://www.nkvdrecords.com/buzzcock.htm |archivedate=21 December 2008}}</ref>
Buzzcocks reunited in late 1989 for a month long tour of the US and seven shows in the UK. While the other members of the band decided to continue, Maher left to continue with his VW business (see below). He returned once more in early 1992, when his replacement ([[Mike Joyce (musician)|Mike Joyce]], formerly of [[The Smiths]]), quit Buzzcocks on the eve of a European and Japanese tour.
In May 2012, Maher stepped out of musical retirement to rejoin Buzzcocks for two one-off shows: his first public appearance behind a drum kit in 20 years. The concerts took place at Manchester Apollo and London's Brixton Academy. Howard Devoto, the band's original vocalist also joined the band on stage for five songs – all four tracks from their debut EP, ''Spiral Scratch'', plus a cover version of The Troggs' "Can't Control Myself". Maher spoke about his brief return to the stage in an interview with online fanzine ''Mudkiss''. Another interview with Maher appears in the first issue of ''The Drummers Journal''.
In 2014, Maher reunited with another Manchester band he had previously been involved with during his Buzzcocks years: The Things.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thethingsband.com/ |title=The Things |website=Thethingsband.com |accessdate=13 March 2016}}</ref> The band recorded several songs, both old and new, during the summer of 2014. An EP (entitled ''EP1'') containing four tracks was released in mid 2015.
In 2015, Maher was back in the recording studio with old friends Pauline Murray and Robert Blamire, working on a new [[Penetration (band)|Penetration]] album – the first since the band's 1979 release, ''Coming Up For Air''. Maher and Blamire first worked together in 1978, on [[Patrik Fitzgerald]]'s debut album ''Grubby Stories''. In 1980 they also worked together on the [[Martin Hannett]] produced [[Pauline Murray and the Invisible Girls (album)|Pauline Murray and the Invisible Girls]] album. The new album ''Resolution'' took the runner-up spot in Vive Le Rock's Top 50 albums of 2015.
In August 2015, the website [[Louder Than War (website)|Louder Than War]] published an in-depth interview with Maher.
==Drag racing== When Maher first quit the [[music industry]] in the 1980s, he developed an interest in car [[drag racing]], racing [[VW Beetle]]s as part of the VWDRC. This led him to develop a successful business, '''John Maher Racing''', building performance engines. After reuniting with Buzzcocks in 1989, he retired from music in 1992 after a tour, and returned to his Volkswagen business in [[Chorlton-cum-Hardy]], in the south of [[Manchester]]. In 1999, Maher's workshop was featured in the [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] programme ''Stars & Cars''. This featured footage of his former incarnation as a drummer, a tour of his workshop, and interviews.
Maher relocated his business from Manchester to the [[Isle of Harris]] in Scotland in 2002. In 2010 he appeared on the [[BBC Alba]] motoring programme ''Air an Rathad''. The interview features footage inside his workshop on the Isle of Harris, a brief interview and a drive in one of his customers' VW Beetle.
==Photography== Since 2009, Maher has gained recognition for his photography; in particular his long-exposure night photographs and interior images of abandoned Hebridean homes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/opinion/13410935.It_is_time_to_wield_the_stick_on_empty_homes/ |title=It is time to wield the stick on empty homes |date=1 June 2015 |newspaper=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] |location=Glasgow |accessdate=13 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=The lonely island: abandoned houses of the Hebrides – in pictures |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2016/aug/17/nobodys-home-john-maher-outer-hebrides-photography-in-pictures |work=The Guardian |date=17 August 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://johnmaherracing.com/ JMR – John Maher Racing] John Maher Racing * [http://www.theflyingmonk.co.uk/ The Flying Monk] Photography by John Maher * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4SmWFTQPFG0 Air an Rathad – BBC Alba] John Maher TV interview 2010 * [http://www.mudkiss.com/johnmaherinterview.htm Mudkiss.com] John Maher talks to Melanie Smith, 2012 * [http://thedrummersjournal.com/ The Drummers Journal] John Maher interview in Issue #1 * [http://louderthanwar.com/nostalgia-age-yet-come-ex-buzzcocks-current-penetration-drummer-john-maher-interviewed-ged-babey/ Louder Than War] John Maher interview 2015
{{Buzzcocks}} {{The Invisible Girls}} {{Authority control}}

{{short description|American musician, singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}} {{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=April 2014}} {{more footnotes|date=April 2014}} {{Unreliable sources|date=April 2021}} }} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Gaelle Adisson | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1974}} | origin = [[South Orange, New Jersey]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/GAELLE24|title=Security Check Required|website=[[Facebook]] |publisher=|accessdate=May 3, 2016}}</ref> | genre = {{flat list| *[[Deep house]] *[[contemporary R&B|R&B]] *[[soul music|soul]] *dance *[[downtempo]] *[[electronic music|electronic]] }} | occupation = {{flat list | *Singer-songwriter *producer }} | years_active = 1997–present | label = Naked Music }}
'''Gaelle Adisson''' (born 1974) is an American [[deep house]] and [[downtempo]] singer-songwriter/producer born in [[New Jersey]].
==Life Style== Adisson contributed vocals on the 1999 global hit "[[King of My Castle]]", a song by the [[Chris Brann|Wamdue Project]]. "King of My Castle" peaked at the top of the [[UK Singles Chart]] and [[UK Dance Chart]] in November 1999. It also made the top ten in Denmark, France, and Germany.
In 2004, Gaelle released her debut album, ''[[Transient (album)|Transient]]'' through the label Naked Music. Her style is known for its smooth signature.
==Influences== Born to Haitian parents, Adisson has created a cultural hybrid that has influenced her music.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/mzp2/ |title=Gaelle Transient Review |editor=Dene, Lewis |year=2005 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=May 28, 2017}}</ref> The following artists have also influenced her:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/GAELLEmusic/info?tab=page_info|title=Gaelle|website=[[Facebook]] |publisher=|accessdate=May 3, 2016}}</ref> [[Patti LaBelle]], [[Radiohead]], [[Portishead (band)|Portishead]], [[Cocteau Twins]], [[Peter Gabriel]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[Sade (band)|Sade]], [[Björk]], [[Duran Duran]], [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], [[Hugh Masekela]], [[Julio Iglesias]], [[Nina Simone]], [[Trevor Horn]], [[Trent Reznor]] and [[Donna Summer]].
==Discography==
===Albums=== * 2004 ''[[Transient (album)|Transient]]''
===Other works=== *1997 "[[King of My Castle]]" – Single *1999 "Cascades of Colour" – Single *2002 "Mercy Street" – Single *2007 "Give It Back" – Maxi Single
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://soundcloud.com/gaelle-gabbythegood-adisson Gaelle on SoundCloud (unreleased songs)] *[https://www.myspace.com/gaelleonline Gaelle on Myspace] *[http://www.discogs.com/artist/Gaelle+Adisson?anv=Gaelle Gaelle on discogs.com] *[http://www.clatl.com/music/article/13017595/music_of_her_mind/ Creative Loafing article about Gaelle and her album ''Transient'']
{{Authority control}}

{{Short description|American historian}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2021}} {{Infobox person | name = David Nasaw | image = PhotographofDavidNasawbyTiernan.jpg | caption = Nasaw in 2012 | birth_name = David George Nasaw | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|07|18}} | birth_place = [[Cortland, New York]], U.S.[https://web.archive.org/web/20150329170019/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-2699300091.html "Nasaw, David 1945-"], ''Contemporary Authors, New Revision Series'' (January 1, 2007). | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | other_names = | known_for = Historian, author | education = [[Bucknell University]] (B.A)
[[Columbia University]] (Ph.D) | employer = [[City University of New York]] | occupation = [[Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.]] Professor of History | spouse = {{marriage|[[Dinitia Smith]]|1978}} | children = 2 | website = }} '''David Nasaw''' (born July 18, 1945) is an American author, [[biographer]] and [[historian]] who specializes in the cultural, social and business history of early 20th Century America.{{cite news |newspaper=Scripps Howard News Service |title=What a difference a day makes |date=November 19, 2001}} Nasaw is on the faculty of the Graduate Center of the [[City University of New York]], where he is the [[Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.]] Professor of History.{{cite web |title=David Nasaw |url=http://www.gc.cuny.edu/Page-Elements/Academics-Research-Centers-Initiatives/Doctoral-Programs/History/Faculty/David-Nasaw |publisher=City University of New York |access-date=July 31, 2012}} In addition to writing numerous scholarly and popular books, he has written for publications such as the ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'', ''American Historical Review'', ''American Heritage'', ''[[Dissent (American magazine)|Dissent]]'', ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', ''[[The London Review of Books]]'', and ''[[Condé Nast Traveler]]''. Nasaw has appeared in several documentaries, including ''The American Experience, 1996'', and two episodes of the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]]'s April 2006 miniseries ''[[10 Days That Unexpectedly Changed America]]'': "The [[Homestead Strike]]" and "The [[Assassination of President McKinley]]". He is cited extensively in the US and British media as an expert on the history of popular entertainment and the news media, and as a critic of American philanthropy. == Early life and education == David George Nasaw was born on July 18, 1945, in [[Cortland, New York]], the oldest son of lawyer Joshua Nasaw (1909{{ndash}}1970) and Beatrice Kaplan (1917{{ndash}}2010), an elementary school teacher.Donna Duffy, [http://www.antonnews.com/roslynnews/obits/6843-obituary-beatrice-nasaw.html "Obituary – Beatrice Nasaw"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125080349/http://www.antonnews.com/roslynnews/obits/6843-obituary-beatrice-nasaw.html |date=January 25, 2012 }}, ''The Roslyn News'' (March 24, 2010). Nasaw is the older brother of Jonathan Lewis Nasaw (b. August 26, 1947),[https://web.archive.org/web/20160224232712/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3449200111.html "Nasaw, Jonathan Lewis"], ''Contemporary Authors, New Revision Series'' (January 1, 2006). the prolific author of at least nine [[thriller (genre)|thrillers]];[http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/n/jonathan-nasaw/ "Jonathan Nasaw"].[http://authors.simonandschuster.com.au/Jonathan-Nasaw/1829733/author_revealed "Jonathan Nasaw Revealed"].[http://authors.simonandschuster.com.au/Jonathan-Nasaw/1829733/books "Jonathan Nasaw Books"] and Elizabeth Perl Nasaw (May 29, 1956 {{ndash}} February 28, 2004),[http://dreamtimevillage.org/wlyx/ "Radio WLYX"]. who as "Elizabeth Was" (later "Liz Was" and finally "Lyx Ish") was a poet and publisher of [[avant-garde]] magazines,[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE0D6123AF93BA25752C0A9669D8B63 "Nasaw, Beatrice"], ''The New York Times'' (January 18, 2010). and the cofounder of Xexoxial Editions and [[Dreamtime Village]] in [[West Lima, Wisconsin]].Maria Damon, ''Postliterary America: From Bagel Shop Jazz to Micropoetries: Contemp North American Poetry'' (University of Iowa Press, 2011):201.Matt Gross, [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/20/travel/20frugal.html?pagewanted=all "Into Middle America but Staying on the Fringe"], ''The New York Times'' (June 20, 2007). Nasaw grew up in [[Roslyn, New York]], and, after a year studying in Denmark as an exchange student,[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19630109&id=EXBIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tBAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5222,2209906 "Pupils Work to Make Exchange Program Success"], ''The Milwaukee Sentinel'' (January 9, 1963), Page 8, part 2. graduated from [[Roslyn High School]] in 1963.[http://www.rhs1963reunion.org/contact-infomation/n.html "Roslyn High School Class of 1963 50th Reunion"] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.today/20130416043053/http://www.rhs1963reunion.org/contact-infomation/n.html |date=April 16, 2013 }}. Nasaw graduated from [[Bucknell University]] with a Bachelor of Arts in 1967, before enrolling in [[Columbia University]], where he was awarded a Ph.D. in 1972 for his dissertation "Jean-Paul Sartre: Apprenticeship in History (1925–45)".[http://www.worldcat.org/title/jean-paul-sartre-apprenticeship-in-history-1925-45/oclc/036603832 "Jean-Paul Sartre: Apprenticeship in History (1925–45)"].[http://en.scientificcommons.org/3812348 Publication View] While studying at Columbia University, for more than two years from 1970 Nasaw was one of two full-time teachers in the Elizabeth Cleaners Street School,Elizabeth Cleaners Street School, ''Starting Your Own High School: The Story of an Alternative High School'' (Vintage Books, 1972):27."Another Look at Student Rights and the Function of Schooling: The Elizabeth Cleaners Street School", ''The Harvard Educational Review'' (Winter 1970). a short-lived experimental alternative free high school founded in New York City. The experience gave rise to the book "Starting Your Own High School," written by the students and edited by Nasaw.{{cite book |title=Starting Your Own High School |year=1972 |publisher=Random House}} == Career == Nasaw began teaching history at the [[College of Staten Island]] in 1978.[http://www1.cuny.edu/events/cunymatters/October_2001/appointed.html "Nine Leading Scholars Named Distinguished Professors"], ''CUNY Matters'' (October 2001). During the 1987–1988 academic year, he was as a Fulbright Professor of American Studies at [[Hebrew University]] in Jerusalem.David Nasaw, ''Going Out: The Rise and Fall of Public Amusements'' (Harvard University Press, 1999):vii.Mari Rich, Olivia J. Smith, and Clifford Thompson, eds., ''World Authors, 1995–2000'' (H.W. Wilson, 2003):592. Nasaw has been on the doctoral faculty of the City University of New York's Graduate Center since 1990, where he also served as chairman. He was director of the CUNY Graduate Center's Center for the Humanities, and the chairman of the advisory board of the Leon Levy Center for Biography at the university.{{cite web|title=Board |url=http://centerforthehumanities.org/board/board |publisher=Center for the Humanities |access-date=July 31, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120709003418/http://centerforthehumanities.org/board/board |archive-date=July 9, 2012 }}{{cite web |title=About us: Officers |url=http://web.gc.cuny.edu/llcb/about_staff.html |publisher=Leon Levy Center for Biography}} Nasaw is a founder of the ''[[Radical History Review]]''. == Personal life == Since June 10, 1978, Nasaw has been married to [[Dinitia Smith]],''Cumberland Evening Times'' (June 26, 1967):9.{{Cite web |url=http://wps.prenhall.com/hss_hirschberg_millennium_4/29/7559/1935320.cw/index.html |title=Dinitia Smith |access-date=August 13, 2012 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130201004931/http://wps.prenhall.com/hss_hirschberg_millennium_4/29/7559/1935320.cw/index.html |archive-date=February 1, 2013 |url-status=dead }} a novelist, [[Emmy award]]-winning filmmaker,[http://www.mediabistro.com/galleycat/dinitia-smith-leaves-full-time-post-at-nyt_b3520 "Dinitia Smith Leaves Full-Time Post at NYT"] ''Galleycat'' (December 21, 2006). and journalist, who worked as a correspondent for ''The New York Times'' for 12 years.Daniel Nasaw, [http://www.danielnasaw.com/about "About"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719044907/http://www.danielnasaw.com/about |date=July 19, 2012 }}{{cite news |title=Making Books |newspaper=New York Times |date=April 5, 2001}} They are the parents of twin sons: Peter Caleb Nasaw and journalist Daniel Allen Nasaw, born in 1980.{{cite web |title=About |url=http://www.danielnasaw.com/about |publisher=Daniel Nasaw |access-date=July 31, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120719044907/http://www.danielnasaw.com/about |archive-date=July 19, 2012 |url-status=dead }} == Thoughts == Although he has published three biographies, Nasaw describes himself as an academic historian, rather than a biographer.{{cite news |title=The Taming Of the Story |date=June 5, 2006 |newspaper=New York Sun |author=Gary Shapiro}} A historian, he says, "sweeps away the fables, the myths, the stories" and places scholarly subjects "in time and over time", while for biographers, the organization of the work is laid out in advance. "Writing history is not an art but a craft," Nasaw has said.{{cite news |title=Writers Beware: History Is an Art, Not a Toaster |newspaper=New York Times |date=February 28, 2002 |author=Martin Arnold |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/02/28/books/making-books-writers-beware-history-is-an-art-not-a-toaster.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm}} "It requires interpretation and fifty sources and integrating and assembling this material into a story told by an individual voice." == Awards == * 2013 – Finalist, [[Pulitzer Prize]] for biography * 2007 – Finalist, [[Pulitzer Prize]] for biography * 2006 – [[American History Book Prize]] * 2006 – [[New-York Historical Society]] American History Book Prize{{cite web |title=The New-York Historical Society American History Book Prize |url=http://www.nyhistory.org/news/book-prize}} * 2001 – [[Bancroft Prize]] * 2001 – [[Ambassador Book Award]] * 2001 – [[J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize]]{{cite web |title=J. Anthony Lukas Prize Project winners |url=http://www.nieman.harvard.edu/NiemanFoundation/Awards/AwardsAtAGlance/JAnthonyLukasPrizeProject/Winners.aspx |publisher=Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard |access-date=March 16, 2011}} * 2001 – Ann M. Sperber Biography Award for Journalism{{cite web |title=Sperber Prize Winners |url=http://www.fordham.edu/academics/programs_at_fordham_/communication_and_me/sperber_award/list_of_prize_recipi_77659.asp}} == Bibliography == {{Expand list|date=December 2020}} === Books === * {{cite book |editor=Nasaw, David |title=Starting your own high school |publisher=Random House |year=1972 }} * ''Schooled to Order: A Social History of Public Schooling in United States'' (Oxford University Press, 1979, 1980). * ''Children of the City: At Work and at Play'' (Anchor Press/Doubleday, 1985; Oxford University Press, 1986). In this Nasaw's highly cited history, Nasaw "unearthed the long-forgotten story of the Newsboy Strike."{{cite news |last=Barry |first=Dan |title=Read All About It! Kids Vex Titans! |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/04/theater/disneys-newsies-the-musical-comes-to-broadway.html?pagewanted=all |access-date=June 2, 2012 |newspaper=New York Times |date=March 4, 2012}} The book inspired the Disney film ''[[Newsies]]'' and the subsequent Broadway musical.{{cite news|author-link1=Robert Simonson |last=Simonson |first=Robert |title=Joseph Pulitzer, the "Villain" of Newsies, Illuminated |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/164745-ASK-PLAYBILLCOM-Joseph-Pulitzer-the-Villain-of-Newsies-Illuminated |access-date=June 2, 2012 |newspaper=Playbill |date=April 11, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415122127/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/164745-ASK-PLAYBILLCOM-Joseph-Pulitzer-the-Villain-of-Newsies-Illuminated |archive-date=April 15, 2012 }} * ''Course of United States History: To 1877'', Vol. 1, ed. (Thomson Wadsworth, 1987) * ''Going Out: The Rise and Fall of Public Amusements'' (Basic Books, 1993) ''Going Out'' "unearths fascinating details about everything from the early history of the movies to pre-World War I dance crazes," wrote critic Jackson Lears in the New York Times.{{cite news |title=Don't Get Around Much Anymore |url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/99/05/02/nnp/nasaw-out.html |date=January 9, 1994 |author=Jackson Lears |work=The New York Times}} Nasaw "raises fundamental questions about the web of connections joining commercial play, public space and cultural cohesion," he wrote. * ''The Chief: The Life of William Randolph Hearst'' (Houghton Mifflin, 2000) Nasaw's 2000 biography of the American newspaper baron was praised as "an absorbing and ingeniously organized biography... of the most powerful publisher America has ever known",{{cite news |last=Evans |first=Harold |title=Press Baron's Progress |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/02/books/press-baron-s-progress.html?ref=bookreviews |access-date=June 2, 2012 |newspaper=New York Times |date=July 2, 2000}} and for "immediacy that almost makes the reader forget that the author himself was not there as the story unfolded".{{cite news |title=Hearst, Man and Mogul: Going Beyond the Myths |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/28/books/books-of-the-times-hearst-man-and-mogul-going-beyond-the-myths.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |access-date=June 1, 2012 |newspaper=New York Times |date=June 28, 2000 |first=Orville |last=Schell}} In 2001, ''The Chief'' won the [[J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize]] and the [[Bancroft Prize]] for American history. It was nominated for a National Book Critics Circle Award. * ''Andrew Carnegie'' (Penguin Press, 2006) Nasaw's 2006 biography of the American steel mogul, was a finalist for the 2007 [[Pulitzer Prize]] for biography.{{cite web |author=Richard Ellmann |url=http://www.pulitzer.org/bycat/Biography-or-Autobiography |title=The Pulitzer Prizes | Biography or Autobiography |publisher=Pulitzer.org |access-date=July 31, 2012}} A reviewer praised Nasaw for "bringing to life the fascinating world of business moguls, statesmen, journalists and intellectuals in which Carnegie moved."{{cite news |title=Exploring the complex life of steelmaker Andrew Carnegie |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-03-04/entertainment/0703020463_1_david-nasaw-andrew-carnegie-business |access-date=June 1, 2012 |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date=March 4, 2007 |first=Richard R |last=John}} Praising Nasaw's "keen all-rounder's eye", [[Christopher Hitchens]] wrote: "The great strength of this immense biography is the way in which David Nasaw causes these tributaries — capitalism, radicalism, and educational aspiration — to converge like the three rivers (the Allegheny, the Ohio, and the Monongahela) whose confluence makes the site of Pittsburgh possible."{{cite news |last=Hitchens |first=Christopher |title=Rich Man's Burden: The Steely Resolve of Andrew Carnegie |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2006/12/rich-man-8217-s-burden/5372/1/ |access-date=June 2, 2012 |newspaper=Atlantic Magazine |date=December 2006}} The book was among ''The New York Times''' 100 Notable Books of the Year, and among the Favorite Books of 2006 by the ''Los Angeles Times'', which praised it as "a fresh and thorough assessment." * ''The Patriarch: The Remarkable Life and Turbulent Times of Joseph P. Kennedy'' (Penguin Press, November 2012) Following the success of Nasaw's 2000 biography of [[William Randolph Hearst]], Senator [[Ted Kennedy]] approached Nasaw to write a biography of his father, Kennedy patriarch [[Joseph P. Kennedy]]. Nasaw told the family that as an academic historian, he had no interest in writing an "authorized biography".{{cite news |title=AUTHOR ENJOYS FULL ACCESS FOR BOOK ON KENNEDY PATRIARCH |newspaper=Boston Globe |date=August 5, 2006 |author=David Mehegan}} "I told him I would undertake this project if I had guarantees to see all the documents at the Kennedy Library and elsewhere, and if I were free to write whatever I wanted, with no censorship or interference of any kind," Nasaw said. Senator Kennedy said he had read and admired Nasaw's book on Hearst and believed the historian would make a "fair evaluation of his life and contributions." The Kennedy family agreed to sit for interviews and to make Joseph Kennedy's private papers available. After publication, the book was nominated for the Pulitzer Prize for Biography in 2013. * {{cite book |author=Nasaw, David |title=The last million : Europe's displaced persons from World War to Cold War |publisher=Allen Lane |year=2020 }} === Articles === * "Earthly Delights," ''[http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1998/03/23/1998_03_23_066_TNY_LIBRY_000015188 The New Yorker]'' March 23, 1998 * "The Empire Builders," ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/11/24/books/the-empire-builders.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm New York Times]'' November 24, 2002 * "Hitler, Stalin, O'Malley and Moses," ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/25/books/hitler-stalin-o-malley-and-moses.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm New York Times]'' May 25, 2003 * "A Real Nice Clambécque," ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/21/books/a-real-nice-clambecque.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm New York Times]'' September 21, 2003 * "They Wanted to Shape Up America," ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/27/books/books-of-the-times-they-wanted-to-shape-up-america.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm New York Times]'' September 27, 2003 * "Billionaires to the Rescue," ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/04/opinion/04nasaw.html New York Times]'' July 4, 2006 * "Giving back, big time," ''Los Angeles Times'' – November 2, 2006 * "Looking the Carnegie Gift Horse in the Mouth," ''[http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/history_lesson/2006/11/looking_the_carnegie_gift_horse_in_the_mouth.html Slate.com]'' November 10, 2006 * "We Can't Rely on the Kindness of Billionaires," ''[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/09/21/AR2007092101541.html Washington Post]'' September 23, 2007 * "The Rich Threaten Democracy," ''[http://triblive.com/news/columnists/1314707-85/guest-columnists-carnegie-government-philanthropy-democracy-giving-money-private-public Pittsburgh Tribune]'' October 14, 2007 * "A Violent Regeneration," ''[http://prospect.org/article/violent-regeneration-0 American Prospect]'' May 23, 2009 * "Banking on the Future," ''The Wall Street Journal'' – May 17, 2011 * {{cite journal |author=Nasaw, David |date=Winter 2019 |title=A 'fool for peace' |journal=Carnegie Reporter |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=38–45 |url=https://www.carnegie.org/publications/carnegie-reporter-vol-11number-1/ }} ===Critical studies and reviews of Nasaw's work=== ;''The last million'' * {{cite news | last = Hoffman | first = Adina | title = How a Million Refugees Became Postwar Pawns of the Allies | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/15/books/review/the-last-million-david-nasaw.html | date = September 15, 2020 | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] }} * {{cite journal |author=Fitzpatrick, Sheila |author-link=Sheila Fitzpatrick |date=January–February 2021 |title=Knotty problems : an examination of Europe's displaced persons |journal=Australian Book Review |volume=428 |pages=12, 14}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{C-SPAN|50169}} * [https://www.gc.cuny.edu/Page-Elements/Academics-Research-Centers-Initiatives/Doctoral-Programs/History/Faculty-Bios/David-Nasaw gc.cuny.edu] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nasaw, David}} faculty]] [[Category:Historians of the United States]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Hebrew University of Jerusalem faculty]] [[Category:People from Cortland, New York]] {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Hitoshi Okamoto
{{nihongo2|岡本 仁志}} | image = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Kyoto]], [[Japan]] | instrument = [[Guitar]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]]
[[Arranger]]
[[Composer]]
[[Radio Personality]] | years_active = 1999–present | label = [[Giza Studio]] | associated_acts = [[Garnet Crow]] | website = {{URL|http://www.giza.co.jp/superlight}} }} {{nihongo|'''Hitoshi Okamoto'''|岡本 仁志}} is a Japanese guitarist, composer, arranger and the former member of the J-pop band [[Garnet Crow]] in years 1999-2013, as well as some of his own solo releases.{{cite web|title=Hitoshi Okamoto|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Hitoshi+Okamoto|work=discogs.com|access-date=5 November 2010}} ==Biography== Since the release of Okamoto's 2010 solo album "Now Printing...", he has used the stage name "Super Light" for his solo projects. As a solo artist, Okamoto writes the majority of his songs by himself, however, fellow '''Garnet Crow''' member [[Azuki Nana|Nana Azuki]] has written lyrics for some of his songs. Okamoto is sometimes referred to with the nickname "Okamocchi" (おかもっち). He has created an alternate version of the "GARNET CROW" songs "Crystal Gauge" and "[[Mysterious Eyes]]", the latter of which Okamoto had released under the "Super Light" name.{{cite web|title=PROFILE Super Light|url=http://www.giza.co.jp/superlight/profile/index.html|website=Super Light Official Website}} During live performances as a solo artist, Okamoto sometimes plays "Garnet Crow" songs, or even invites the other Garnet members to appear as guest musicians. In "Garnet Crow" live performances, Okamoto provides back-up vocals in addition to playing the guitar.{{cite web|title=メンバープロフィール 岡本仁志|url=http://garnetcrow.com/profile/|website=Garnet Crow Official Website}} From 2002 until 2009 he was the host of the radio show "Pastime Paradise", which was regularly broadcast on Sunday on the Japanese radio station Alpha Station (FM Kyoto 89.4).{{cite web|title=岡本仁志ラジオパーソナリティースタート！|url=http://www.garnetcrow.com:80/menu/news/tv_radio.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041118024923/http://www.garnetcrow.com/menu/news/tv_radio.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=18 November 2004|website=Garnet Crow Official Website (archived)|access-date=15 January 2020}}{{cite web|title=「PASTIME PARADISE」好評OA中！　ギターの岡本仁志による味のあるトークで好評のラジオ番組「PASTIME PARADISE」とリンクした京都の最新音楽情報番組。|url=http://www.mfmagazine.com/mfm/other_contents/backnumber/previous_year/2002/02_08/0208_tokushu1.html|website=mfmagazine.com}}{{cite web|title=TimeTable Sunday - PASTIME PARADISE (DJ: 岡本仁志)|url=http://fm-kyoto.jp/timetable/index.html|website=FM Kyoto (archived)|url-status=bot: unknown|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040605145343/http://fm-kyoto.jp/timetable/index.html|archive-date=5 June 2004}}{{cite web|title=Program PASTIME PARADISE|url=http://fm-kyoto.jp:80/timetable/program/pastime_paradise/index.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040406004316/http://fm-kyoto.jp/timetable/program/pastime_paradise/index.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=6 April 2004|website=FM Kyoto (archived)|access-date=15 January 2020}} In years 2004-2006 he occasionally performed as the lead singer in ''THURSDAY LIVE at hills Pan Koujou "Okamoto Night"'' where he sang his own solo and Garnet Crow songs.{{cite web|title=GIZA studio presents THURSDAY LIVE at hillsパン工場"OKAMOTO NIGHT"開催決定！|url=http://www.garnetcrow.com:80/menu/news/information.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041118024923/http://www.garnetcrow.com/menu/news/information.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=18 November 2004|website=Garnet Crow Official Website (archived)|access-date=15 January 2020}}{{cite web|title=GIZA studio presents THURSDAY LIVE OKAMOTO NIGHT|url=http://www16.ocn.ne.jp/~neko-ac/HillsOnlineCafe/thursdaylive/okamotonight20050630.html|website=HillsOnlineCafe (archived)|url-status=bot: unknown|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091105235336/http://www16.ocn.ne.jp/~neko-ac/HillsOnlineCafe/thursdaylive/okamotonight20050630.html|archive-date=5 November 2009}} In years 2010-2013 he formed with the vocalist and composer of Garnet Crow, Yuri Nakamura subgroup "MINIQLO". They released four mini studio albums which were sold in limited copies, during their live performances. The albums consist of re-arranged songs from their previously release studio albums.{{cite web|title=Green Flash [会場限定CD]|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/Green-Flash-%E4%BC%9A%E5%A0%B4%E9%99%90%E5%AE%9ACD-MI-MINIQLO/dp/B00B5FHNTA|website=Amazon JP}}{{cite web|title=Vieto Blanco [会場限定CD]|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/Viento-blanco-%E4%BC%9A%E5%A0%B4%E9%99%90%E5%AE%9ACD-MI-MINIQLO/dp/B00F9YVQAA/ref=sr_1_2?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1499505418&sr=1-2|website=Amazon JP}}{{cite web|title= Paralyzed Frequency [廃盤]|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/Paralyzed-Frequency-%E5%BB%83%E7%9B%A4-M-MINIQLO/dp/B00B2WELS2/ref=sr_1_1?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1499505418&sr=1-1|website=Amazon JP}}{{cite web|title=above all else!![会場限定CD]|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/above-all-else-%E4%BC%9A%E5%A0%B4%E9%99%90%E5%AE%9ACD-MI/dp/B00BBJ96WW/ref=sr_1_3?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1499505418&sr=1-3|website=Amazon JP}} After disband of the band, he regularly appeared in live performances of [[doa (Japanese band)|Doa]] and [[Zard]] as guest musicians and sometimes provided music compositions for several [[Giza Studio]] artists. == Discography == ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable" !No. !Information {{cite web|title=Discography Super Light/Hitoshi Okamoto|url=http://www.giza.co.jp/superlight/discography/index.html|website=Super Light Official Website}} !Release !Ranking |- !1st |align="center"|'''A First Fine Day''' |align="center"|20 March 2002 |align="center"| - |- !2nd |align="center"|'''FF/Rewind''' |align="center"|17 November 2004 |align="center"|39{{cite web|title=FF/Rewind (岡本仁志)|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/257598/products/573250/1/|website=Oricon News|language=ja-JP}} |- !3rd |align="center"|'''Now Printing...''' |align="center"|8 December 2010 |align="center"|74{{cite web|title=Now Printing... (Super Light)|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/257598/products/893002/1/|website=Oricon News|language=ja-JP}} |} === Singles === {| class="wikitable" !No. !Information !Release !Ranking |- !1st |align="center"|'''First fine day''' |align="center"|8 November 2000 |align="center"| - |- !2nd |align="center"|'''Sweet×2 Summer Rain''' |align="center"|20 June 2001 |align="center"| - |} === Digital Singles === {| class="wikitable" !No. !Information !Release{{cite web|title=SUPER LIGHT "Mysterious Eyes ~Reason P~|url=https://itunes.apple.com/jp/album/mysterious-eyes-reason-p-single/id433398801|website=iTunes JP}} |- !1st |align="center"|'''Mysterious Eyes ~Reason P~''' |align="center"|4 May 2011 |} === Compilations album === {| class="wikitable" ! !Album !Release !Track !Ranking |- ! |align="center"|'''[[Giza Studio Masterpiece Blend 2001]]''' |align="center"|19 December 2001 |align="center"|DISC2 #10 ''Sweet×2 Summer Rain'' |align="center"|13{{cite web|title=GIZA studio Masterpiece BLEND 2001 (V.A)|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/52027/products/466459/1/|website=Oricon News|language=ja-JP}} |- ! |align="center"|'''GIZA studio Masterpiece BLEND 2002''' |align="center"|18 December 2002 |align="center"|DISC2 #11 ''STRAY BEAST'' |align="center"|15{{cite web|title=GIZA studio Masterpiece BLEND 2002 (V.A)|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/52027/products/496933/1/|website=Oricon News|language=ja-JP}} |- ! |align="center"|'''Cool City Production Vol.8 GARNET CROW REMIXES''' |align="center"|25 January 2005 |align="center"|#2 ''Crystal Gauge ~hitoshi okamoto mix~'' |align="center"|Live venue limited release |- ! |align="center"|'''Christmas Non-Stop Carol''' |align="center"|1 December 2010 |align="center"|#6 ''Angels We Have Heard on High'' |align="center"|71{{cite web|title=Christmas Non-Stop Carol (V.A)|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/52027/products/892987/1/|website=Oricon News|language=ja-JP}} |} === Live DVD === {| class="wikitable" !No. !Information !Release !Ranking |- !1st |align="center"|'''Bootleg''' |align="center"|12 December 2012 |align="center"| Limited sale |} ==List of provided works== ===Composer and arranger=== *[[Band-Maid]]: Before Yesterday, Time *Grram: Kimi ja Nai! Watashi ja Nai!, Sora no you na hito *[[Mai Kuraki]]: [[P.S My Sunshine]], Juliet, Zutto... *[[Aiko Kitahara]]: Haru Saku Michi *[[Hayami Kishimoto]]: Air Mail..., Telepathy, reigning star *[[Aya Kamiki]]: Just take my heart, Are you happy now?, It's a beautiful day, I'm your side, Whenever you're gone Today, Yakusoku no Basho de, *[[Azumi Uehara]]: Marmalade Love *[[Zard]]: [[Mind Games (Zard song)|Hypnosis]] *Uura Saeka: Kimi ga Ita, Genzai Shinkoukei *WAR-ED: Ikitakutemo Ikirarenai Seimei, Underworld ===Composer=== *[[Aya Kamiki]]: A constellation, Ever so Sweet *[[Shiori Takei]]: Yuunagi *[[Akane Sugazaki]]: Boyfriend, La la la ~ Yume wo Mitsumeta made~, Itsumademo Zutto *[[Aiko Kitahara]]: Cobalt blue *Uura Saeka: Koko janai Basho de *[[Qyoto]]: Taiyou mo Hitoribocchi, I'm a A first fine day self liner notes{{cite web|url=http://www.mfmagazine.com/mfm/other_contents/backnumber/previous_year/2002.html#88|title=Back Number 2002 (March)|language=ja|website=mfmagazine.com}} revision.text:
{{Short description|American-Hungarian musical artist (died 2020)}} {{multiple issues|{{more citations needed|date=May 2022}} {{more footnotes|date=May 2018}}}} {{Infobox musical artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Tom Barabas | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_upright = | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Hungary]] | origin = Hungary | death_date = 2020 | death_place = [[ San Diego, California]] | genre = | occupation = Pianist/keyboardist | instrument = | years_active = | label = | associated_acts = | website = | module = | module2 = | module3 = }} '''Tom Barabas''' was an American-Hungarian pianist/keyboardist. He studied [[classical music]] at the [[Caracas Conservatory]] in [[Venezuela]] before developing a taste for rock, jazz, and New Age. He died in San Diego, California in the spring of 2020. While he was over 70 years old, his kept his exact age secret.[https://www.amazon.com/Tom-Barabas/e/B000AP9LG4 Tom Barabas] Amazon.com. Retrieved February 2011[http://www.jukeboxalive.com/tombarabas Tom Barabas] jukeboxalive.com. Retrieved February 2011 ==Early life== Barabas spent his childhood in [[Hungary]] and began playing music at the age of four in [[Budapest]]. By age 12, he had attracted the interest and praise of his piano instructors and he made his public debut at the Liszt Conservatory of Music. In 1949 his family emigrated to Venezuela where he studied classical piano and composition at the Venezuela Conservatory of Music in Caracas, earning his Master's Degree in 1957. In 1966, Barabas emigrated to the US, living and composing in [[San Diego, California]]. ==Live performance== Barabas's compositional style was distinguished by the influences of his classical Conservatory training, the [[Latin pop|Latin]] and Caribbean [[Music of Venezuela|pop music of Venezuela]] and North American [[rock and roll]]. After a successful career performing daily on stage, radio and television in Venezuela, Barabas moved to San Diego in 1966 seeking greater opportunities. The Southern California music scene inspired and cultivated his interest in jazz and soon he was opening for figures such as [[Oscar Peterson]], [[Bill Evans]] and [[Ramsey Lewis]]. He later became the house pianist for a five-star resort, and it was during his tenure there that he began playing his own compositions. ==Commercial success== Barabas released 12 CD's, three of which made the [[Billboard charts|Billboard Charts]]. ''Sedona Suite'' charted number 12 and held that position for 29 weeks. Other albums of note include ''Wind Dancer'' (with Dean Evenson), reaching Billboard's Top-15, and ''Classica Nouveau'', which reached number 18 on Billboard's Top-20. Barabas and [[Dean Evenson]] enjoyed a long friendship and collaborated on several Soundings albums including ''Soaring'', ''WindDancer'', ''Back to the Garden'' and ''Healing Suite''. Barabas wrote and performed an original composition for the Heartkeys AIDS Benefit Concert and the Heartkeys album, and performed for the [[American Cancer Society]] and the AIDS Foundation of America. Some of his better known performance venues were the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[Red Rocks Amphitheatre|Red Rocks Amphitheater]], [[Delta Air Lines|Delta Airlines]] and [[Princess Cruises|Princess Cruise Lines]]. == List of albums == ''Piano Impressions'' (1986)
''You Are The End Of The Rainbow'' (1987)
''Magic In December'' (1991)
''Sedona Suite'' (1992)
''Classica Nouveaux'' (1994)
''Mosaic'' (1995)
''Journey Back To Sedona'' (1996)
''It's a New Life'' (1998)
''Romantic Rhapsodies'' (1998)
''Tom Barabas Live'' (1999)
''Wedding in Heaven'' (1999)
''Classical Healing'' (2000)
''Goodnight My Angel'' (2001)
''The Very Best Of'' (2004) Tom Barabas and [[Dean Evenson]]
''Wind Dancer'' (1992)
''Soaring'' (1996)
''Back to the Garden'' (1997)
''Healing Suite'' (2009) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.tombarabas.com Official website] *[http://www.soundings.com Soundings website] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fWCnwhivoD8&NR=1—SOLAR WIND Solar Wind Video] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mEd5IoKtlyE&NR=1—DOLPHIN DREAM Dolphin Dream Video] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8zeTi8uvXm8—FREE SPIRIT Free Spirit Video] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barabas, Tom}} [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:20th-century births]] [[Category:2020 deaths]] [[Category:Hungarian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:American male pianists]] [[Category:21st-century American pianists]] [[Category:21st-century American male musicians]]

{{Short description|Japanese rapper, singer and songwriter|bot=PearBOT 5}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Dohzi-T
童子-T | image = | caption = | birth_name = Takesue Mitsuru
竹末 充 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|5|13}} | origin = [[Japan]] | genre = [[J-pop]], [[Japanese hip hop|hip hop]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]], [[rapping|rapper]] | years_active = 1989–present | label = Atomic Boom (2001)
[[Universal Music Japan|Universal Music]] (2002 – 2003, 2005 – present)
[[Sony Music Records]] (2004 – 2005) | website = [http://www.dzt.jp/ Official website] {{in lang|ja}}
[http://www.universal-music.co.jp/dohzi_t/ Universal Music profile] {{in lang|ja}} }} {{nihongo|'''Dohzi-T'''|童子-T|Dōji Tī|extra=born {{nihongo|'''Mitsuru Takesue'''|竹末 充|Takesue Mitsuru}}, May 13, 1969}} is a Japanese rapper, singer and songwriter who has been active since 1989. ==Biography== Dohzi-T belonged to hip hop band "Zingi", formed in 1990. He debuted as a solo singer with the single "Shōnen A" (lit. "Boy A") on October 10, 2001. He associated with popular singers such as [[Shota Shimizu]], [[Miliyah Kato]] and [[Hiromi Go]].{{cite web|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/entertainment/music/news/20081108et02.htm|script-title=ja:ヒップホップの童子―Ｔ　優しいラブソング集好評|publisher=Yomiuri Shimbun|date=2008-11-08|accessdate=2008-12-02|language=ja}} Since he has long career in Japan, he is called "Brother Dohzi" by other musicians.{{cite web|url=http://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000043791|title=童子-T、キャリア19年目にして"旬"を迎える|publisher=Barks|date=2008-10-01|accessdate=2008-12-02|language=ja}} He is also known for his ability to find new singers. Dohzi-T and DJ Bass were featured in [[Ayumi Hamasaki]]'s song "[[Nothing from Nothing (Ayumi Hamasaki song)|Nothing from Nothing]]", released by [[Nippon Columbia]] on September 21, 1995.{{cite web|url=http://natalie.mu/artist/item/artist_id/218/id/11275|title=AYUMI FEATURING DOHZI-T & DJ BASS「NOTHING FROM NOTHING」|publisher=natalie|accessdate=2008-12-02|language=ja|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511122835/http://natalie.mu/artist/item/artist_id/218/id/11275|archive-date=2009-05-11|url-status=dead}} However, Hamasaki soon left from the record label and became a pop singer under [[Avex Trax]]. In January 2008, he collaborated with [[Thelma Aoyama]] in a song "This Day" on her CD single "[[Soba ni Iru ne]]". In June 2008, he released his single "[[Mō Ichi do...]]", featuring [[Beni (singer)|Beni]]. It sold over two million ringtone downloads. Soon after "Mō Ichi Do..." released an album named ''[[12 Love Stories]]'' including "Mō Ichi do..." as well as other collaboration songs with YU-A (from Foxxi misQ), [[Thelma Aoyama]], [[Juju (singer)|JUJU]] and many more. The album was ranked as No. 3 on the weekly [[Oricon]] chart making it Dohzi-T's highest ranked album. ==Discography== ===Albums=== #2007 August 29 - ''ONE MIC'' #33 on Oricon #2008 September 24 - ''[[12 Love Stories]]'' #3 on Oricon #2009 December 16 - ''4 ever'' #2010 December 9 - ''Gold'' #2011 November 30 - ''12 Love Stories 2'' ===Collaborations=== #2008 June 11 - ''[[Mō Ichi do...]]'' #7 on Oricon #2009 September 2 - Dakishimete feat. Dohzi-T ([[BENI]] - [[Bitter & Sweet (Beni Arashiro album)|Bitter & Sweet]]) #5 on Oricon ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.dzt.jp/ Official Website] {{in lang|ja}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dohzi-T}} [[Category:Japanese rappers]] [[Category:Japanese male pop singers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Universal Music Japan artists]] {{hiphop-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox writer <!--For more information, see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]].--> | name = Neil Bartram | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = [[Derby]], [[United Kingdom]] | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = Composer & Lyricist | language = English | nationality = Canadian & American | period = | genre = <!-- or: | genres = --> | notablework = music & lyrics for Disney's [[Bedknobs and Broomsticks (musical)|Bedknobs and Broomsticks]], [[The Story of My Life (musical)]], [[The Theory of Relativity (musical)|The Theory of Relativity]] | awards = 2009 [[Drama Desk Award]] nominee | years_active = 1993–present | website = {{URL|http://www.bartramandhill.com/|BartramAndHill.com}} }}
{{Use Canadian English|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} '''Neil Bartram''' is a musical theatre composer/lyricist based in New York. Bartram is the composer and lyricist of Disney's ''[[Bedknobs and Broomsticks (musical)|Bedknobs and Broomsticks]]'' and Broadway's ''[[The Story of My Life (musical)|The Story of My Life]]'' with book writer [[Brian Hill (author)|Brian Hill]].
==Career== Prior to Broadway, ''The Story of My Life'' played at Canadian Stage Company in Toronto and Goodspeed's Norma Terris Theatre. Bartram has also written music and lyrics for ''Clara's Piano'' ([[Stratford Festival]]), ''Somewhere in the World'' (five seasons at the [[Charlottetown Festival]]) and ''The Nightingale and the Rose'', and scored productions of ''[[Shakespeare In Love]]'', ''Romeo and Juliet'', ''Timon of Athens'' and ''A Midsummer Night's Drea''m. His adaptation of Carlo Collodi's ''[[The Adventures of Pinocchio]]'' was commissioned by [[Chicago Shakespeare Theater]] for their 2011 season. Bartram and Hill's musical ''Not Wanted On The Voyage'' received a developmental production at [[Northwestern University]]'s Barber Theatre as part of the American Music Theatre Project and was part of [[Goodspeed Musicals]]' 2012 New Works Festival. His musical ''The Theory of Relativity'', commissioned by Toronto's [[Sheridan College]] and written specifically for and about college age students, was part of Goodspeed's 2014 New Works Festival and had its London, UK premiere in May 2014.
Other projects include ''Spin'' directed by [[Eric Schaeffer]] (premiered at the [[Signature Theatre (Arlington, Virginia)|Signature Theatre]], Arlington, VA), an adaptation of [[Michel Tremblay]]'s [[Les Belles-Soeurs]], a musical based on [[Ray Bradbury]]'s classic novel ''Something Wicked This Way Come''s, and the stage adaptation of Disney's beloved film ''[[Bedknobs and Broomsticks (musical)|Bedknobs and Broomsticks]]'', all with book writer [[Brian Hill (author)|Brian Hill]].
Bartram's awards include a Jonathan Larson Foundation Award, a Dramatists Guild Fellowship, and a Dora Award. ''[[The Story of My Life (musical)|The Story of My Life]]'' received four [[Drama Desk Award]] nominations: outstanding book, outstanding music, outstanding lyrics and outstanding production of a musical.
Cast albums include ''Somewhere in the World'', ''The Story of My Life'' and ''[[The Theory of Relativity (musical)|The Theory of Relativity]]'' (PS Classics). Bartram is a member of the Dramatists Guild, ASCAP, and is an alumnus of the BMI Lehman Engel Music Theatre Workshop. His work is published by Warner / Chappell Music.<ref>bartramandhill.com</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mtishows.com/people/neil-bartram|title=Music Theatre International Artist Page}}</ref>
==Works== *''[[The Story of My Life (musical)|The Story of My Life]]'' with [[Brian Hill (author)|Brian Hill]], directed by [[Richard Maltby Jr.]], starring [[Will Chase]] and [[Malcolm Gets]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mtishows.com/the-story-of-my-life|title=The Story of My Life|date=16 September 2015|website=Music Theatre International}}</ref> *''[[The Adventures of Pinocchio]]'' with Hill, commissioned by [[Chicago Shakespeare Theater]]<ref name="Chicago Shakespeare Website">[http://www.chicagoshakes.com/main.taf?p=2,6], Chicago Shakespeare Theater Website - Pinocchio page.</ref> *''[[Something Wicked This Way Comes (novel)|Something Wicked This Way Comes]]'' with Hill *''The Theory of Relativity'' with Hill,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.relativemotion.co.uk/|title=Relative Motion|website=Relative Motion}}</ref> [[Goodspeed Musicals]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/casting-announced-for-goodspeeds-theory-of-relativity-new-musical-from-story-of-my-life-writers-com-345728|title=Casting Announced for Goodspeed's Theory of Relativity, New Musical from Story of My Life Writers|first=Andrew|last=Gans|date=2 April 2015|website=Playbill}}</ref> *''Spin'' with Hill, [[Signature Theatre (Arlington, Virginia)|Signature Theatre]], directed by [[Eric Schaeffer]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130419200033/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-03-04/entertainment/37433970_1_signature-theatre-new-musicals-revivals The Washington Post]</ref> *''You Are Here'' with Hill, [[Thousand Islands Playhouse]], Goodspeed Musicals<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.1000islandsplayhouse.com/you-are-here/|title=You Are Here}}</ref> *''Senza Luce'' with Hill, [[Sheridan College]] *''[[Shakespeare In Love]]'', new score for Chicago Shakespeare Theater, directed by [[Rachel Rockwell]] *''[[Bedknobs and Broomsticks (musical)|Bedknobs and Broomsticks]]'' with Hill
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *Official site: [http://www.bartramandhill.com Bartram & Hill] *[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/122188.html Broadway-Aimed Musical Story of My Life, With Gets and Chase, Makes U.S. Premiere in CT]
{{authority control}}
