{{short description|American composer|bot=PearBOT 5}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Laura Karpman | background = non_performing_personnel | image = | caption = | birth_name = Laura Anne Karpman | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|03|01}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | occupation = [[Film Composer]] | genre = | instruments = | years_active = 1994{{ndash}}present | website = {{ubl|{{url|http://laurakarpman.com}}}} }} '''Laura Anne Karpman''' (born March 1, 1959) is an American [[composer]], whose work has included music for [[film]], [[television]], [[video game]]s, [[theater]], and the [[concert|concert hall]]. She has won five{{Cite web|url=http://www.laurakarpman.com/about|title=Composer}} [[Emmy Awards]] for her work. Karpman was trained at [[The Juilliard School]], where she played [[jazz]], and honed her skills [[Scat singing|scatting]] in bars. ==Education== Born in Los Angeles, Karpman worked with [[John Harbison]] at the [[Tanglewood Music Center]], and attended Aspen Music School and the Ecole des Arts Americaines, where she worked with [[Nadia Boulanger]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} She received her Bachelor of Music degree from the [[University of Michigan]], where she graduated [[magna cum laude]], studying with [[William Bolcom]] and [[Leslie Bassett]]. She received both her Doctorate and master's degree in Music Composition at [[The Juilliard School]], where her principal teacher was [[Milton Babbitt]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} ==Career== Compositions by Karpman have been commissioned by [[Tonya Pinkins]], [[Los Angeles Opera]], [[American Composers Orchestra]], [[Czech Philharmonic]], The Juilliard Choral Union, Pacific Serenades,{{cite web|url=http://pacser.org/v2/premieres/|title=Premieres – Pacific Serenades|publisher=}} and percussionist [[Evelyn Glennie]]. They have been performed internationally.{{Cite web |title=Composer |url=http://www.laurakarpman.com/about |access-date=2022-03-18 |website=Laura Karpman |language=en-US}} Karpman's theater catalog includes three musicals for Los Angeles's "A Noise Within" theater company, as well as underscores for dozens of classic plays.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} Among her media music credits are [[Steven Spielberg]]'s Emmy-winning, 20-hour TV miniseries, ''[[Taken (miniseries)|Taken]]''; and [[PBS]]'s series ''[[The Living Edens]]'' (for which she received nine [[Emmy Awards|Emmy]] nominations). She has scored numerous films, television programs and video games (including music for ''[[Halo 3]]'' and her award-winning score for ''[[EverQuest II]]'').{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} Karpman received an [[Annie Award]] nomination for ''[[A Monkey's Tale]]'', a short film commissioned by the Chinese government, which later premiered in the US and was performed by the [[Detroit Symphony]]. Karpman's Grammy-winning ''Ask Your Mama''{{cite web|url=http://www.AskYourMama.com|title=MAMA|website=AskYourMama.com}} premiered at [[Carnegie Hall]] on March 16, 2009, with performances by [[Jessye Norman]], [[Cassandra Wilson]], [[The Roots]], and the [[Orchestra of St. Luke's]] conducted by [[George Manahan]]. With [[Langston Hughes]]'s epic poem for a libretto, Karpman's work exhibited an eclectic musical mix. Using Hughes' own voice at the core of the work, this musical includes passages from [[Louis Armstrong]], [[Big Maybelle]], [[Pigmeat Markham]] and [[Bill "Bojangles" Robinson]], integrated with projected images by [[Rico Gatson]] and additional archival video, as well as Hughes's own poetry. Annie Dorsen directed it.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} ''Ask Your Mama'' was released by Avie Records in July 2016. Later, Karpman created "The 110 Project", a work commissioned by the L.A. Opera as a paean to the city's first freeway, [[Arroyo Seco Parkway|I-110]], which turned 70 in 2009.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} In 2014, Karpman co-founded the [[Alliance for Women Film Composers]] with [[Lolita Ritmanis]] and [[Miriam Cutler]].{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2019/music/news/starr-parodi-president-alliance-for-women-film-composers-1203153992/|title=Starr Parodi Named President of the Alliance for Women Film Composers|last=Burlingame|first=Jon|date=2019-03-03|website=Variety|language=en|access-date=2019-03-10}} The organization provides visibility and advocacy for women composers.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/10/movies/female-film-composers.html|title=Female Composers Are Trying to Break Film's Sound Barrier|last=Greiving|first=Tim|date=2019-01-10|work=The New York Times|access-date=2019-03-10|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} In 2016, Karpman became the first woman elected to the music branch of The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences Board of Governors.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/motion-picture-academy-2016-2017-911981|title=Academy Elects Steven Spielberg, Laura Dern to Board of Governors|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2017-07-03|language=en}} In 2020, Karpman was hired to compose the score for the [[Marvel Studios]] animated anthology series ''[[What If...? (TV series)|What If...?]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/lists/varietys-l-a-womens-impact-report-2020/laura-karpman/|title=Variety's L.A. Women's Impact Report 2020 |last=Garrett|first=Diane|date=2020-10-28|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|access-date=2020-10-29|language=en-US}} In January 2022, Karpman was hired to compose the score for the upcoming superhero film ''[[The Marvels]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2022/artisans/news/the-marvels-mcu-what-if-composer-1235152926/|title='The Marvels' Lands Laura Karpman From 'What If…?' as Composer (EXCLUSIVE)|last=Tangcay|first=Jazz|date=2022-01-13|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|access-date=2022-01-13|language=en-US}} In May 2022, Karpman was set to compose the score for her third Marvel Studios outing, with the streaming series ''[[Ms. Marvel (TV series)|Ms. Marvel]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2022/artisans/news/ms-marvel-composer-score-music-laura-karpman-1235268151/|title='The Marvels' Composer Laura Karpman Scores 'Ms. Marvel' on Disney+ (EXCLUSIVE)|last=Tangcay|first=Jazz|date=2022-05-16|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|access-date=2022-05-16|language=en-US}} ==Personal life== Karpman is married to fellow composer Nora Kroll-Rosenbaum. They live in [[Playa del Rey, Los Angeles|Playa del Rey]], California, with their son.{{Cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/story/2019-08-20/composer-laura-karpman-on-all-american|title=History forgot these female composers. An L.A. music writer is helping us remember.|last=Womack|first=Carolyn|date=2019-08-21|work=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=2019-08-21}} ==Filmography== ===Films=== ====2020s==== {| class="wikitable sortable" width=100% |- ! 2003 |''[[Odyssey 5]]'' | |19 Episodes |- |2002 |[[Taken (miniseries)|''Taken'']] | |10 Episodes |- |1997 - 2003 |''[[The Living Edens]]'' | |24 Episodes |} === Video Games === {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Title !Notes |- |2014 |''[[Project Spark]]'' | |- |2012 |''[[Guardians of Middle-earth]]'' | |- |2011 |''[[Kung Fu Panda 2 (video game)|Kung Fu Panda 2]]'' | |- |2007 |''[[EverQuest: The Buried Sea]]'' | |- |2006 |''[[EverQuest: Prophecy of Ro]]'' | |- |2006 |''[[Untold Legends: Dark Kingdom]]'' | |- |2006 |''[[EverQuest II: The Fallen Dynasty]]'' | |- |2006 |''[[Field Commander]]'' | |- |2006 |''[[EverQuest II: Kingdom of Sky]]'' | |- |2005 |''[[EverQuest II: The Splitpaw Saga]]'' | |- |2004 |''[[EverQuest II]]'' | |} ==Awards and nominations== {{BLP unsourced section |date=October 2020}} '''Primetime Emmy Awards''' * 2021 nomination, "[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Music Composition for a Series|Outstanding Music Composition for a Series (Original Dramatic Score)]] - [[Lovecraft Country (TV series)|Lovecraft Country]]: Rewind 1921" .{{Cite web |title=Laura Karpman |url=https://www.emmys.com/bios/laura-karpman |access-date=2022-03-18 |website=Television Academy |language=en}} * 2020 won, "[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Music Composition for a Documentary Series or Special|Outstanding Music Composition for a Documentary Series or Special (Original Dramatic Score)]] - ''[[Why We Hate]]'': Tools & Tactics". * 2020 nomination, "[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Original Main Title Theme Music|Outstanding Original Main Title Theme Music]] - ''[[Why We Hate]]''. * 2008 nomination, "[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Music Composition for a Limited or Anthology Series, Movie or Special|Outstanding Music Composition for a Miniseries, Movie or a Special (Original Dramatic Score)]]" for ''[[Masters of Science Fiction]]'': Jerry Was a Man". * 2003 nomination, "[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Music Composition for a Series|Outstanding Music Composition for a Series (Original Dramatic Score)]] - ''[[Odyssey 5]]'': pilot". '''The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences''' * 2015 Membership Induction '''Annie Awards''' * 2007 nomination, "Best Music in an Animated Feature Production" for ''A Monkey's Tale'' '''BMI Film & TV Awards''' * 2003 won, "BMI Cable Mini-Series Award" for ''Taken'' '''G.A.N.G. Awards''' * 2004 won, "Best Arrangement of a Non-Original Score" for ''Everquest II'' * 2004 nomination, "Best Music of the Year" for ''Everquest II'' '''The Charles Ives Award, [[American Academy of Arts and Letters]]''' * 1984 won '''News & Documentary Emmy Awards''' * 2008 nomination, "Outstanding Individual Achievement in a Craft: Music and Sound" for ''[[Craft in America]]'' * 2003 nomination, "Outstanding Individual Achievement in a Craft: Music and Sound" for ''The Living Edens'' for "Big Sur: California's Wild Coast". {{short description|South Korean model and actor}} {{family name hatnote|Kim||lang=Korean}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}} {{Infobox person | name = Kim Jae-Uck | image = 190403 tvN ‘그녀의 사생활’ 제작발표회 김재욱.jpg | caption = Kim in 2019 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1983|4|2}} | birth_place = [[Seoul]], South Korea | othername = Kim Jae-wook | death_date = | death_place = | education = Dankook High School
[[Seoul Institute of the Arts]] | occupation = Actor, model, singer | years_active = 2002–present | agent = [[Management SOOP]] | module = {{Infobox Korean name|child=yes|headercolor=transparent | hangul = {{linktext|김|재|욱}} | hanja = | rr = Gim Jae-uk | mr = Kim Chae-uk }} }} '''Kim Jae-wook''' (born April 2, 1983) is a South Korean model and actor. He is best known for his roles in the hit series ''[[Coffee Prince (2007 TV series)|Coffee Prince]]'' (2007), [[comedy film]] ''[[Antique (film)|Antique]]'' (2008), mystery drama ''[[Who Are You? (2013 TV series)|Who Are You?]]'' (2013), [[Thriller film|thriller]] ''[[Voice (TV series)|Voice]]'' (2017), ''[[The Guest (TV series)|The Guest]]'' (2018), ''[[Her Private Life (TV series)|Her Private Life]]'' (2019) and [[Crazy Love (2022 TV series)|Crazy Love]] (2022). Also, he is fluent in [[Japanese language|Japanese]], and played the role of [[Sō Takeyuki]], the Japanese husband of [[Princess Deokhye]], in the film ''[[The Last Princess (film)|The Last Princess]]''.{{Cite web|title=김재욱 "日 전문배우? 금성무처럼 되고파" [인터뷰]|url=https://entertain.naver.com/read?oid=109&aid=0003298600|access-date=2021-04-26|website=entertain.naver.com|language=ko}} ==Early life== Kim was born in [[Seoul]], and grew up in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] until he was seven years old before returning to South Korea.{{Cite web|date=2009-09-25|title=김재욱, 日팬미팅 매진 "어릴적 살았던 도쿄, 기대된다"|url=https://www.asiae.co.kr/article/2009092516484732939|access-date=2021-04-18|website=아시아경제|language=ko}} His father worked as a journalist and was transferred to Japan as a foreign correspondent.{{cite web|url=http://star.mt.co.kr/stview.php?no=2018030823022332042|title=[별별TV]'인생술집' 김재욱 "아버지, 日주재 특파원 출신"|date=March 8, 2018|website=Star News|language=ko}} He started out performing in a band, and then when he was 17 years old, began modelling.{{Cite web|title=모델 김재욱) 따뜻한 감성으로 모델과 연기자의 경계를 허무는 남자 / Top Model에서.|url=https://blog.naver.com/shl3741/60167775121|access-date=2021-04-18|website=네이버 블로그 {{!}} 고요한 작업|language=ko}} Due to the time he spent in Japan, he can speak fluent [[Japanese language|Japanese]].{{Cite web|title=김남길 “빵모자는 감독님 아이디어”|url=https://entertain.naver.com/read?oid=312&aid=0000004106|access-date=2021-04-18|website=entertain.naver.com|language=ko}} ==Career== ===2002–2011: Career beginnings and breakthrough=== In 2002, Jae-wook debuted as the member of an indie band in the MBC drama ''[[Ruler of Your Own World]]''.{{cite web|url=http://star.ohmynews.com/NWS_Web/OhmyStar/at_pg.aspx?CNTN_CD=A0002486984&CMPT_CD=P0010|title=뭘 해도 '섹시하다'는 평가... 김재욱 "일단 즐기고 있다"|date=November 14, 2018|website=OhMyNews|language=ko}} After this first role, he concentrated on his modeling career for 5 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.osen.co.kr/article/G1111026372|title=김재욱 "'손 the guest' 구마의식서 묘한 사명감 생겨..악몽도 꿨다" [Oh!커피 한 잔②]|date=November 8, 2018|website=Osen|language=ko}} In 2007, he auditioned for and won the role of No Sun-ki in the 2007 hit drama series ''[[Coffee Prince (2007 TV series)|Coffee Prince]]''.{{cite web|url=http://news.donga.com/View?gid=8478467&date=20070816|title=이언-김동욱-김재욱 "왕자님 캐릭터 하나씩 나눠 가졌죠"|date=August 16, 2007|website=The Donga Ilbo|language=ko}} The role shot him to fame in both South Korea and several Asian countries.{{cite web|url=https://news.sbs.co.kr/news/endPage.do?news_id=N1000472331|title='커피프린스 1호점' 김재욱 일본서 팬미팅|date=September 17, 2008|website=SBS News|language=ko}} He later appeared in the 2008 drama ''[[The Kingdom of The Winds]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.asiae.co.kr/news/view.htm?idxno=2008090808341920790|title='와플선기' 김재욱, '바람의 나라'서 첫 사극 도전|date=September 8, 2008|website=10Asia|language=ko}} and served as the ambassador of goodwill for the 9th Jeonju International Film Festival (JIFF) in May 2008.{{cite web|url=http://news.joins.com/article/3061763|title=전주국제영화제 홍보대사 배우 김재욱·김성은씨 선정|date=March 4, 2008|website=JoongAng Ilbo|language=ko}} Kim then starred in his first film, ''[[Antique (film)|Antique]]'', based on the manga ''[[Antique Bakery]]'', which was invited to the [[59th Berlin International Film Festival]].{{cite news|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2009/01/30/2009013061025.html|title=6 Korean Films to Screen at Berlin Festival|work=The Chosun Ilbo|date=January 30, 2009}} He played a gay chef working at a bakery.{{cite news|last=Applegate|first=Ben|title=Pretty boys serve up a musical dramedy|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2903052|newspaper=Korea Joongang Daily|date=April 3, 2009}} He won the Best New Actor award at the 16th Korean Entertainment Awards. In October 2009, he formed a modern rock band named Walrus, where he served as guitarist and vocal. The name of the group came from the [[Beatles]] single "[[I am the Walrus]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.hancinema.net/kim-jae-wook-we-will-be-a-rock-band-with-no-compromise-27578.html|title=Kim Jae-wook "We will be a rock band with no compromise"|date=January 30, 2011|website=Hancinema|publisher=Daum}} Kim got his first leading role in Bee TV's South Korean-Japanese drama ''Give Me Your Memory: Pygmalion's Love'', which aired in March 2010.{{cite web|url=http://star.mt.co.kr/stview.php?no=2010022417145395395&outlink=1&ref=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dramabeans.com|title=김재욱 김준, 韓日합작 드라마 공동주연 발탁|date=February 24, 2010|website=Star News|language=ko}} The same year, he starred in the melodrama television series ''[[Bad Guy (TV series)|Bad Guy]]'',{{cite web|url=https://www.hancinema.net/interview-model-and-actor-kim-jae-wook--part-1-24770.html|title=[INTERVIEW] Model and actor Kim Jae-wook – Part 1|date=August 20, 2010|website=10Asia}}{{cite web|url=https://www.hancinema.net/interview-model-and-actor-kim-jae-wook--part-2-24769.html|title=[INTERVIEW] Model and actor Kim Jae-wook – Part 2|date=August 20, 2010|website=10Asia}}{{cite web|url=https://www.hancinema.net/interview-model-and-actor-kim-jae-wook--part-3-24768.html|title=[INTERVIEW] Model and actor Kim Jae-wook – Part 3|date=August 20, 2010|website=10Asia}} and featured in the romantic comedy series ''[[Marry Me, Mary!]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.hancinema.net/kim-jae-wook-hops-aboard-jang-geun-suk-drama-25205.html|title=Kim Jae-wook hops aboard Jang Geun-suk drama|date=September 27, 2010|website=Hancinema|publisher=10Asia}} Before enlisting to military service in 2011, he played in rock musical, Hedwig And the Angry Inch, from May 14 until June 19, 2011. ===2013–2016: Comeback=== After finishing his [[Conscription in South Korea|mandatory military service]], Kim made his comeback in the 2013 television series ''[[Who Are You? (2013 TV series)|Who Are You?]]'', playing the dead boyfriend of [[So Yi-hyun]]'s character.{{cite web|url=http://mwave.interest.me/en/kpop-news/article/40578/cast-of-who-are-you-pray-for-the-drama-to-be-a-success|title=So E Hyun, 2PM's Ok Taecyeon and Kim Jae Wook Wish for the Success of ′Who Are You′|date=July 12, 2013|access-date=November 21, 2016|work=Mwave|author=Jeon Su Mi|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170728114109/http://mwave.interest.me/en/kpop-news/article/40578/cast-of-who-are-you-pray-for-the-drama-to-be-a-success|archive-date=July 28, 2017|url-status=dead}} In 2014, Kim was featured in KBS' period action drama ''[[Inspiring Generation]]'' as [[Kim Hyun-joong]]'s rival, but quit after episode 8 due to unavoidable circumstances.{{cite web|title='감격시대' 김재욱, 갑작스러운 하차 "불가피한 사정"|trans-title=Kim Jae-wook, "Suddenly getting off" "Inevitable circumstances"|url=http://enews24.tving.com/news/article.asp?nsID=345885|work=ENews|date=February 14, 2014|language=ko|author=Kim Byung-Kwan|access-date=July 28, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170805143835/http://enews24.tving.com//news/article.asp?nsID=345885|archive-date=August 5, 2017|url-status=dead}} In 2015, Kim was cast for the lead role in the fantasy comedy film ''Plank Constant'', playing a script writer with weird sexual fantasies.{{cite web|title=서로 다른 이야기들이 하나의 우주로 이어진다!|trans-title=Different stories lead to a universe!|url=http://movie.daum.net/moviedb/main?movieId=93206|website=Movie Daum|language=ko}}{{cite web|title=[HanCinema's Film Review] "Planck Constant"|url=http://www.hancinema.net/hancinema-s-film-review-planck-constant-81305.html|website=HanCinema|date=April 25, 2015|author=William Schwartz}} The following year, Kim took on the role of a Japanese nobleman who marries [[Son Ye-jin]]'s character [[Princess Deokhye]] in the [[historical drama|period]] film ''[[The Last Princess (film)|The Last Princess]]''.{{cite web|title=[ON+리뷰┃‘덕혜옹주’] 비극적 역사 속 ‘한 여인의 삶’…제대로 살려낸 손예진|trans-title=[ON + Review ┃ 'Dee-Hee Hye-ju'] 'Tragic history' in a woman's life '... Son Hak-na|url=http://www.etnews.com/20160801000535|work=ET News|date=August 1, 2016|language=ko|author=Lee Ju-hee}} The same year, Kim took a leading role in the film ''Two Rooms, Two Nights'' as a popular movie director who tries to maintain secretive romantic relationships with both: his current girl friend and ex-girl friend.{{cite web|title=KOREAN FILM FESTIVAL 2016 REVIEW: TWO ROOMS, TWO NIGHTS (SOUTH KOREA, 2016)|author= Kat Czornij|url=http://www.helloasia.com.au/reviews/film/korean-film-festival-2016-review-two-rooms-two-nights-south-korea-2016/|work=Hello Asia|date=August 14, 2016}}{{cite web|title=BUSAN 2015 REVIEW: TWO ROOMS, TWO NIGHTS|author= Matthew Rooke|url=http://www.filmedinether.com/reviews/busan-2015-review-two-rooms-two-nights/|work=Filmed in Ether|date=November 6, 2015}} ===2017–present: Rising popularity=== In January 2017, Kim starred in romance film ''[[Another Way (2017)|Another way]] (2017)'', playing the role of a police officer who finds [[Seo Yea-ji]]'s character online and forms a suicide pact.{{cite web|title='Another Way' hopes to share pain and prevent suicide|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/culture/2017/01/141_221886.html|work=The Korea Times|author=Kim Jae-heun| date=January 11, 2017|language=ko}} He then played the antagonist in [[Orion Cinema Network|OCN]]'s hit thriller drama ''[[Voice (TV series)|Voice]]'', earning acclaim for his performance as a serial killer.{{cite web|url=http://koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2017/03/398_226632.html|title=[INTERVIEW] Kim Jae-wook fearful of portraying psychopath|date=March 29, 2017|website=The Korea Times}} In July the same year, Kim was cast as in the romance drama ''[[Temperature of Love]]'', playing a rich businessman.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mydaily.co.kr/new_yk/html/read.php?newsid=201707271357156660&ext=na|title='사랑의 온도' 측 "김재욱·조보아 합류 확정, 시너지 기대" [공식]|trans-title= 'Temperature of love' side "Kim Jae-wook, Jo Boa Confirm Confirmation, Synergy Expectation" [Official]|author=Hee Sul Hee|date=July 27, 2017|website=My Daily|language=ko}} In 2018, Kim was cast in the musical ''Amadeus'' in triple casting, alongside [[Jo Jung-suk]] and [[Kim Sung-kyu]].{{cite web|title=[단독] 조정석·김재욱, 차기작은 연극 '아마데우스'..7년만 재회|url=http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2018/01/09/2018010900521.html|author=Park Jin-young| date=January 9, 2018|language=ko|website=News Chosun}} Kim's Japanese film ''Butterfly Sleep'' was released in Japan in May 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://eiga.com/news/20180221/4/|title=中山美穂×キム・ジェウク、"年の差純愛"描く「蝶の眠り」予告完成|date=February 21, 2018|website=Eiga|language=ja}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.cinematoday.jp/news/N0098567|title='圧倒的な美しさ！中山美穂＆キム・ジェウク、年の差カップル描く『蝶の眠り』予告編|date=February 21, 2018|website=Cinema Today|language=ja}} The same year, he was cast in [[Orion Cinema Network|OCN]]'s supernatural thriller ''[[The Guest (TV series)|The Guest]]''.{{cite web|url=http://kpopherald.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=201805231108465346115_2|title=OCN to air another shamanism series|date=May 23, 2018|website=Kpop Herald}}{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=3048464|title=Kim Jae-uck to play cynical priest in ‘Guest’|date=May 24, 2018|website=Korea JoongAng Daily}} In 2019, Kim was cast as the main lead in the romantic comedy drama ''[[Her Private Life (TV series)|Her Private Life]]'' alongside [[Park Min-young]].{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=3058826|title=tvN romantic comedy names cast|date=January 30, 2019|website=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|author=Yeo Ye-rim}} The show marks Kim's first time as a primary lead in a romantic comedy. In 2020, Kim created "My Margiela", a 5-episode video series on the Belgian fashion designer [[Martin Margiela]].{{cite web|title=Hyukoh vocalist Oh Hyuk, Burning actor Yoo Ah-In, and more featured in Kim Jae Wook's My Margiela video series|url=https://www.bandwagon.asia/articles/hyukoh-oh-hyuk-burning-actor-yoo-ah-in-gong-hyo-jin-featured-kim-jae-wook-jaeuck-fashion-designer-my-martin-margiela-video-interview-series-2020| date=December 9, 2020|website=bandwagon}} In 2022, Kim stars alongside [[Krystal Jung]] in [[KBS2]] television series ''[[Crazy Love (2022 TV series)|Crazy Love]]'', playing a maths instructor and CEO of a top math institute. ==Personal life== In May 2011, along with fashion models [[Jang Yoon-ju]], Ji Hyun-jung, [[Han Hye-jin (model)|Han Hye-jin]] and Song Kyung-ah, he co-authored ''Top Model'', a book based on their experiences in the industry.{{cite news|title=Models Reveal Behind-the-Scenes Secrets in New Book|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2011/05/12/2011051200882.html|newspaper=The Chosun Ilbo|date=May 12, 2011}} He then enlisted for [[Conscription in South Korea|mandatory military service]] on July 5, 2011 for 21 months of active duty after five weeks of basic military training.{{cite web|url=https://www.hancinema.net/kim-jae-wook-goes-to-the-army-today-5th--31146.html|title=Kim Jae-wook goes to the army today (5th)|date=July 4, 2011|website=Hancinema|publisher=Nate}} In June 2015, Kim signed an exclusive contract with management agency Better ENT.{{cite web|title=김재욱, 소속사 새 둥지..송승헌·채정안과 한솥밥|trans-title='Kim Jae Wook, the new agency nest ... Chae Jung Ahn, Song Seung Hun and hansotbap'|url=http://star.mt.co.kr/view/stview.php?no=2015060508104176825&type=1&outlink=1|work=Star News|date=June 5, 2015|language=ko|author=Sung Keun Yoon}} In June 2017, he left Better ENT and signed with new management agency Management SOOP.{{cite web|title=김재욱, 매니지먼트 숲과 전속계약...공유와 한솥밥|url=http://osen.mt.co.kr/article/G1110662957|trans-title=[Official position] Kim Jae-wook, exclusive contract with Management Forest ...|work=OSEN|author=Ji Min-kyung| date=June 9, 2017|language=ko}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{infobox musical artist | name = Lauris Elms (AM), (OBE) | birth_name = Lauris Margaret Elms | birth_place = [[Springvale, Victoria]], Australia | birth_date = {{birth_date and age|df=yes|20 October 1931}} | occupation = Singer | genre = Opera, lieder | years_active = 1952-1994 (retirement) }} '''Lauris Margaret Elms''' {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AM|OBE}} (born 20 October 1931) is an Australian retired [[contralto]], renowned for her roles in opera and [[lied]]er and as a recording artist.
==Biography== She was born in [[Springvale, Victoria]],<ref name=dpaa>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ELACebeQEgcC&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76&dq=lauris+elms+1931&source=web&ots=aawSMoB1TY&sig=_TneUq5cJIHTPQfEJtif-FB2Rec&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result#PPA77,M1 Dictionary of Performing Arts in Australia]</ref> the elder daughter of Harry Britton Elms and Jean (née Halford)<ref name = iwww>[https://books.google.com/books?id=6J8xDWDqOkEC&pg=PA161&lpg=PA161&dq=lauris+elms+1931&source=web&ots=vNvZVRbxyO&sig=8aYTXT0hLpRPAkE1ajoRM44W5Bg&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result International Who’s Who of Women 2002]</ref> and trained with Katherine Wielaert in [[Melbourne]].<ref name=iwwcm>[https://books.google.com/books?id=48V3kmpJEEgC&pg=PA220&lpg=PA220&dq=lauris+elms+1931&source=web&ots=IPgzvqjPX-&sig=LIqo-ZaCdsmt_HaZtZvX2YmQrio&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=10&ct=result#PPA220,M1 International Who’s Who in Classical Music 2003]</ref>
She first sang with the National Theatre Opera Company in 1952 in ''[[The Consul]]''. She had further study in Paris with Dominique Modesti.<ref name=iwwcm/> She made her [[Royal Opera, London|Royal Opera]], [[Covent Garden]] debut in 1957 as Ulrica in [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s ''[[Un ballo in maschera]]'', and was principal contralto at Covent Garden from 1957 to 1959.<ref name=dpaa/> She appeared there in ''[[Elektra (opera)|Elektra]]'', ''[[Les Troyens]]'', ''[[The Tales of Hoffmann]]'', ''[[Dialogues of the Carmelites]]'', [[George Frideric Handel|Handel]]'s ''[[Samson (Handel)|Samson]]'', ''[[Die Walküre]]'', ''[[Lucia di Lammermoor]]'', and ''[[Rigoletto]]''. She also appeared as Mrs Sedley in [[Benjamin Britten]]'s ''[[Peter Grimes]]'', and in the Decca recording conducted by the composer.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/classic/daily/stories/s631141.htm ABC Classic FM]</ref>
She toured [[Israel]] in 1958 for the 10th anniversary of the State of Israel, appearing with the [[Israel Philharmonic Orchestra]], in nine performances of [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven's]] [[Symphony No. 9 (Beethoven)|Ninth Symphony]] conducted by [[Rafael Kubelík]].<ref name=iwwcm/><ref> Recordings of many of these Covent Garden and Israel performances are available on CD at Presto Classical</ref> In 1958 she married Graeme de Graaff, and they have one daughter,<ref name=iwww/> the clarinetist [[Deborah de Graaff]].
Lauris Elms presented lieder recitals with [[Musica Viva Australia]] and the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] throughout Australia between 1960 and 1970. In 1961 she was a soloist in [[Antonín Dvořák|Dvořák]]'s ''[[Stabat Mater (Dvořák)|Stabat Mater]]'' with the [[Adelaide Symphony Orchestra|South Australian Symphony Orchestra]] under [[Karel Ančerl]]. Amongst the other soloists was [[Arnold Matters]].<ref>[http://www.karel-ancerl.com/pagb11.php?ANNEE=1961 Karel Ancerl]</ref>
In 1965, she sang with the [[Joan Sutherland|Sutherland]]–[[J. C. Williamson|Williamson]] Opera Company and then with the [[Opera Australia|Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust]] and the [[Opera Australia|Australian Opera]] from 1966 to 1987. She was much praised for her Arsace in ''[[Semiramide]]'' in 1965, Azucena (Verdi's ''[[Il trovatore]]'') opposite [[Donald Smith (tenor)|Donald Smith]] and [[Elizabeth Fretwell]] and later with Kenneth Collins and Joan Sutherland in the [[Elijah Moshinsky|Moshinsky]]/Nolan production. Between 1958 and 1973 she sang in five Royal Command performances. In 1970 she sang in [[Requiem (Verdi)|Verdi's ''Requiem'']] with an all-Australian cast of soloists, at the [[Royal Festival Hall]], London, conducted by [[Charles Mackerras]], marking the 200th anniversary of [[James Cook]]'s charting of the east coast of Australia.
In 1973 she sang at the openings of the [[Adelaide Festival Centre|Adelaide Festival Theatre]] and the [[Sydney Opera House]], and she appeared in the inaugural opera season at the latter venue in all three parts of [[Giacomo Puccini|Puccini]]'s ''[[Il trittico]]''. That year she also appeared as a soloist in [[Hector Berlioz]]'s ''[[Les nuits d'été]]'' (''Summer Nights'') and lieder recitals in [[Korea]]. She performed with Marilyn Richardson in [[Ian Cugley]]'s ''The Six Days of Creation'', which was written for their voices. Her 1979 solo recital at the Opera House was the first ABC recital to feature a resident Australian singer. She gave recitals in China in 1983.
In 1987, Lauris Elms commissioned a song cycle from composer Derek Strachan. He produced ''Rose of the Bay'', a cycle of nine songs for mezzo-soprano, clarinet and piano. It was premiered by Lauris Elms, Deborah de Graaff, and David Miller, and they went on to make the premiere recording.<ref>[http://www.musicweb-international.com/classrev/2004/Apr04/strahan_rose.htm Naxos Music Library]</ref>
Lauris Elms retired in 1994. In 2001 she published her autobiography "The Singing Elms: the autobiography of Lauris Elms". The book is currently out of print but an electronic copy (text only) is available at smashwords.com.<ref>[http://www.smashwords.com/books/view/285849 Smashwords]</ref>
==Honours== Lauris Elms was appointed an [[Order of the British Empire|Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in 1974, awarded the Queen's Jubilee Medal in 1977,<ref name=iwww/> and appointed a [[Order of Australia|Member of the Order of Australia]] (AM).
In 1988, the [[University of Sydney]] awarded her an honorary Doctorate of Music,<ref>[http://www.usyd.edu.au/senate/honawardshistoricalyear.shtml University of Sydney]</ref> and in 1995 she received the Rotary International Award for Vocational Excellence. In 2010 she received the Melbourne [[Green Room Awards|Green Room Award]] for Lifetime Achievement.
==Roles and recordings== Her principal roles were: Micah (''[[Samson (Handel)|Samson]]''), Arsace (''[[Semiramide]]''), Amneris (''[[Aida]]''), Azucena (''[[Il trovatore]]''), Ulrica (''[[Un ballo in maschera]]''), Eboli (''[[Don Carlos]]''), the title role in ''[[Carmen]]'', Frugola, Principessa, Zita, (''[[Il trittico]]''), Lucretia (''[[The Rape of Lucretia]]''), Mistress Quickly (''[[Falstaff (opera)|Falstaff]]''), Sesto (''[[La clemenza di Tito]]''), Caesar (''[[Giulio Cesare|Julius Caesar]]''), Orpheus (''[[Orpheus]]''), Mrs Sedley (''[[Peter Grimes]]''), and Anna and Dido (''[[Les Troyens]]''), Bradamante (''[[Alcina]]''), and Judith ''[[Bluebeard's Castle]]'', Delilah (''[[Samson and Delilah (opera)|Samson and Delilah]]''), Fricka (''[[Die Walküre]]''), Erda (''[[Siegfried (opera)|Siegfried]]''), and the Ice Queen (''[[Schwanda the Bagpiper]]'').
Her recordings include: * highlights from [[Giovanni Battista Bononcini|Bononcini]]'s ''[[Griselda (Giovanni Bononcini)|Griselda]]'' (title role) *[[Benjamin Britten]]'s ''[[Peter Grimes]]'' * [[Ernest Chausson|Chausson]]'s ''[[Poème de l'amour et de la mer]]'' * [[Edward Elgar|Elgar]]'s ''[[Sea Pictures]]'' * highlights from [[Carl Heinrich Graun]]'s ''[[Montezuma (Graun)|Montezuma]]'' (title role) * [[George Frideric Handel|Handel]]'s ''[[Alcina]]'' (with [[Joan Sutherland]], [[Margreta Elkins]], [[Spiro Malas]] and others) * [[Franz Liszt|Liszt]] songs with David Miller * [[Franz Schubert|Schubert]] lieder with John Winther * a video of [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s ''[[Il trovatore]]'' with Joan Sutherland, conducted by [[Richard Bonynge]], recorded at the [[Sydney Opera House]] * [[Johannes Brahms|Brahms]], [[Henri Duparc (composer)|Duparc]] and [[Alban Berg|Berg]] songs with [[Geoffrey Parsons (pianist)|Geoffrey Parsons]] * [[Claude Debussy|Debussy]] and Beethoven song recitals * operatic arias with the [[Sydney Symphony Orchestra]] and the [[West Australian Symphony Orchestra]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Elms, Lauris}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century Australian women singers]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Australian Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Operatic mezzo-sopranos]] [[Category:Operatic contraltos]] [[Category:Australian contraltos]] [[Category:Singers from Melbourne]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Agnete Johnsen | image = ESC2016 - Norway 15 (crop).jpg | caption = Agnete in 2016 | birth_name = Agnete Kristin Johnsen | alias = {{Hlist|Agnete|Agnete Saba}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1994|7|4|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Nesseby]], [[Norway]] | genre = {{Hlist|[[Pop music|Pop]]|[[pop rock]]|[[pop punk]]}} | occupation = {{Hlist|Singer|songwriter}} | instrument = {{Hlist|Vocals}} | years_active = 2008–present | label = | associated_acts = [[The BlackSheeps]] | website = }} '''Agnete Kristin Johnsen''' (born 4 July 1994), also known as '''Agnete Saba''',{{cite web|url=https://wiwibloggs.com/2020/08/20/norways-agnete-saba-discusses-eurovision-2016-experience/256855/|title=“Everything got so tough” — Norway’s Agnete Saba discusses Eurovision 2016 experience|date=2020-08-21|publisher=Wiwibloggs}} or simply '''Agnete''', is a Sami singer and songwriter from Norway. Johnsen is best known for being the lead singer of the Norwegian teen punk band [[The BlackSheeps]]. She represented [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest 2016|Norway]] in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] as a solo artist with the song "[[Icebreaker (song)|Icebreaker]]". ==Life and career== ===Early life and career=== Johnsen was born on 4 July 1994 in [[Varangerbotn]], [[Nesseby]], located in [[Finnmark]], [[Norway]]. She is an [[Sami people|ethnic Sami]] and the daughter of Sami children's author [[Signe Iversen]].[http://www.finnmarkdagblad.no/finnmarken/lokale_nyheter/article6948912.ece Nå kan Signe vinne Nordisk råds litteraturpris] på www.finnmarkdagblad.no/finnmarken/lokale_nyheter/ Publisert 29. oktober 2013. Besøkt 2. november 2013. [[The BlackSheeps]] were formed in 2008 while its members were attending school in their hometown of Nesseby. They later won ''[[Melodi Grand Prix Junior 2008]]'' with their song "[[Oro jaska, beana]]" ("Be quiet, dog") which was performed in both [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] and [[Northern Sami language|Northern Sami]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/troms_og_finnmark/1.6209272|title=Suveren seier til samisk rock|date=2008-09-14|publisher=NRK Troms og Finnmark}} The band later performed at [[MGP Nordic 2008]] and won the competition. "Oro jaska, beana" went on to win Song of the Year at the [[Spellemannprisen]] Awards and peaked at number-one on the Norwegian singles chart.{{cite web|url=http://lista.vg.no/album_info.php?AlbumOp=show&albumId=5407&listId=1&albumtype=song|title=Oro Jaska, Beana|language=no|access-date=2008-11-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218222633/http://lista.vg.no/album_info.php?AlbumOp=show&albumId=5407&listId=1&albumtype=song|archive-date=2008-12-18|url-status = dead}} In 2011, the band were announced as one of the competing acts in [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest 2011|''Melodi Grand Prix 2011'']] with the song "Dance Tonight", where they placed second.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16282|title=Norway: Full line up for Melodi Grand Prix revealed|last=Hondal|first=Victor|date=29 November 2011|work=ESCToday.com|access-date=29 November 2011}} They later split up the same year. In 2013, Agnete competed in the second season of the Norwegian music TV-competition ''{{Interlanguage link|Stjernekamp|no|Stjernekamp}}'', where she placed second in the finale against [[Silya Nymoen]]. The same year she also performed as an interval act during ''[[Melodi Grand Prix Junior 2013]]''. ===2014–present: ''Skal vi danse?'' === In 2014, Johnsen was announced as one of the competing celebrities in the tenth season of the Norwegian version of ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]'', called ''[[Skal vi danse?]]'' (Shall we dance?). She went on to win the competition. In 2015, she participated in the Norwegian reality television series ''{{Interlanguage link multi|71° nord|no}}'', but withdrew early in the season because of mental health problems.{{cite web|last1=Ighanian |first1=Catherine Gonsholt|title=Agnete trakk seg fra "71 grader nord" – utredes for bipolar lidelse|url=http://www.vg.no/rampelys/tv/agnete-johnsen/agnete-trakk-seg-fra-71-grader-nord-utredes-for-bipolar-lidelse/a/23615374/|website=vg.no|publisher=vg.no|access-date=5 May 2016|language=no|date=14 February 2016}} Her debut Album is set to be called NATURE due to the topics of its tracks. ===Eurovision Song Contest 2016=== On 19 January 2016, Johnsen was announced as one of the ten competing acts in [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest 2016|''Melodi Grand Prix 2016'']] with the song "[[Icebreaker (song)|Icebreaker]]".{{cite web|last1=Hyttebakk|first1=Jon Marius|title=Stage Dolls blant årets MGP-artister|url=http://www.nrk.no/mgp/stage-dolls-blant-arets-mgp-artister-1.12756061|website=mgp.no|publisher=[[NRK]]|access-date=19 January 2016|language=no|date=19 January 2016}} In the final, held on 27 February, she was declared the winner after receiving 166,728 votes from the Norwegian public.{{cite web|last1=Jordan|first1=Paul|last2=Nilsson|first2=Helena|title=Agnete to represent Norway in 2016|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=agnete_to_represent_norway_in_2016|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|access-date=27 February 2016|date=27 February 2016}} She represented Norway in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] performing on May 12, 2016, during the second semi-final held in [[Stockholm]], but failed to qualify to the May 14 final. ==Discography== ===Extended plays=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"| Title ! scope="col" style="width:14em;"| Details |- ! scope="row"| ''Tundra'' | * Released: 26 March 2021 * Label: Aiko * Format: [[Music download|Digital download]] |} ===Singles=== ====As lead artist==== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Year ! scope="col" colspan="1"| Peak chart positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Certifications ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Album |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:85%;"| [[VG-lista|NOR]]
{{cite web|url=http://norwegiancharts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Agnete|title=Discography Agnete|publisher=Norwegian Charts Portal. Hung Medien (Steffen Hung)|last=Hung|first=Steffen}} |- ! scope="row"| "Goin' Insane" | 2013 | — | | rowspan="3"| ''Nature'' |- ! scope="row"| "Mama" | 2014 | — | |- ! scope="row"| "[[Icebreaker (song)|Icebreaker]]" | 2016 | 11 | * [[IFPI]] NOR: Gold |- ! scope="row"| "Beginning of the End" | 2020 | — | | rowspan="3"| ''Tundra'' |- ! scope="row"| "Boo" | rowspan="3"| 2021 | — | |- ! scope="row"| "Solid" | — | |- ! scope="row"| "Barely Breathing"

{{short description|Belgian singer}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2020}} {{Infobox person | name = Emly Starr | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Marie-Christine Mareels | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1957|9|5}} | birth_place = [[Laarne]], [[Belgium]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Belgian | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = singer }} '''Emly Starr''' (born 5 September 1957 in [[Laarne]], [[Belgium]]; birth name '''Marie-Christine Mareels''') is a Belgian disco singer. She also appeared in the documentary film ''Santiago Lovers'' by [[Romano Ferrari]]. She has participated in several dance and song contests. In the [[World Popular Song Festival]] at [[Tokyo]] in 1980 with the entry "Mary Brown", she was finalist as Emly Starr Explosion. Starr entered the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1981]], where she performed "[[Samson (Emly Starr song)|Samson]]" and finished in 13th place. In 1985, she appeared in the role of Erika in the film ''Jumping'' (Dutch: ''Springen'') directed by [[Jean-Pierre De Decker]], a film which was [[List of submissions to the 59th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film|submitted to the 59th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] but not nominated, where she sang the song "Jump in the Dark", that was in the film's soundtrack. ==Discography== ===Singles=== * "Tears of Gold" / idem instr. (1976) * "Back to the Beatles" / "I'll risk it" (1977) * "Cha Cha D'Amore" / idem instr. (1977) * "Dance of love" / "My Time (is your time)" (1977) * "No No Sheriff" / idem instr. (1978) * "Santiago Lover" / idem instr. (1978) * "Baby love me" / idem instr. (1979) * "Hey Aloha (Honolulu)" / "Baby love me" (1979) * "Do Svidaanja" / "Bee bop boogie" (1980) * "Get Up" / "Music in the air" (1980) * "Mary Brown" / "Rock 'n' Roll Woman" (1980, Japão) * "Sweet Lips" / "Hang On" (1981) * "Let Me Sing" / "Baby I need your loving" (1981) * "Samson" (''Samson & Delilah'') (1981, in [[dutch language|Dutch]] and [[english language|English]]) * "Dynamite" / idem instr. (1982) * "Key To Your Heart" / "The Letter" (1983) * "Jump in the Dark" / "I know (how to love you)" (1986) * "Rock and roll woman" / "I need help" (1980–1981) ===Albums=== * 1980: ''Emly Starr'' * 1980: ''The Best of Emly Starr Explosion'' * 1981: ''Emly Starr Explosion'' * 1982: ''Greatest Hits'' * 1984: ''The Letter'' * 2008: ''Greatest Hits (CD)'' ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.emlystarr.com/page/1/Home/}} in Dutch, French and English * [http://users.telenet.be/wpsf/WPSF1980.htm Tokio's contest] * {{IMDb name|id=0823501}} {{S-start}} {{succession box | before=[[Telex (band)|Telex]]
with "[[Euro-Vision]]" | title=[[Belgium in the Eurovision Song Contest]] | years=1981 | after=[[Stella Maessen]]
with "[[Si tu aimes ma musique]]" | }} {{S-end}} {{Belgium in the Eurovision Song Contest|state=collapsed}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1981|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Starr, Emly}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest entrants for Belgium]] [[Category:Belgian women singers]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest entrants of 1981]] [[Category:People from Laarne]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Rosa Rio | image = Foxrosario.jpg | caption = Rosa Rio at the Brooklyn Fox (1933–34), started her career as a silent film accompanist | birth_date = {{birth date |1902|06|02}}<ref name="nytbio">Margalit Fox, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/15/arts/music/15rio.html?hpw "Rosa Rio, Organist From Silent Films to Soap Operas, Dies at 107"], ''[[New York Times]]'', May 14, 2010.</ref> | death_date = {{Death date and age|2010|05|13|1902|06|02|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], [[United States]] | death_place = [[Sun City Center, Florida]]<ref name="nytbio"/> | birth_name = Elizabeth Raub<ref name="washpostobit">Matt Schudel, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/15/AR2010051503454.html "Rosa Rio, 106; organist went from silent films to soap operas and back again"], ''[[Washington Post]]'', May 16, 2010.</ref> | years_active = 1911–2010 | occupation = {{hlist|Concert pianist|music producer|arranger|silent film accompanist|theatre performer}} | instrument = [[Wurlitzer]] [[theatre organ]], [[Hammond organ|Hammond]] [[electric organ]] }} '''Rosa Rio''' (June 2, 1902 – May 13, 2010) was the [[stage name]] of American concert pianist Elizabeth Raub, who also provided scores and arrangement for theater, radio, television and film productions later becoming a teacher of music and voice. She started her career as a theatre performer before becoming a [[silent film]] accompanist, after which she became a leading organist on network radio and television for soap operas and dramas. In 1993 she reprised her film accompaniment career in Florida, providing the scores for early productions, some of which she had accompanied some 80 years earlier, on their release to cinema.<ref name="nytbio"/>
==Biography== ===Early life=== Rio was born as '''Elizabeth Raub''' and raised in [[New Orleans]].<ref name="washpostobit"/> She began playing piano at the age of four and started taking lessons at the age of eight. At age nine she played piano at a silent movie theater for the first time. She studied music at Oberlin College and at the Eastman School of Music. Her instrument of choice was a [[Wurlitzer]] pipe organ. She married her professor at Eastman, organist John Hammond; they had a son, John Farnsworth Hammond III, who preceded her in death. The marriage ended in divorce. She later married Bill Yeoman, her husband of 63 years. She had three grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren, and a pet snail named Iowa.<ref name="washpostobit" />
Bill Yeoman, her husband, said that Raub adopted the stage name of Rosa Rio because it fitted easily on a theater marquee.
===Motion Pictures=== As a theater organist, Rio performed in Syracuse, at Loews theaters in [[New York City]], at the Saenger Southeastern theater chain, the Scranton Paramount, Brooklyn Fox Theatre, RKO Albee, and the [[Brooklyn Paramount Theater|Brooklyn Paramount]].<ref name=rio>[http://www.goldenage-wtic.org/gaor-11.html The Golden Age of Radio: Rosa Rio]</ref> She was working at the [[Saenger Theatre (New Orleans, Louisiana)|Saenger Theatre]] in her hometown of New Orleans when [[Al Jolson]]'s ''[[The Jazz Singer]]'' was released, signaling the end of the silent film era.<ref name="washpostobit"/> Among the films she composed for and provided accompaniment for were ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of The Opera]]'', ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1923 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]'' and the seminal ''[[The Birth of a Nation]]''.
===Radio=== [[File:Rosariogregwilliam.png|thumb|Caricature of Rosa Rio reflecting on her career as a staff organist for NBC Radio.]] Known as "Queen of the Soaps," Rio worked for 22 years in radio, providing the organ background music for 24 radio soap operas and radio dramas, and playing an average of five to seven shows per day.<ref name="Varietyobit">[https://www.variety.com/article/VR1118019440.html?categoryId=25&cs=1 "Musician Rosa Rio dies at 107: Silent film organist worked on NBC shows"], ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', May 16, 2010.</ref> Some days she went from one program immediately to another—as when ''Lorenzo Jones'' and ''Bob and Ray'' were adjacent on NBC's schedule during the early 1950s—with less than 50 seconds to run from one NBC studio to another .{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} Some of the programs she played for included ''[[Bob and Ray]]'', ''[[Ethel and Albert]]'', ''Front Page Farrell'', ''[[Lorenzo Jones]]'', ''[[My True Story]]'', ''[[The Shadow]]'' and ''[[When a Girl Marries]]''.
During [[World War II]] she had her own radio show, ''Rosa Rio Rhythms''.
===Television and teaching=== Rio made a smooth transition into television, playing for shows such as ''[[As the World Turns]]'' and ''[[Today (NBC program)|the Today Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tampatheatre.org/Rosa/Still%20Coming%20Up%20Rosa.pdf |title=Schroeder, Tara. "Still Coming up Rosa", ''Theatre Organ: Journal of the American Theatre Organ Society'', September;October 2001 |accessdate=2013-08-08 |url-status=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105205734/http://www.tampatheatre.org/Rosa/Still%20Coming%20Up%20Rosa.pdf |archivedate=January 5, 2009 }}.</ref> However, compared to radio, television offered fewer opportunities for work. Rio later moved to [[Connecticut]], where she opened a music school with classes in voice, organ and piano.
===Video scores=== During the 1980s, she provided scores and [[Hammond organ]] accompaniment to more than 370 silent films released on video by [[Video Yesteryear]].<ref name=rio/>
===Later career=== [[File:Rosa Rio at the Tampa Theatre Wurlitzer (May 2006).jpg|thumb|left|Rosa Rio at the Tampa Theatre Wurlitzer (May 2006)]]
In 1993, Rio moved to [[Hillsborough County, Florida|Hillsborough County]] in [[Florida]], where she played accompaniment to silent films at the [[Tampa Theatre]]. She was still providing silent film accompaniment up to her death, including a screening of the [[Buster Keaton]] film ''[[One Week (1920 film)|One Week]]''.<ref>[http://tampatheatre.org/about/rosa-rio/ Tampa Theatre: Rosa Rio]</ref> It was from the stage of the Tampa Theatre in 2007 that she first publicly gave her real age, which she had kept to herself for decades due to age discrimination dating back to her network radio years.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} Because Rio never celebrated birthdays, some of her family members were not aware of her age until the night before her Tampa Theatre "confession."<ref>{{Citation | last = Jenkins | first = Colleen | author-link = | title = The Queen of Soaps Comes Clean | newspaper = St. Petersburg Times | pages = | date = 7 June 2007 | url = http://www.sptimes.com/2007/06/07/Hillsborough/The_queen_of_soaps_co.shtml | accessdate = 2010-05-15}} </ref> She celebrated her 107th birthday in June 2009.
She broke her hip in March 2010 and suffered a bout of influenza; however, she continued to perform on her five-foot Grand Piano. Rio died on May 13, less than three weeks before her 108th birthday. Her organ arrangements remain in print.<ref>[http://michaelsmusicservice.com Michael's Music Service], ''St. Petersburg Times,</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rio, Rosa}} [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:American centenarians]] [[Category:Theatre organists]] [[Category:American organists]] [[Category:Women organists]] [[Category:Musicians from New Orleans]] [[Category:People from Hillsborough County, Florida]] [[Category:20th-century organists]] [[Category:21st-century organists]] [[Category:21st-century American keyboardists]] [[Category:Women centenarians]]

{{Infobox person | name = Richard Kapp | birth_date = {{Birth date|1936|10|09}} | birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2006|06|04|1936|10|09}} | death_place = [[Danbury, Connecticut|Danbury]], [[Connecticut]] | nationality = American | occupation = [[conducting|conductor]] }} '''Richard Kapp''' (October 9, 1936 – June 4, 2006) was an American [[conducting|conductor]].
Richard Kapp was born in [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], [[Illinois]].<ref name="obituary">{{cite web |url=https://www.legacy.com/obituaries/newstimes/obituary.aspx?pid=18026327 |title=Richard Kapp |website=Legacy.com |access-date=September 8, 2019}}</ref> He was a child piano [[Child prodigy|prodigy]]. He studied German political history at [[Johns Hopkins University]] and received his [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in 1957. He then went abroad on a [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright fellowship]] and studied conducting, composition, and piano at the Stuttgart [[State University of Music and Performing Arts Stuttgart|Staatliche Hochschule für Musik]] in Germany.<ref name="Oron">{{cite web |url=https://www.bach-cantatas.com/Bio/Kapp-Richard.htm |title=Richard Kapp (Conductor) |first1=Aryeh |last1=Oron |first2=Thomas H. |last2=Pease |access-date=September 8, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sonybmgmasterworks.com/artists/richardkapp/ |title=Richard Kapp |access-date=September 8, 2019 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827162913/http://www.sonybmgmasterworks.com/artists/richardkapp/ |archive-date=August 27, 2008}}</ref>
Kapp started his musical career as a vocal coach at the [[Theater Basel|Basel Stadttheater]], [[Switzerland]]. He then moved back in the United States and served as music director of the Opera Theater of the [[Manhattan School of Music]] in New York from 1963 to 1965. While in New York City he earned a law degree from the [[New York University]] in 1966. He also studied conducting, piano and harpsichord.<ref name="Oron" />
In 1968 Richard Kapp founded the chamber orchestra [[Philharmonia Virtuosi]] of New York. He served as their musical director for the rest of his life. Among other notable concerts the Philharmonia Virtuosi of New York gave the inaugural concert at the Performing Arts Center at the [[State University of New York at Purchase]] in 1977.<ref>{{cite book |last=Kapp |first=Richard |title=Program Notes to Vivaldi's Favorites |volume=1 |date=April 1992}}</ref>
The [[Philharmonia Virtuosi]] of New York performed and recorded until 2004 when concerts were suspended when Kapp became ill.
With the Philharmonia Virtuosi of New York Kapp released a series of classical "greatest hits" records. This included the 1977 album "Greatest Hits of 1720" on [[CBS Masterworks]]. These albums were collections of shorter more accessible repertoire that were designed to have popular appeal.<ref name="Oron" /> Kapp and the Philharmonia Virtuosi also recorded a notable collection of three volumes of "Vivaldi's Favorites".
Kapp was the first of the original plaintiffs in ''[[Golan v. Holder]]'', a 2012 [[United States Supreme Court]] that held that restoration of copyrights under the [[Uruguay Round Agreements Act]] was not unconstitutional.<ref>{{cite web |last=Saunders |first=Christina |title=Golan v. Holder: U.S. Supreme Court to Consider Freedom of Expression and the Rights of Americans to Use Foreign Copyrighted Materials in the Public Domain |url=http://nouveaulaw.com/general/golan-v-holder-u-s-supreme-court-to-consider-freedom-of-expression-and-the-rights-of-individual-americans-to-use-foreign-copyrighted-materials-in-the-public-domain/ |publisher=Nouveau Law |access-date=September 8, 2019 |date=March 21, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130323231724/http://nouveaulaw.com/general/golan-v-holder-u-s-supreme-court-to-consider-freedom-of-expression-and-the-rights-of-individual-americans-to-use-foreign-copyrighted-materials-in-the-public-domain/ |archive-date=March 23, 2013}}</ref> Kapp joined the case to oppose the restoration of [[United States copyright law|U.S. copyright]] in orchestral [[public domain]] works such as [[Shostakovich]]'s ''[[String Quartets]]'', which Kapp had previously arranged while in the public domain, and which he would be unable to continue to exploit after restoration without paying royalties.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lee |first=Edward |title=Golan v. Holder: Supreme Court to Review Copyrighting Works in Public Domain |url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/supreme-court-to-review-copyright-public-domain_b_832886 |newspaper=Huffington Post |access-date=September 8, 2019 |date=March 9, 2011}}</ref>
Kapp died at his home in [[Danbury, Connecticut|Danbury]], [[Connecticut]], at the age of 69 from cancer.<ref name="obituary" />
