{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{family name hatnote|Lorenzo|Pascual|lang=Spanish}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Ruth Lorenzo | image = Ruth Lorenzo Presentación 2.jpg | image_size = | caption = Ruth Lorenzo in 2014 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Ruth Lorenzo Pascual | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1982|11|10}} | birth_place = [[Las Torres de Cotillas]], [[Region of Murcia|Murcia]], Spain | genre = {{flat list| *[[Rock music|Rock]] *[[rock en Español]] *[[Latin pop]] *[[Pop music|pop]] }} | occupation = Singer-songwriter, actress | years_active = 2008–present | instrument = Vocals, [[guitar]], [[piano]] | associated_acts = [[List of The X Factor finalists (UK series 5)|''The X Factor'' finalists 2008]], [[Dannii Minogue]], [[Conchita Wurst]] | label = [[Virgin Records|Virgin]]/[[EMI Records]] (2009–2010){{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/s103/the-x-factor/news/a255915/x-factor-lorenzo-splits-from-emi.html|title='X Factor' Lorenzo splits from EMI|website=Digital Spy|date=2010-08-04|access-date=2012-04-10}}
H&I Music (2012–2013)
Roster Music (2013–2017)
Raspberry Records (2017-present) Binary Beryl Music (2022-present) | website = {{url|ruthlorenzo.com}} }} '''Ruth Lorenzo Pascual''' ({{IPA-es|rut ˈloɾenθo}}; born 10 November 1982),{{cite web|url=http://www.russellgrant.com/articles/xfactor2008.php?id=O2|title=X-Factor Horoscopes|publisher=Russell Grant|date=2012-03-14|access-date=2012-04-10}} better known as '''Ruth Lorenzo''', is a Spanish singer and composer, perhaps best known in the UK for coming fifth in the [[The X Factor (UK series 5)|fifth series]] of the British TV talent show ''[[The X Factor (UK TV series)|The X Factor]]'' in 2008. She represented [[Spain in the Eurovision Song Contest|Spain]] in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2014]] with the song "[[Dancing in the Rain (song)|Dancing In The Rain]]", which entered the Spanish Singles Chart at number 5. In the [[Eurovision Song Contest]], she scored 74 points for Spain, finishing in 10th place. Artists such as [[Auryn]] and [[Dannii Minogue]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.popjustice.com/thenews/dannii-minogue-is-releasing-a-new-greatest-hits-and-itll-feature-a-new-song-called-cos-youre-beautiful/117504/|title = Dannii Minogue is releasing a new greatest hits and it'll feature a new song called "'Cos You're Beautiful' • Popjustice|date = 24 July 2013}} have included compositions of hers in their albums. Her debut single "[[Burn (Ruth Lorenzo song)|Burn]]" entered the Spanish Singles Charts and reached number 16 when she released the single on 27 June 2011. She released her first UK single "[[The Night (Ruth Lorenzo song)|The Night]]" on 15 June 2013, featuring a club remix by Almighty. {{Citation needed|date=April 2013}} Her debut album '[[Planeta Azul]]' was released on 27 October 2014, with number six single on the Spanish Single Charts ‘Gigantes’. In November 2017 ‘Good Girls Don't Lie’ was released as the first single of her second album 'Loveaholic' (9 March 2018). The song made it to number one iTunes Spain on the first 24 hours.{{Cite web|url=http://jenesaispop.com/2017/10/18/310970/ruth-lorenzo-numero-1-virales-spotify-espana/|title = Ruth Lorenzo, número 1 en virales de Spotify en España|date = 18 October 2017}} ''Loveaholic'' includes a collaboration of guitarist [[Jeff Beck]]. She achieved a [[Guinness World Records]] in 2016 for performing in eight different Spanish cities in 12 hours, in a breast cancer awareness charity event.{{Cite web|url=https://guinnessworldrecords.es/news/2016/10/spanish-singer-ruth-lorenzo-sets-record-performing-eight-concerts-in-12-hours-to-448176|title=La cantautora Ruth Lorenzo establece récord con ocho conciertos en 12 horas a través de España para recaudar fondos para fundación para la cura del cáncer|date=25 October 2016|website=Guinness World Records}} ==Early life== Ruth Lorenzo was born on 10 November 1982 in the [[Region of Murcia]], in south-eastern Spain. At a very young age she became a fan of the musical ''[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]'' and although she had no idea of what the words meant she would sing along to the songs in English. When she was six years old she discovered music by Catalan opera singer [[Montserrat Caballé]], and after her mother bought her an album by Caballé, Lorenzo began to sing opera, imitating Caballé's vocals until she was pitch perfect. At the age of 12, Lorenzo's family moved to [[Utah]] in the [[United States]] and this was the first time she had the opportunity to be involved in music at school.{{cite news|url=http://elpais.com/diario/2008/12/05/tentaciones/1228504974_850215.html|title=La murciana que cabreó a Price|newspaper=El País|date=2008-12-05|access-date=2015-07-11}} After much encouragement from her teachers, Lorenzo was entered into competitions and played lead roles in musical productions such as ''The Phantom of the Opera'' and ''My Fair Lady''. When Lorenzo turned 16 the family returned to Spain and although having had singing lessons by this time, she had to cancel these lessons due to family financial difficulty and as a result Lorenzo gave up on her dream of becoming a recording artist. When Lorenzo was 19 she joined a rock band, which was a challenge for her as she had only sung opera music. She also made a big decision to quit her job in her family's business in order to pursue her dreams once again, but after three years of touring around Spain the group decided to split up. Ruth landed a contract at [[Polaris World]] where as well as performing, she worked as a PR consultant. ==Career== ===2008: ''The X Factor''=== {{Main|The X Factor (UK series 5)}} In 2008, Lorenzo auditioned for the fifth series of ''The X Factor'' in front of judges [[Simon Cowell]], [[Cheryl Cole]] and [[Louis Walsh]]. She sang "[[(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman]]". She impressed the judges and made it through to the next stage of the show, "bootcamp". Lorenzo passed both stages of bootcamp and was sent to [[St. Tropez]] with the other successful contestants from the over-25s category. There she auditioned in front of [[Dannii Minogue]] who was her ''X Factor'' mentor. After an emotional performance of "[[True Colors (Cyndi Lauper song)|True Colors]]", sung in Spanish, Minogue decided to pick Lorenzo for her final three who would proceed to the live shows. On the first live show she sang "[[Take My Breath Away]]" in English and Spanish. She had mainly good comments, especially from Cowell, who told her she should sing in Spanish more often. However, the next week Lorenzo sang "[[I Just Can't Stop Loving You]]" in English only, and ended up in the bottom two. She performed "[[Purple Rain (song)|Purple Rain]]" in the singoff, and it saved her into the next week. In Week 5, Lorenzo was in the bottom two again against one of the crowd favourites [[Laura White]]. This time she sang "[[Knockin' on Heaven's Door]]" and was saved by Cowell, Minogue and Walsh. Her performance was overshadowed by the uproar over White's departure. Voting statistics revealed that White received more votes than Lorenzo meaning if Walsh sent the result to deadlock, White would’ve been saved. During [[Take That]] week, Lorenzo sang "[[Love Ain't Here Anymore]]". She received high praise for her performance, with Cowell saying it was sensational. By the quarter-final, Lorenzo was Minogue's last remaining act and she was eliminated after receiving the fewest public votes. Lorenzo bowed out with another performance of "[[Always (Bon Jovi song)|Always]]". Former friend [[Alexandra Burke]] went on to win the show. ====Performances on ''The X Factor''==== {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="4" style="background:#BFBFBF;"| ''The X Factor'' performances and results |- |- ! Week ! Song ! Theme (if any) ! Result |- | Week 1 | "[[Take My Breath Away]]" | Number one songs in UK and US | Safe '''10th''' (3.47%) |-style="background:lightblue" | Week 2 | "[[I Just Can't Stop Loving You]]" | Songs by [[Michael Jackson]] or [[The Jackson 5]] | Bottom two '''10th''' (2.95%) |- | Final Showdown (Week 2) | "[[Purple Rain (song)|Purple Rain]]" | Contestants' choice | Saved by deadlock |- | Week 3 | "[[Summertime (George Gershwin song)|Summertime]]" | [[Big band]] | Safe '''5th''' (8.93%) |- | Week 4 | "[[No More Tears (Enough Is Enough)]]" | [[Disco]] | Safe '''5th''' (10.25%) |-style="background:lightblue" | Week 5 | "[[My All]]" | Songs by [[Mariah Carey]] | Bottom two '''7th''' (6.94%) |- | Final Showdown (Week 5) | "[[Knockin' On Heaven's Door]]" | Contestants' choice | Saved by judges |- | Week 6 | "[[Angels (Robbie Williams song)|Angels]]" | Best of British | Safe '''3rd''' (13.91%) |- | Week 7 | "[[Love Ain't Here Anymore]]" | Songs by [[Take That]] | Safe '''3rd''' (16.07%) |-style="background:pink" | rowspan="2"| Quarter-Final | "[[I Love Rock 'n' Roll]]" | Songs by [[Britney Spears]] | rowspan="2"| Eliminated by public vote
'''5th''' (15.23%) |-style="background:pink" | "[[Always (Bon Jovi song)|Always]]" | American classics |} ===2009–10: After ''The X Factor''=== Lorenzo performed at gigs across the UK and Ireland in December 2008 and January 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www4.u.tv/UTV_WhatsOn/Programmes/utvlife/feature.asp?epis_id=100676&feat_id=102065 |access-date=2009-01-21 |df=dmy-all }} In February and March 2009, she joined the ''X Factor Live'' tour with fellow finalists. She also was nominated for three awards at the Digital Spy Reality TV Awards. Ruth officially confirmed her record deal with [[Virgin Records]] on May 6 with an interview with Xpose. In 2010, Lorenzo was approached by Spanish TV Channel [[Cuatro (channel)|Cuatro]] and asked to write a song for their new fictional drama [[Valientes (Spanish TV series)|''Valientes'']]. She accepted and composed two songs for the show, one for the opening ("Quiero Ser Valiente") and one for the end credits ("Te Puedo Ver"). Ruth performed "Quiero Ser Valiente" on Friday 22 January on Spanish talent show ''Fama a bailar'' (which was also aired on Cuatro).{{cite web|url=http://www.formulatv.com/1,,13912,1.html |title=Ruth Lorenzo compone e interpreta la cabecera y el cierre de 'Valientes' |publisher=FormulaTV |access-date=2012-04-10}} In July 2010 it was revealed that Lorenzo had written songs for Dannii Minogue's comeback album revealed on Dannii's ITV2 show ''Style Queen''.{{citation needed|date=January 2020}} Lorenzo confirmed in a blog posting that she parted away from [[Virgin Records]]/[[EMI]] due to "creative differences" and that she would continue working on her album as an independent artist. [[File:Rurthinscotland.jpg|thumbnail|Ruth performing live in [[Ayr]], [[Scotland]]]] ===2011–13: ''The Raspberry Pattern''=== She signed up to website indiegogo.com where fans helped to fund her debut single. The funding was for airplay, the video shooting, marketing and PR services.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiegogo.com/ruthlorenzovideo |title=Ruth Lorenzo - Single Pre-Sales and VIP Exclusives |publisher=Indiegogo |access-date=2012-04-10}} The CD version included "[[Burn (Ruth Lorenzo song)|Burn]]", an acoustic version of the song and "Eternity".{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/ruth-lorenzo-single-pre-sales-and-vip-exclusives?c=activity|title = Ruth Lorenzo - Single Pre-Sales and VIP Exclusives}} The Raspberry Pattern became the name of her band.{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.formulatv.com/xfactor/entrevista-con-ruth-lorenzo/|title = Entrevista con Ruth Lorenzo}} Lorenzo was booked for more dates around the United Kingdom for the summer and autumn of 2011. Ruth released a free track download titled "The Night" for her Facebook fans in August 2012 which was officially released in June 2013 with a videoclip. On 11 November a lyric video for her single "Love is Dead" was uploaded to Ruth's [[YouTube]] channel. The single was released under the independent H&I Music on digital platforms, including the song "Pain" as a B-side. At the end of 2013 Ruth signed with a new record company, Spanish company Roster Music and unveiled her new website. During 2013 she took part on the ''Celebrities On Ice'' tour in the UK.{{Cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/theatre/q--celebrities-ice-star-2821534|title=Q & A with Celebrities On Ice star Ruth Lorenzo|first=Roz|last=Laws|date=19 April 2013|website=BirminghamLive}} ===2014: ''Planeta Azul'' and Eurovision Song Contest === [[File:ESC2014 - Spain 04.jpg|thumb|Ruth Lorenzo at rehearsal in Copenhagen]] {{Main|Eurovision Song Contest 2014|Planeta Azul}} Her website announced the upcoming release of her first studio album.{{Cite web|url=https://ruthlorenzo.com/|title=Ruth Lorenzo | Official Website}} She left to [[Los Angeles, California]] to record various tracks for her album, to be titled ''[[Planeta Azul]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://wiwibloggs.com/2014/06/02/ruth-lorenzo-record-album/52145/|title=Ruth Lorenzo heads to Los Angeles to record new album|first=Liam|last=Thorne|date=2 June 2014|website=wiwibloggs}} On 20 January [[Televisión Española|TVE]] selected Ruth Lorenzo as one of the five candidates to represent Spain at the 2014 [[Eurovision Song Contest]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurovision-spain.com/iphp/noticia.php?numero=9157&idioma=|title = TVE confirma a Ruth Lorenzo, Brequette, Jorge González, Raúl y la Dama para su preselección|date = 20 January 2014}} Months earlier the ''eurovision-spain.com'' website made a survey known as "La Elección Interna" among Eurovision fans and international juries from thirteen different countries to check who could be the ideal Spanish candidate to represent Spain. Ruth came second in the list among one hundred different Spanish candidates{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurovision-spain.com/iphp/noticia.php?numero=8990|title=La joven promesa Roko se alza con el título de artista ideal de España para Eurovisión|date=29 September 2013}} In February the song "[[Dancing in the Rain (song)|Dancing In The Rain]]" was released{{Cite web|url=http://www.rtve.es/alacarta/audios/eurovision-2014/eurovision-2014-ruth-lorenzo-canta-dancing-in-the-rain/2369873/|title = Ruth Lorenzo -"Dancing in the rain"|date = 28 February 2014}} as one of the Spanish pre-selection entries for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2014]]. The song was released on 18 February and it became number one on [[iTunes]] Spain. On 22 February she won the [[Spain in the Eurovision Song Contest|Spanish national final]]. Therefore, she represented Spain in the contest with the song "[[Dancing in the Rain (song)|Dancing In The Rain]]" on 10 May 2014 in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. The song finished 10th overall. Her debut album ''[[Planeta Azul]]'' was released on 27 October 2014. The album contains thirteen new songs, and also "[[Dancing in the Rain (song)|Dancing In The Rain]]". The release of the album was preceded by the release of its lead single, "Gigantes", on 7 October 2014,{{Cite web|url=https://los40.com/los40/2014/09/30/lomas40/1412097240_701130.html|title=Xavi Martínez presentará en exclusiva Gigantes, lo nuevo de Ruth Lorenzo|date=30 September 2014|website=LOS40}} which debuted at number six on the [[Productores de Música de España|Spanish Singles Chart]]. The official video for the single was released on 22 October. ===2015–2016: After Eurovision, ''Tu Cara Me Suena''=== In 2015, Lorenzo served as a judge in the Spanish [[talent show]] ''Levántate'' (Spanish version of ''Stand Up for Your Country''), aired on [[Telecinco]] from 10 February 2015 to 17 March 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://www.formulatv.com/noticias/43736/manuel-villanueva-orgullos-seamos-primera-cadena-producir-levantate/|title=Manuel Villanueva: "Es un orgullo que 'Levántate' sea un formato español y que seamos la primera cadena en ponerlo en marcha"|website=FormulaTV}} She also served as a member of the Spanish jury in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015]]. On 16 October 2015, a special re-issue of her debut album ''[[Planeta Azul]]'' was released, which includes new tracks and songs she had recorded previously in English language. One of the new tracks, titled "99", was released as a single on 28 August 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.europapress.es/chance/cineymusica/noticia-ruth-lorenzo-publica-hoy-nuevo-single-ingles-99-20150828154341.html|title=Ruth Lorenzo publica hoy su nuevo single en inglés, '99'|date=28 August 2015|publisher=Europa Press|language=es}}{{cite web|url=http://spanishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Ruth+Lorenzo&titel=99&cat=s|title=RUTH LORENZO - 99 (SONG)|publisher=Hung Medien}} On 30 July 2015, Lorenzo was announced to join the cast of the fourth season of television show ''[[Tu cara me suena (Spanish TV series)|Tu cara me suena]]'', in which celebrity contestants impersonate a different iconic music artist on stage each week.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.20minutos.es/dando-la-nota/2015/07/30/exclusiva-ruth-lorenzo-concursara-en-tu-cara-me-suena/|title=Ruth Lorenzo concursará en 'Tu Cara Me Suena'|newspaper=20 Minutos|language=es}} The season premiered on 18 September 2015 on [[Antena 3 (Spain)|Antena 3]].{{cite news|url=http://www.larazon.es/sociedad/comunicacion/tu-cara-me-suena-un-espectaculo-total-OD10756976#.Ttt1v8vVLXuDYnO|title="Tu cara me suena", un espectáculo total|newspaper=La Razón|language=es}} In the season finale that took place on 29 January 2016, she was declared winner with 47% of the televote.{{cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/television/2016/01/30/56ac703022601dd6698b4588.html|title=Ruth Lorenzo gana 'Tu cara me suena'|newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|language=es}} ====Performances on ''Tu Cara Me Suena''==== {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="width:100%; margin:1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan="5" style="background:#BFBFBF;"| ''Tu cara me suena'' performances and results |- |- ! Week ! Portraying ! Song ! Points ! Result |- | Week 1 | [[Lady Gaga]] | "[[The Edge of Glory]]" | 24 | 1st place |- | Week 2 | [[Freddie Mercury]] and [[Montserrat Caballé]] | "[[Barcelona (Freddie Mercury and Montserrat Caballé song)|Barcelona]]" | 22 | 2nd place |- | Week 3 | [[María Jiménez]] | "Se Me Olvidó Otra Vez" | 11 | 8th place |- | Week 4 | [[Sinéad O'Connor]] | "[[Nothing Compares 2 U]]" | 21 | 2nd place |- | Week 5 | [[Tina Turner]] | "[[Proud Mary]]" | 24 | 1st place |- | Week 6 | [[Amaral (band)|Amaral]] | "Toda La Noche En La Calle" | 14 | 6th place |- | Week 7 | [[Marilyn Manson]] | "[[Personal Jesus]]" | 21 | 2nd place |- | Week 8 | [[Céline Dion]] | "[[All By Myself]]" | 22 | 2nd place |- | Week 9 | [[Amy Winehouse]] | "[[Back to Black (song)|Back to Black]]" | 21 | 2nd place |- | Week 10 | [[Jessica Rabbit]] | "[[Why Don't You Do Right?]]" | 22 | 1st place |- | Week 11 | [[Gloria Estefan]] | "[[Conga (song)|Conga]]" | 10 | 7th place |- | Week 12 | [[Conchita Wurst]] | "[[Rise Like a Phoenix]]" | 19 | 4th place |- | Week 13 | [[Florence & the Machine]] | "[[Shake It Out]]" | 20 | 3rd place |- | Week 14 | [[Mariah Carey]] | "[[All I Want For Christmas Is You]]" | 17 | 4th place |- | Week 15 (1st Semi-Final) | [[P!nk]] | "[[Glitter in the Air]]" | 22 | 1st place (1st qualifier for the final) |- | Week 16 (2nd Semi-Final) | [[David Bowie]] | "[["Heroes" (David Bowie song)|Heroes]]" | {{N/A|Already qualified}} | {{N/A|Already qualified}} |- | Week 17 (Final) | [[Jennifer Hudson]] | "[[And I Am Telling You I'm Not Going]]" | style="background:Gold" | '''47%''' | style="background:Gold" | '''Season's Winner''' |- |colspan="3" style="text-align:center;" |'''TOTAL''' |'''290''' | |} ==== ''Voces Tour'' ==== After a short break from television, the artist focused on music, recording her new album between Berlin, Stockholm, Madrid, Barcelona and London. On 14 May, she joined the television show ''Objetivo [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovisión]]'' to discuss about the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] and the Spanish candidate.{{cite web |url=https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CgqPGvLXEAA7U3O.jpg|title=tour poster|publisher=Twitter}} In September 2016, she announced that on 19 October she would achieve a [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]] with the goal of getting funds breast cancer investigation. The record consisted in holding eight concerts in eight different Spanish towns in less than twelve hours (''Un Récord Por Ellas'' - a Guinness Record Award for Women). [[File:Ruth Lorenzo Guinnes World Records.jpg|thumb|alt=Ruth Lorenzo receiving the World Guinness Records Certificate]] At the end of 2016, she started the ''Voces Tour'' touring Spain, visiting Madrid, Barcelona, Seville, Valencia and Murcia. ===2017: Entrepreneurial projects === On 13 October 2017 and after a little break from music industry, Lorenzo released "Good Girls Don't Lie", the first single of her upcoming second studio album ''Loveaholic''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurovision-spain.com/iphp/noticia.php?numero=12009|title=Ruth Lorenzo presenta Good girls don't lie, primer single de su esperado nuevo álbum|last=Gregoris|first=Ángel M.|date=2017-10-13|website=eurovision-spain.com|language=es|access-date=2017-10-19}} Previously, she worked on a collaborative cover of the Spanish hit song "[[¿A quién le importa?]]", originally performed by [[Fangoria (band)|Alaska y Dinarama]], as the anthem for [[WorldPride#WorldPride Madrid 2017|WorldPride Madrid 2017]], with other famous Spanish singers such as [[Marta Sánchez]], [[Rosa López]], [[Vicky Larraz]], [[La Terremoto de Alcorcón]], [[Soraya Arnelas]] and [[Nancys Rubias]], among others.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lasexta.com/especiales/world-pride-madrid/orgullo-lgtbi/a-quien-le-importa-asi-suena-el-himno-oficial-del-world-pride-madrid-2017_201706285953f2d20cf2a25c00ab7737.html|title = 'A quién le importa': Así suena el himno oficial del World Pride Madrid 2017|date = 28 June 2017}} On 29 September 2017, Lorenzo announced "[[Good Girls Don't Lie]]", the first song of ''Loveaholic''. The song was released on the 13 October 2017, reaching number one in sales on the main digital platforms such as [[iTunes]], [[Google Play Music]] and [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]]. The song became trending topic on [[Twitter]] during that first weekend, and it also aired on main Spanish radio stations. Soon after that she announced ''The Loveaholic Tour'' for 2018. ==== Record label: Raspberry Records ==== After declining an offer from [[Virgin EMI Records]], being part of [[Roster Music]] from 2013 and releasing a charity single with [[Universal Music]], in 2017 Lorenzo decided to create her own record label, Raspberry Records, and release her music under this label. ==== White Lion ==== Lorenzo announced the creation of her own clothing line, White Lion. The name was chosen in homage to the name given to her fans (lions). === 2018–2019: ''Loveaholic'', ''La Llamada'', new single, and television projects=== {{More citations needed section|date=November 2019}} Her second album, ''Loveaholic'', was released on 9 March 2018; the album includes a collaboration with [[Jeff Beck]]. It peaked at number 9 on the [[Productores de Música de España|Spanish Albums Chart]]. In December 2018, Lorenzo debuted in musical theatre with the role of God in ''La Llamada'', at the Teatro Lara in [[Madrid]].{{cite web|url=https://los40.com/los40/2018/11/30/actualidad/1543586035_625941.html|title=RUTH LORENZO SE SUMA A 'LA LLAMADA' DE LOS JAVIS|publisher=[[Los 40]]|date=2018-11-30|access-date=2018-12-26}} On March 29, 2019, she performed at the sold out ''Festival Mil·leni'' at the Teatro Coliseum in Barcelona. In May 2019, Lorenzo starred in an episode of the [[La Sexta]] travel show ''Viajeras con B''. In June 2019, she released the single "Underworld". Its official music video was directed by Pablo H. Smith and produced by The Panda Bear Show. During the summer of 2019, she toured Spain with ''La Llamada: Musical''. In November 2019, she starred in the multimedia event show ''El gran secuestro'' for [[Playz]].{{cite news|url=http://joseisasa.com/2019/11/elgransecuestro-o-como-revolucionar-la-tv/|title=#ElGranSecuestro, o cómo revolucionar la TV|access-date=2019-11-24|date=2019-11-24|website=Blog de José de Isasa|language=es}}{{cite news|url=https://www.lainformacion.com/opinion/borja-teran/un-secuestro-de-culto-emitido-en-directo-por-rtve/6522270|title=Un secuestro de culto, emitido en directo por RTVE|access-date=2019-11-24|last=LaInformacion|website=La Información|language=es}} === 2020–present: ''Crisálida'' and ''Veo cómo cantas''=== In June 2020, Lorenzo released "Miedo", the first single from her third studio album, to be titled ''Crisálida''.{{cite news|url=https://www.eldia.es/vida-y-estilo/gente/2020/06/15/ruth-lorenzo-regresa-cantando-miedos-22389345.html|title=Ruth Lorenzo regresa cantando a sus miedos|access-date=2021-01-20|date=2020-11-24|website=El Día|language=es}} A second single that precedes the album, the same-titled "Crisálida", will be released on January 29, 2021.{{cite news|url=https://los40.com/los40/2021/01/19/musica/1611097083_600623.html|title=RUTH LORENZO ANUNCIA LA FECHA DE LANZAMIENTO DE SU NUEVA CANCIÓN: 'CRISÁLIDA'|access-date=2021-01-20|date=2021-01-20|website=[[Los 40]]|language=es}} In 2021, she joined the [[Antena 3 (Spanish TV channel)|Antena 3]] music game show ''[[Veo cómo cantas]]'' (the Spanish version of ''[[I Can See Your Voice]]'') as a panelist.{{cite news|url=https://vertele.eldiario.es/noticias/Manel-Fuentes-y-asesores-Veo-como-cantas-comparten-fotos-inicio-sus-grabaciones_0_2305269465.html|title=Manel Fuentes y los asesores de 'Veo cómo cantas' comparten fotos en el inicio de sus grabaciones|access-date=2021-01-20|date=2021-01-15|website=[[eldiario.es]]|language=es-ES}} In 2022, she was guest judge on season 2 of ''[[Drag Race España (season 2)|Drag Race España]]''.{{Cite tweet |user=DragRaceEs |number=1520843718458322945|date=1 May 2022 |title=La semana que viene nos espera: · Lucha de sumos 🤼‍♀️ · Spots publicitarios para convencer a todas las drag queens del mundo que España es el mejor destino 😍 · @RuthLorenzo de jurado invitada 💫 👠 Directo ▶ http://atres.red/sj3ec #DragRace6 |access-date=2 May 2022}} ==Discography== {{Main|Ruth Lorenzo discography}} ;Studio albums * ''[[Planeta Azul]]'' (2014) * ''[[Loveaholic (album)|Loveaholic]]'' (2018) ;Extended plays * ''[[Burn (Ruth Lorenzo song)|Burn]]'' (2011) * ''The Night'' (2013) {{cleanup-PR|date=March 2017}} {{COI|date=March 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Jarrad Rogers, 'Mstr Rogers' | image = Mr Rogers.jpg | birth_name = Jarrad Leith Rogers | alias = Mstr Rogers | origin = [[Melbourne]], Australia | genre = Pop, [[Electronic dance music|EDM]] | occupation = Artist, record producer, songwriter | years_active = 2001–present | past_member_of = Beachwood<ref>{{cite web|url=https://musicfeeds.com.au/features/telenova-there-isnt-any-pressure-its-still-a-gas/|title=Telenova: 'There Isn’t Any Pressure – It’s Still a Gas'|author=Billy, August|date=19 August 2022|access-date=29 August 2022|work=[[Music Feeds]]}}</ref> }} '''Jarrad Leith Rogers''', aka "Mstr Rogers" is an Australian-British artist, songwriter and pop producer.
==Early life== Jarrad played trumpet and classical piano from an early age. Studying piano under renowned concert pianist, Alexander Sumetski, he progressed to the Australian Music Education Board's highest grade. At 13, he formed a band with his brother and together they won studio time through a local band competition which sparked his interest in music production. He completed a double degree with Honours in Business Management and Civil Engineering at RMIT University in Melbourne and then worked as a consultant for Accenture but spent all his spare time pursuing music.
==Career== ===2001–2005: Beginnings in Australia=== From 2001, Jarrad worked as the in-house producer at a newly formed independent record label in Melbourne and developed the direction and sound of artists [[Daniel Merriweather]] and [[Phrase (rapper)|Phrase]]. He co-wrote the singles '[[Predictable (Delta Goodrem song)|Predictable]]' and '[[Not Me, Not I]]' with [[Delta Goodrem]] and [[Kara DioGuardi]] for 15 x platinum selling Australian artist [[Delta Goodrem]]'s debut album 'Innocent Eyes'.<ref name="Predictable">{{cite web|url=http://www.acharts.us/australia_singles_top_50/2003/40|title=Predictable Peak Chart Position|website=αCharts|access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="Not Me Not I">{{cite web|url=http://www.acharts.us/australia_singles_top_50/2003/40|title=Not Me Not I Peak Chart Position|website=αCharts|access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref> Innocent Eyes was the highest-selling album in Australia of the decade. 'Not me, Not I' peaked at number-one in the Australian charts, breaking Kylie Minogue's record of having the most songs released from an album to reach number-one. 'Predictable' also reached number-one and remained in the top ten for eight weeks.
Jarrad went on to write and produce songs for Australian Idol winner [[Guy Sebastian]]. In 2006, Jarrad won a prestigious [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) award in the category of 'Most Performed Urban Work' for '[[Oh Oh]]', a single which Jarrad produced and co-wrote with Guy Sebastian<ref name="Oh Oh">{{cite web|url= http://acharts.us/australia_singles_top_50/2005/11 |title=Oh Oh Peak Chart Position|website=αCharts|access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="Oh Oh ARIA">{{cite web|url=http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/APRAAwards/MusicAwards/History/2006Winners.aspx |title=Oh Oh ARIA Awards |access-date=2 September 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110308003717/http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/APRAAwards/MusicAwards/History/2006Winners.aspx |archive-date= 8 March 2011 }}</ref>). He also wrote with [[Ricki-Lee Coulter]] the song ('Sunshine', No. 8<ref name="Sunshine Peak Chart Position">{{cite web|url= http://acharts.us/australia_singles_top_50/2005/43 |title=Sunshine Peak Chart Position|website=αCharts|access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref>) and [[Jimmy Barnes]] ('Say It Ain't So' which appears on AUS No. 1 selling album 'Double Happiness').
===2005–2014: Success in the United Kingdom===
In 2005, Jarrad signed a publishing deal with Mushroom Music and relocated to London.
On a songwriting trip to LA in 2006, Jarrad had the opportunity to work with and produce songs (unreleased) for [[Lauryn Hill]] who was in the process of writing new material. Jarrad co-wrote 'Smilin' with [[Bryn Christopher]]<ref name="Bryn Christopher Smilin' Peak Chart Position">{{cite web|url= http://acharts.us/uk_singles_top_75/2008/37 |title= Bryn Christopher Smilin' Peak Chart Position |website= αCharts |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref>) and The Quest,<ref name="Bryn Christopher The Quest Peak Chart Position">{{cite web|url= http://acharts.us/uk_singles_top_75/2008/25 |title= Bryn Christopher The Quest Peak Chart Position |website= αCharts |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref> and also featured in series 4 of [[Grey's Anatomy]]<ref name="Bryn Christopher in Greys Anatomy">{{cite web|url=http://abc.go.com/music-lounge/artist/bryn-christopher/325353 |title= Bryn Christopher in Greys Anatomy |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref>). In 2006, Jarrad produced Official Remixes for [[Mark Ronson]] single 'Valarie featuring [[Amy Winehouse]], and [[Groove Armada]]'s single '[[Song 4 Mutya (Out of Control)|Song 4 Mutya]]'.
Jarrad produced and co-wrote '[[Love You Anyway]]' for [[Boyzone]], which entered the UK singles charts at No. 5<ref name="Love You Anyway Peak Chart Position">{{cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-chart/20081005/7501/ |title= Love You Anyway Peak Chart Position |website= [[Official Charts Company|Official Charts]] |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref> and peaked in the Irish singles charts at No. 3<ref name="Love You Anyway Ireland Peak Chart Position">{{cite web|url= http://acharts.us/ireland_singles_top_50/2008/41 |title= Love You Anyway Ireland Peak Chart Position |website= αCharts |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref> In October 2008, Jarrad produced a song for Annie Lennox, ('[[Pattern of My Life]]').
2010 saw Jarrad write with artist [[Alex Clare]]. Two songs from these sessions, 'Treading Water' (co-written with [[Eg White]]) and 'Sanctuary' were chosen to feature on Clare's debut album on Island Records which was released on 8 July 2011. [[The Lateness of the Hour (Alex Clare album)|The Lateness of the Hour]]. The album peaked at number 17 on the UK Albums Chart, number 8 on the German Albums Chart and number 48 on the US Billboard 200. 'Treading Water' was released as a single.
Jarrad also wrote with Lana Del Rey in 2011. Together they wrote 'Live or Die' which was leaked online.<ref name="Live or Die">{{cite web|url= https://genius.com/Lana-del-rey-live-or-die-lyrics/ |title= Live or Die |access-date=21 January 2016}}</ref> In 2011, Jarrad also produced and co-wrote (with [[Bryn Christopher]]) for [[The Saturdays]]' 2011 album ''[[On Your Radar (album)|On Your Radar]]''. He also worked with UK rap artist [[Tinchy Stryder]] and wrote "[[Bright Lights (Tinchy Stryder song)|Bright Lights]]", which entered the UK Singles Chart at number seven<ref name="Bright Lights Peak Chart Position">{{cite web|url= https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-chart/20120311/7501/ |title= Bright Lights Peak Chart Position |website= [[Official Charts Company|Official Charts]] |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref> and featured [[Pixie Lott]] as a guest vocalist. Pixie released her own version of the song on her album ''[[Young Foolish Happy]]'' titled "Bright Lights (Good Life) Part II", which Jarrad also produced.
Between November 2011 and February 2012, Jarrad co-wrote and produced the debut album from X Factor finalist [[Aiden Grimshaw]], titled ''[[Misty Eye]]''. The album was released to critical acclaim<ref name="Misty Eye Guardian Review">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/aug/09/aiden-grimshaw-misty-eye-review |title=Misty Eye Guardian Review |access-date=2 September 2012 | location=London |work=The Guardian |first=Caroline |last=Sullivan |date=9 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="Misty Eye Digital Spy Review">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/albumreviews/a399165/aiden-grimshaw-misty-eye-album-review.html |title=Misty Eye Digital Spy Review |website=[[Digital Spy]] |date=14 August 2012 |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref><ref name="Misty Eye Any Decent Music Review Aggregator">{{cite web|url=http://www.anydecentmusic.com/review/4807/Aiden-Grimshaw-Misty-Eye.aspx |title=Misty Eye Any Decent Music Review Aggregator |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref> and entered the UK Albums Chart at No. 19 on 26 August 2012.<ref name="Misty Eye Peak Chart Position">{{cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/albums-chart/20120826/7502/ |title= Misty Eye Peak Chart Position |website= [[Official Charts Company|Official Charts]] |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref>
Dance producer [[Avicii]] released a version of Jarrad's song "Last Dance", co-written with Karen Poole. The track was premiered on [[Pete Tong]]'s show on [[BBC Radio 1]] on 23 March 2012.<ref name="Last Dance Debut On Pete Tong">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01dc1ww |title= Last Dance Debut on Pete Tong |access-date=2 September 2012}}</ref> Jarrad co-wrote "Give Me Life" which was released by English boy band [[JLS]] on their fourth studio album, ''Evolution''. The album was released on 5 November 2012 through RCA Records and debuted at number 3 in the UK. In 2012, Jarrad was an 'International Judge' for [[Australasian Performing Right Association]]'s prestigious songwriting competition and was asked to be the key speaker for an APRA event held on 6 December 2012 at the Australia Centre, The Strand, London.
In early 2013, Jarrad co-wrote "Lost Boys" with Roy Stryde and Australian Band, [[5 Seconds of Summer]] which was performed by the band while they were supporting One Direction on their world tour. "Ghost Ship", co-written by Jarrad, [[Devlin (rapper)|Devlin]] and [[Alex Clare]] was released on ''[[A Moving Picture]]'', the second studio album by English rapper Devlin. The album was released on 4 February 2013 and peaked at number 19 on the UK charts. In May 2013, "Fire Starter", a song co-written with [[Lindy Robbins]] and Julia Michaels, was released on the fourth studio album by [[Demi Lovato]], on Hollywood Records. The album debuted at number three on the US Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 110,000 copies, becoming her best-selling debut week of her career. "Fire Starter" was chosen by [[E!]] to feature on their promotion for the 8th season of [[Keeping Up with the Kardashians]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disneydreaming.com/2013/05/23/kim-kardashian-talks-pregnancy-curves-in-keeping-up-with-the-kardashians-promo/ |title=Kim Kardashian Talks Pregnancy Curves In "Keeping Up with the Kardashians" Promo |publisher=Disney Dreaming |date=23 May 2013 |access-date=28 June 2014}}</ref>
Icona Pop released "In the Stars", a song co-written and produced by Jarrad which appears on their full-length album, ''[[This Is... Icona Pop]]''. "In the Stars" was also released in association with Samsung's Galaxy series, using a 'Galaxy mix' of the original.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popjustice.com/songs/icona-pop-into-the-stars-galaxy-mix/ |title=Listen: Icona Pop – 'Into The Stars' (Galaxy mix) |publisher=Popjustice.com |date=5 September 2013 |access-date=28 June 2014}}</ref> In December 2013, [[Rebecca Ferguson (singer)|Rebecca Ferguson]] released her second album ''[[Freedom (Rebecca Ferguson album)|Freedom]]'' which includes five songs co-written and produced by Jarrad. The album debuted at number 6 and the single "I Hope" debuted at number 15 on the UK charts. The Album achieved a silver certification from the BPI after just 3 weeks since its release date followed by a Gold certification on 27 December 2013.
Glorious, the debut studio album by the Grammy award winner [[Foxes (singer)|Foxes]], released 12 May 2014, features 'Night Owl' which Jarrad co-wrote and produced. In July 2014, 'Lost Boy' was released on the Australian version of [[5 Seconds of Summer]]'s self-titled debut studio album. The album which went to number 1 on the Australian charts. He co-wrote with James Morrison for his forthcoming album. He also collaborated with [[Charli XCX]] for releases for a number of artists. On 28 July, [[Neon Jungle]] released 'So Alive', produced by Jarrad and co-written with Charli XCX and Ana Diaz. Neon Jungle's album, 'Welcome to the Jungle', went to number 8 on the UK Album Charts.
===2015–present: Move to America===
In October 2015, Mstr Rogers released his own debut single, "I'll Take You" on Big Beat Records. In January 2016, it reached no. 1 on the Global Viral Chart and no. 6 on the US Viral Chart.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2017/06/26/mstr-rogers-turns-sultry-new-electro-jam-dont-think/|title = MSTR ROGERS turns out sultry new electro jam "Don't You Think"|date = 26 June 2017}}</ref>
In June 2017, Mstr Rogers released his follow up single, "Don't You Think", featuring Aanysa on [[Ultra Music]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://soundcloud.com/mstr_rogers/dont-you-think|title = Don't You Think ft. Aanysa}}</ref>
Jarrad signed a record deal with Ultra Music and released "Sooner or Later" (1+ million streams across platforms).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.magneticmag.com/2017/03/premiere-hit-making-mstr-rogers-drops-catchy-electronic-track-sooner-or-later/|title=Premiere: Hit-Making MSTR ROGERS Drops Catchy Electronic Track "Sooner or Later"}}</ref> He has done official remixes for [[Twenty One Pilots]] and [[Andra Day]].
He co-wrote and produced [[Rachel Platten]]'s single "[[Broken Glass (Rachel Platten song)|Broken Glass]]" in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/Pop-Star-Rachel-Platten-Crashes-The-Ceiling-With-Brand-New-Single-Broken-Glass-591084|title=Pop Star Rachel Platten Crashes the Ceiling with Brand New Single 'Broken Glass'}}</ref> As of October 2017, it was 31 on AC radio chart and growing and has 7+ million [[Spotify]] streams.
He co-wrote "Like That" for [[Bea Miller]] which has over 56 million Spotify streams.
In 2017, Mstr Rogers signed a deal with Circle Live Agency.
He has upcoming releases for [[Andy Grammer]] including "Smoke Clears" (writer / producer) and "Workin On It" (producer).
Rogers is currently based in [[Los Angeles]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2022}}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Irving Kaufman | image = Irving_Kaufman_singer_crop.jpg | caption = Kaufman circa 1919 | image_size = | birth_name = Isidore Kaufman | birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1890|2|8}} | birth_place = [[Syracuse, New York]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|1976|1|3|1890|2|8|mf=yes}} | Star Sign = | origin = | instrument = [[Singing|Vocals]] | genre = | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]] | years_active = 1914–1949 | label = [[Victor Talking Machine Company|Victor]]
[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]
[[Edison Records|Edison]]
[[Gennett Records|Gennett]]
[[Aeolian Company|Aeolian]]
[[Banner Records|Banner]]
[[Oriole Records (U.S.)|Oriole]]
[[Vocalion Records|Vocalion]] }} '''Irving Kaufman''' (February 8, 1890 – January 3, 1976) was a prolific American early twentieth century singer, recording artist and [[vaudeville]] performer. ==Life and career== Kaufman was born '''Isidore Kaufman''' in [[Syracuse, New York]], the son of [[Russian people|Russian]] [[Russian Jewish|Jewish]] immigrants. He was a member of ''The Kaufman Brothers'', along with his brothers Phillip and Jack.{{cite web|last=Gracyk|first=Tim|title=Irving Kaufman (8 February 1890 - 3 January 1976)|url=http://www.gracyk.com/kaufman.shtml|work=Popular American Recording Artists|access-date=5 September 2013}} From 1913 through 1919 Kaufman was part of [[Avon Comedy Four|The Avon Comedy Four]], a popular comedy and music group that was formed in 1902. Two of the group's members went on to fame as [[Smith and Dale]]. Kaufman began recording in 1914, and recorded for [[Victor Records|Victor]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Aeolian Company|Vocalion]], [[Gennett Records|Gennett]], [[Edison Records|Edison]], [[Harmony Records|Harmony]], as well as all of the dime labels ([[Banner Records|Banner]], [[Perfect Records|Perfect]], etc.). Early in his career, when recording for Edison and Victor, he recorded under his own name, but he also used a number of (non-Jewish-sounding) aliases including 'Tom Frawley'.{{cite web|title=Irving Kaufman as Lazy Dan|url=http://www.lib.umd.edu/LAB/JERRYLEE/vocalists/0000000b.html|work=The LAB On-Line Photo Archive|publisher=Library of American Broadcasting|access-date=5 September 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305015100/http://www.lib.umd.edu/LAB/JERRYLEE/vocalists/0000000b.html|archive-date=5 March 2012}}{{cite web|last=Barna|first=Ryan|title=The Final Years of Irving Kaufman: An Illustrated Discography (1938-1974)|url=http://www.phonostalgia.com/kaufman/final.html|publisher=Phonostalgia|access-date=5 September 2013|date=22 November 2010}} Sometimes, as in the case of several of his 1927 "Broadway Bell-Hops" vocals, he was merely credited as "Vocal Chorus". He was often credited as "vocal refrain by George Beaver" on the dime store labels. Kaufman was a singer in the vaudeville style, and although he was not considered a jazz singer, he nonetheless sang on recordings accompanied by some of the foremost jazz figures of the 1920s, including [[Leon "Bix" Beiderbecke]], [[Frank Trumbauer]], [[the Dorsey Brothers]], [[Red Nichols]], [[Miff Mole]], and [[Eddie Lang]]. His voice recorded well - both acoustically and electrically - and was one of the most prolific singers during the 1920s. Kaufman retired after a heart attack in 1949, and made no further commercial recordings until 1974, when a 2-LP set titled ''Reminisce With Irving Kaufman'' was released. It consisted mostly of transcriptions of his old recordings, but included several new cuts of Kaufman singing, accompanied by his second wife, Belle Brooks (1904–93). After his retirement, he lived in [[Palm Springs, California]].{{cite news|title=Palm Springs Home To Radio Veterans: Stars of 'Golden Era'|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0qlRAAAAIBAJ&dq=palm-springs&pg=3384%2C2762174|access-date=September 30, 2012|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=December 18, 1974|agency=AP}} He died January 3, 1976 in [[Indio, California]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1976/01/05/archives/irving-kaufman-singer-85-dead-early-radio-and-recording-artist.html ''The New York Times'', 5 January 1976] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commons category |Irving Kaufman}} ==External links== *[http://www.mainspringpress.com/kaufman_photos.html American Recording Pioneers] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=HT9WMVXdAW4C&pg=PA213&lpg=PA213&dq=Irving+Kaufman+(singer).&source=bl&ots=bRQl-W8zRU&sig=37vdBGAf4ETptPwBXXw_IdkCwi0&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=6&ct=result Popular American Recording Pioneers, 1895-1925] * [https://adp.library.ucsb.edu/names/100308 Irving Kaufman recordings] at the [[Discography of American Historical Recordings]]. *{{IMDb name|1532065|Irving Kaufman}} *{{Find a Grave|7861650}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kaufman, Irving}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1976 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American singers]] [[Category:20th-century American male singers]] [[Category:American people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Columbia Records artists]] [[Category:Edison Records artists]] [[Category:Gennett Records artists]] [[Category:Jewish American musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Palm Springs, California]] [[Category:Musicians from Syracuse, New York]] [[Category:Sterling Records (US) artists]] [[Category:Vaudeville performers]] [[Category:Victor Records artists]] [[Category:Vocalion Records artists]] [[Category:20th-century American Jews]]

revision.text:
{{short description|American actress}} {{Infobox person | name = Rena Riffel | birth_name = Rena Lynn Riffel | image = Rena Riffel at 7th Annual WeHo Awards 3.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Rena Riffel at 7th Annual WeHo Awards, 2008 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|03|05}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0726457/|title=Rena Riffel|publisher=IMDb.com|accessdate=2013-09-29}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States | occupation = Actress, dancer, singer, model, director, producer, writer, composer | yearsactive = 1988–present }} {{commons category}}
'''Rena Riffel''' (born March 5, 1969) is an American actress, singer, dancer, model, writer, producer, and director. She is known for her supporting roles in films such as ''[[Showgirls]]'', ''[[Striptease (film)|Striptease]]'', and ''[[Mulholland Drive (film)|Mulholland Drive]]''.
==''Showgirls''== Riffel landed her breakthrough role in the 1995 film ''[[Showgirls]]'' starring [[Elizabeth Berkley]], [[Gina Gershon]], and [[Kyle MacLachlan]]. Initially reading for the lead role of Cristal Connors, Riffel was cast in the supporting role of Penny/Hope after director [[Paul Verhoeven]] decided that she was too young to play an aging showgirl.
While on the set of ''Showgirls'', Riffel approached the music supervisor with a song she recorded, "Deep Kiss". The music supervisor tested the song on the production office (without telling them it had been written by one of the actresses) to determine if it was suitable for the film. Director Paul Verhoeven listened to the song and decided to include it in the [[lap dance]] scene at the Cheetah strip club.
Although an initial box office failure, ''Showgirls'' enjoyed success in the home video market, generating more than $100 million in video rentals and became one of MGM's top 20 all-time best sellers.<ref>{{cite web|first=Jennifer|last=Wood |date=22 September 2015 |access-date=30 August 2021 |title=Showgirls': Paul Verhoeven on the Greatest Stripper Movie Ever Made|publisher=Rollingstone.com |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-news/showgirls-paul-verhoeven-on-the-greatest-stripper-movie-ever-made-54740/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200611131729/https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-news/showgirls-paul-verhoeven-on-the-greatest-stripper-movie-ever-made-54740/ |archive-date=2020-06-11 }}</ref>
For the 2004 re-release as a DVD limited edition box set, Riffel, along with cast members Lin Tucci and Patrick Bristow, had their hand prints and names put in cement in front of the Hollywood Vista Theater at the red carpet event where they were also interviewed by ''[[Access Hollywood]]''. Riffel and Bristow were also special guests at Peaches Christ's Midnight Mass midnight screening of ''Showgirls'' in 2008 in San Francisco, California. They were interviewed on stage after the live performance of the Goddess volcano dance performed by drag queens in gold lamé and featuring [[Peaches Christ]] as Goddess.
When asked if she expected ''Showgirls'' to produce such a cult legacy, Riffel replied, "No. I went into it thinking it would be a really erotic, serious, shocking exposé. People would be sitting on the edge of their seats from suspense. [... But] some people were trying to play straight comedy – I played my character with comedy; I was hoping to get a laugh – but no one was acting with [[Tongue-in-cheek|tongue in cheek]]. I know that everyone went into it thinking it would be like ''[[Basic Instinct]]''. [...] Maybe it's Verhoeven. Even [''Basic Instinct''] seems kind of campy now [...] I think it's something with European filmmakers. I think – and this is my theory – [...] that there's something that European filmmakers have, a punched-up, extreme vibe. Everything's extreme."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mondocelluloid.com/blog.php?p=254 |title=Interview: Rena Riffel Talks to Mondo Celluloid – Part 1 |publisher=Mondo Celluloid |date=2009-03-17 |accessdate=2013-09-29}}</ref>
She is also quoted as saying, "''Showgirls'' just keeps getting more and more popular, it's a total phenomenon. I don't think a film could even try to have this afterlife happen to it. This cult status and celebration is all created by the fans and the people who saw something special in the film. I seem to be one of the only actors that represents and gets involved with the cult status. I think Elizabeth (Berkley) is still upset about how the film was received initially. I think she is brilliant in her role and she should have won best actress at some film festivals, and I think Joe Eszterhas's writing is remarkably brilliant. I suspect because the way they marketed the film, that is what led to the backlash. The marketing campaign was misleading. But at the end of the day, it all worked out for the best."<ref name="eatmybrains.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.eatmybrains.com/showfeature.php?id=92 |title=Interview with Dark Reel star Rena Riffel - Feature Article |publisher=Eat My Brains! |date=2009-04-07 |accessdate=2013-09-29}}</ref>
''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'''s July 23, 2010 issue announced a sequel to ''Showgirls''. Rena Riffel wrote, directed, and starred in the film, released in 2011. Initially entitled ''Showgirl'', it was later renamed ''[[Showgirls 2: Penny's from Heaven]]''.
==''Striptease''==
Following her role in ''Showgirls'', Riffel was cast in ''[[Striptease (film)|Striptease]]'' with [[Demi Moore]] and [[Burt Reynolds]]. ''Showgirls'' was generally disliked and the filmmakers feared people would pre-judge ''Striptease'' for that reason. To avoid any association between the two films, advèrtisements projected ''Striptease'' as more comedic than ''Showgirls'', which had been marketed as a drama. Aside from a common context, ''Striptease'' and ''Showgirls'' shared two notable connections: [[Marguerite Derricks]] choreographed both films, and Rena Riffel played a prominent role in each.
Widely considered a box office failure, ''Striptease'' lacked the momentum that ''Showgirls'' gained in its cult status and has subsequently been referred to as one of the [[worst movies ever made]].
==''Mulholland Drive''==
In 2001, Riffel appeared in the [[David Lynch]] film ''[[Mulholland Drive (film)|Mulholland Drive]]''. When interviewed about the film and if she “got it”, Riffel replied, “See…I can’t remember. No, I guess it still doesn’t make sense to me. It’s been a while – I’d like to watch it again….one website put a lot of clarity on it with their theories.”<ref name="mondocelluloid.com">{{cite web|author=Connie Lynn says |url=http://www.mondocelluloid.com/blog.php?p=256 |title=Interview: Rena Riffel talks to Mondo Celluloid – Part 2 |publisher=Mondo Celluloid |date=2009-03-17 |accessdate=2013-09-29}}</ref>
==Czechsploitation, erotica and horror==
After ''Striptease'', Riffel accepted minor roles on the television series ''[[Married... with Children]]'' in 1997, and ''[[Clueless (TV series)|Clueless]]'' as well as the [[HBO]] movie ''[[Breast Men]]'' before making a string of films with European director Lloyd Simandl. These movies, referred to by some{{Who|date=December 2009}} as “Czechsploitation” films, include ''Dark Confessions'', ''Bound Cargo'', ''Caligula’s Spawn'', and ''No Escape''. These films, coupled with Riffel’s roles in ''Showgirls'' and ''Striptease'' opened the door for her to be cast in a handful of erotic/thriller films such as ''The Pornographer'' and ''Scandalous Behavior'' (with [[Shannon Tweed]]).
In 1999, Riffel appeared in ''[[Citizens of Perpetual Indulgence]]'', a gay-themed comedy/drama/art film. Riffel also appeared in several horror/thriller movies including ''[[Candyman 3: Day of the Dead]]'', ''Unstable Minds'', and ''Dark Reel'' starring Edward Furlong and Tony Todd.
==Musical work and other projects== According to the text trivia track on the 2010 Blu-ray release of ''Showgirls'', one of the songs played during the film's lap-dance sequence was co-written by Riffel.
In 2004, Riffel’s song "Geisha Girl" was featured in Oliver Robbins film ''Wild Roomies''. She also sang the theme song for 2007 E! Entertainment's series, ''Billionaire Heiresses'', called "Livin' in the Fast Lane". In 2008, she starred in [[Coheed and Cambria]]'s music video for "Feathers" playing the 1950s character, Judy Feathers. Judy Feathers is the perfect housewife with a secret of being a cannibal, killing then serving the milkman, postman, sailor, and a boyscout for dinner. It won Best Video in 2008 in the UK for the Kerrang! Awards and Rena appeared on ''Jimmy Kimmel Live!'' on March 5, 2008 with the band.
In 2008, Riffel directed, produced, wrote, and starred in the movie ''Trasharella'', a comedy/crime/fantasy musical. She edited the film herself and her production company, Rena Riffel Films, released the film on DVD through Amazon.com in 2009.
When asked to describe ''Trasharella'', Riffel stated, "It is a satire on B-movie horror films... I went against the grain and instead of trying to make this slick Hollywood film, I just let things be as they were and made it into a really bad grindhouse style exploitation film. ...it's not a dumb film, it's just 'bad'... in a good way. Mae West said: 'When I'm good I'm good, but when I'm bad I'm better.' And we use her quote in ''Trasharella''."<ref name="eatmybrains.com"/>
Riffel developed a musical based on ''Showgirls'', titled ''[[Showgirls#Showgirls! The Musical|Showgirls! The Musical]]'' and also wrote and directed a sequel to ''Showgirls''. The film had its first screening in October 27, 2011, at the Laemmle Theatre's Sunset 5 in West Hollywood, California. It played to a packed house who enjoyed the epic, which had a duration of 2 hours and 24 minutes. The film, now titled ''[[Showgirls 2: Penny's from Heaven]]'' received favorable reviews, with references made to David Lynch's ''[[Inland Empire (film)|Inland Empire]]'' by [[CraveOnline]].com and ''[[LA Weekly]]''. ''Showgirls 2: Penny's from Heaven'' was screened in arthouse theatres across the country and announced further surprise screenings on the movie website, ShowGirls2Movie.com.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}<!-- links and references needed for those sources -->
Riffel is featured on the [[Velvet Revolver]] album ''[[Contraband (Velvet Revolver album)|Contraband]]''.<ref>{{IMDb name|id=0726457}}</ref>

''Chained Heat III: No Holds Barred'' (UK: video title) |- | ''Shark in a Bottle'' | Receptionist | |- | ''[[MP Da Last Don (film)|MP Da Last Don]]'' | Dancer | |- | rowspan="5" | 1999 | ''The Pornographer'' | Tiffany | |- | ''[[Candyman 3: Day of the Dead|Candyman: Day of the Dead]]'' | Lena | a.k.a. {{Short description|Estonian singer}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Silvi Vrait | image = Silvi Vrait 1989.jpg | image_size = | caption = Silvi Vrait in 1989 | background = solo_singer | birth_date = {{birth date|1951|4|28|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Kehra]], Estonia | death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|6|28|1951|4|28|df=y}} | death_place = [[Tallinn]], Estonia | genre = [[Jazz]], [[Country music|country]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[Folk music|folk]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[pedagogue|music teacher]] | instrument = Vocals, piano | years_active = 1972–2013}} '''Silvi Vrait''' (28 April 1951 – 28 June 2013) was an [[Estonia]]n singer and music teacher.{{cite news|first=Jaak|last=Vihmand|publisher=[[Postimees]]|url=http://www.postimees.ee/170206/lisad/arter/arteri_persoon/190837.php|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120913153954/http://www.postimees.ee/170206/lisad/arter/arteri_persoon/190837.php|url-status=dead|archive-date=13 September 2012|title=Silvi Vrait — staar elu lõpuni|date=4 February 2006|accessdate=15 December 2008|language=et}} ==Biography== Vrait was born in [[Kehra]] in 1951 to Einar "Edward" Wright, a [[Minnesota]]-born American of [[Finland|Finnish]] ancestry and his Estonian wife Senta (née Schönberg).{{cite web |url=https://lood.delfi.ee/eestinaine/elud/salaparane-silvi-vrait-nii-jaa-kui-tulikuum?id=79720410|title=Salapärane Silvi Vrait – nii jää kui tulikuum|work=Eesti Naine|first=Piret|last=Tali|date=4 October 2017|accessdate=6 December 2020|language=et}} She had a half-sister, Pille, five years her senior. Vrait graduated from the Kehra Music School in 1968 on piano. In 1974 she graduated from the [[University of Tartu]] with a degree in [[English philology]]. From 1994, she taught English in a secondary school in [[Tallinn]]. Vrait coached vocalists, [[Evelin Samuel]] and [[Kaire Vilgats]] among many at the [[Georg Ots Music School]] in Tallinn. ==Stage career== Silvi Vrait first appeared on stage in 1972 when she performed in a TV show. She was a member of several pop and rock musical ensembles, including Viker 5, Suuk, Initsiaal and in 1975, she joined the popular band Fix. From 1976 to 1983 she was active in theatre [[Vanemuine]] in [[Tartu]]. Her style varies from jazz to country and from rock to folk. In the late 1980s, she was an important figure within the Estonian armless struggle for restoring the independence, the [[Singing Revolution]], for at least two recordings, "Väikene rahvas, väikene maa" ("Small Nation, Tiny Country") and "Ei ole üksi ükski maa" ("No Land Is Alone"). She appeared in [[musicals]] and [[opera]]s, such as ''"Põhjaneitsi"'' (''"The Maid of the North"'') (title role, 1980), ''[[Porgy and Bess]]'' (Bess, 1985), ''[[The King and I]]'' (Lady Thiang, 1998), ''[[Zorba (musical)|Zorba]]'' (Leader, 2000), ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]'' (Mama Rose, 2001), ''[[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]]'' (Mama Morton, 2004) and ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' (Mother Abbess, 2003, reprised in 2010), ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]]'' (Fräulein Schneider, 2012). In 1994, Vrait was the representative of Estonia at the [[Eurovision Song Contest]], held in [[Dublin]] that year. Her song "[[Nagu merelaine]]" ended up on 24th out of 25 places, beating only [[Lithuania]]. ==Death== [[File:Silvi Vrait memorial bench.jpg|thumb|Silvi Vrait memorial bench in [[Kehra]]]] In 2013 Vrait was hospitalized with a brain tumour and died on 28 June 2013, aged 62. She was buried at Tallinn's [[Metsakalmistu|Forest Cemetery]]. Vrait is survived by her son, Silver Vrait.[http://www.ohtuleht.ee/531850 Suri lauljanna Silvi Vrait] {{in lang|et}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{MusicBrainz artist|id=b1a4351b-c42d-4fe6-8b8e-1a0de06966d3|name=Silvi Vrait}} *{{IMDb name|1488751}} {{s-start}} {{s-ach}} {{succession box | before=''none'' | title=[[Estonia in the Eurovision Song Contest]] | years=[[Eurovision Song Contest 1994|1994]] | after=[[Maarja-Liis Ilus]] and [[Ivo Linna]]
with "[[Kaelakee hääl]]" }} {{s-end}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1994|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vrait, Silvi}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Estonian women singers]] [[Category:Estonian pop singers]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest entrants of 1994]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest entrants for Estonia]] [[Category:Estonian musical theatre actresses]] [[Category:Estonian people of Finnish descent]] [[Category:Estonian people of American descent]] [[Category:Estonian music educators]] [[Category:People from Kehra]] [[Category:Singers from Tallinn]] [[Category:Deaths from brain tumor]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Estonia]] [[Category:Burials at Metsakalmistu]] [[Category:University of Tartu alumni]] [[Category:20th-century Estonian actresses]] [[Category:21st-century Estonian actresses]] [[Category:Women music educators]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the White Star, 5th Class]] [[Category:Teachers of English as a second or foreign language]] [[Category:21st-century Estonian women singers]]

{{Short description|German composer and conductor}} {{Infobox person | name = Hans Vogt | image = | image_upright = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1911|05|14|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Gdańsk|Danzig]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1992|05|19|1911|05|14|df=y}} | death_place = [[Metterich]] | education = [[Akademie der Künste]] | occupation = {{plainlist| * Composer * Academic teacher }} | works = ''[[Die Stadt hinter dem Strom (opera)|Die Stadt hinter dem Strom]]'' | organization = Musikhochschule in Mannheim-Heidelberg | awards = }} '''Hans Vogt''' (14 May 1911 – 19 May 1992) was a German [[composer]] and [[Conducting|conductor]].
== Career == Born in [[Gdańsk|Danzig]], Vogt studied with [[Georg Schumann (composer)|Georg Schumann]] and [[Otto Frickhoeffer]] at the [[Akademie der Künste]] in Berlin from 1929 to 1934.<ref name=p>Prieberg, {{pp.|389|390}}.</ref> From 1934 he worked in [[Minden]] as a cellist, pianist and conductor.<ref name=p/> In 1935 he was appointed [[Kapellmeister]] at the [[Bielefeld Opera]] and in 1937 at the [[Landestheater Detmold]]. That same year he joined the [[Nazi Party]] (registration no. 5.653.178).<ref name=p/> From 1938 until 1944 he was Kapellmeister of the Stralsunder Theater, and then music director of [[Stralsund]], where he was also chairman of the Ministry of Arts.<ref name=p/> In 1944 he was drafted into the military and sent to the Russian front. He was taken prisoner of war in 1945 and did not return from the Sowjet Union until 1949.
In the postwar period Vogt lived first in 1949 as a freelance composer in [[Neckargemünd]].<ref name=p/> From 1951 to 1978 he led a composition class at the Musikhochschule in Mannheim-Heidelberg. In 1971 he was appointed professor.<ref>Klee, S. 632.</ref> Among his students was [[Barbara Heller]].
Vogt composed two [[opera]]s, ''[[Die Stadt hinter dem Strom (opera)|Die Stadt hinter dem Strom]]'' after the [[Die Stadt hinter dem Strom|novel]] of [[Hermann Kasack]] and ''Athenerkomödie'' (The Metropolitans) on a libretto by [[Christopher Middleton (poet)|Christopher Middleton]] after a fragment of [[Menander]]. Vogt wrote a [[symphony]], two concertos for orchestra, two [[piano concerto]]s, a [[violin concerto]], a [[cello concerto]], ''Serenade und Tarantella'' for viola and chamber ensemble, [[chamber music]] and [[Lied]]er. His sacred music included a [[Requiem]], two chamber [[oratorio]]s, a [[cantata]], a [[Magnificat]], and other choral music. In particular he composed the [[Psalm 130|Psalm 129]], ''De profundis clamavi ad te, Domine'', for a seven-part mixed choir [[a cappella]] (1951),a [[Passion (music)|Passion music]] ''Ihr Töchter von Jerusalem, weinet nicht über mich'' in Latin and German for tenor, mixed choir and percussion (1973), and a [[Nunc dimittis|Canticum Simeonis]] for mixed choir and flute (1976).<ref>[http://www.di-arezzo.co.uk/scores-of-Hans+Vogt-from-Suddeutscher.html?app=40 Scores of Hans Vogt from Suddeutscher (Bärenreiter)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808000656/http://www.di-arezzo.co.uk/scores-of-Hans+Vogt-from-Suddeutscher.html?app=40 |date=2016-08-08 }} di-arezzo.co.uk</ref>
Vogt's first opera, ''Die Stadt hinter dem Strom'', was originally written for radio and premiered on [[Nordwestdeutscher Rundfunk]] and [[BBC Radio]] in 1952.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Opera (British magazine)|Opera]]|volume=8|page=393|number=1|author=George Lascelles, 7th Earl of Harewood|year=1957|author-link=George Lascelles, 7th Earl of Harewood}}</ref> Vogt later adapted the work for the stage, and as a live theatre piece the opera was first performed at the [[Hessisches Staatstheater Wiesbaden]] in 1955 as part of the [[Internationale Maifestspiele Wiesbaden]].<ref name="Oeser" /><ref name="operone">[http://www.operone.de/komponist/vogt.html Hans Vogt] operone.de</ref><ref>Hermann Kasack: [https://books.google.com/books?id=OrOeZtaPhFoC&pg=PA59&lpg=PA59&dq=hans+vogt+kasack+wiesbaden+oper+die+stadt+hinter+dem+strom&source=bl&ots=PHwm8PJVNw&sig=nbMduH3Bhw0va-nK21lVYJxH71w&hl=it&ei=JVfdTcD8OMyc-wazmKWqDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBw Rückblick auf mein Leben] {{in lang|de}}</ref> For his operas, Vogt collaborated personally with the librettists, Hermann Kasack (Die Stadt hinter dem Strom) and Christopher Middleton (The Metropolitans). [[Erich Fried]], together with the composer, translated Middleton's English libretto into German. In an obituary for the publisher and musicologist Fritz Oeser that Vogt authored, the composer recalled how, during rehearsals for Die Stadt hinter dem Strom, Oeser had requested him to come to Wiesbaden to change the Chorprolog (choral prologue), also that Oeser missed a climax in a certain scene in act 3 and promised to pay for a change.<ref name="Oeser">Hans Vogt: [http://www.fritz-oeser.de/1982-vogt-wuerdigung-text.html Fritz Oeser], ''Musica 36'', volume 2, p. 194-196, 1982, on fritz-oeser.de {{in lang|de}}</ref> Kasack's libretto was published by [[Suhrkamp]] in 1955.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/title/stadt-hinter-dem-strom-oratorische-oper-in-drei-akten/oclc/14511105 Die Stadt hinter dem Strom; oratorische Oper in drei Akten] worldcat.org</ref> Vogt's opera ''Athenerkomödie'' (The Metropolitans) was premiered at the [[National Theatre Mannheim|Nationaltheater Mannheim]] in 1964, he revised it in 1967.<ref name="operone" /><ref>Christopher Middleton: [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-0483.1965.tb01236.x/full A Talk on Athenerkomödie] onlinelibrary.wiley.com 2007</ref>
Vogt composed secular vocal works inspired by poems of Hermann Kasack, [[Christopher Fry]], [[W. H. Auden]], [[T. S. Eliot]], [[Gerard M. Hopkins]], [[Aesop's Fables]], poems of [[Christopher Middleton (poet)|Christopher Middleton]], [[Gertrud Kolmar]], [[Horace]], [[Eduard Mörike]] and [[Gottfried Benn]]. Vogt's chamber music without keyboard includes a trio for flute, viola and harp (1951, revised 1989), a [[string trio]], four [[string quartet]]s, a [[string quintet]], a [[string sextet]], a [[string octet]], duos for violin and double bass, violin and cello, violin and viola, cello and double bass, and music for solo instruments. With keyboard, he composed works for piano solo, piano four hands, two pianos, a [[quintet]] for flute, oboe, violin, bassoon and harpsichord (1958), ''Konzertante Sonate für 17 Soloinstrumente'', a sonata concertante for 17 solo instruments (1959), ''Dialoge für Klavier, Violine und Violoncello'' (dialogues for [[piano trio]], 1960), and works with piano for solo instruments cello, violin and oboe.
Vogt's music was published by [[Breitkopf & Härtel]], [[Bärenreiter]], and [[Bote & Bock]]. He also published books, ''Neue Musik seit 1945'' (New Music since 1945), {{ISBN|3-15-010203-0}}, and ''Johann Sebastian Bachs Kammermusik: Voraussetzungen, Analysen, Einzelwerke'' (Johann Sebastian Bach's chamber Music: background, analysis, works), Stuttgart 1981, {{ISBN|3-15-010298-7}}. The latter was translated to English and published in [[Portland, Oregon]], in 1988, {{ISBN|0-931340-04-7}}, and to Spanish, published in [[Barcelona]] in 1993, {{ISBN|84-335-7880-4}}.
Vogt died in [[Metterich]] in 1992 at the age of 81.
==Selected works==
=== Opera === * ''[[Die Stadt hinter dem Strom (opera)|Die Stadt hinter dem Strom]]'', Oratorische Oper (oratorio opera) in 3 acts, text by Hermann Kasack after his novel, [[Bärenreiter]]/Alkor, 1952 radio version, revised stage version 1955 * ''Athenerkomödie'' (The Metropolitans), Opera giocosa in one act, text after a fragment of Menander by [[Christopher Middleton (poet)|Christopher Middleton]], in German by Erich Fried and Hans Vogt, Bärenreiter/Alkor, 1962, revised version 1987
=== Orchestra === * ''Konzert für mehrchöriges Orchester'', concerto for orchestra in several choirs, Bärenreiter/Alkor, 1950 * ''Konzert für Klavier und Orchester'', piano concerto, Bärenreiter/Alkor, 1955 * ''Konzert für Orchester'', Bärenreiter/Alkor, 1960 * ''Strophen'' (Stanzas), orchestral and vocal on an [[ode]] of [[Horace]], its composition by [[Petrus Tritonius]] (1507) and its German poetry by [[Eduard Mörike]] for baritone and orchestra, Bärenreiter/Alkor, 1975 * ''Konzert für Violine und Orchester'', violin concerto, [[Bote & Bock]], 1981 * ''Konzert für Violoncello und Orchester'', cello concerto, Bote & Bock, 1981 * ''Dona nobis pacem'', symphony in one movement, Bote & Bock, 1984 * ''Apreslude'', music for large orchestra, mezzo-soprano ad lib, in three movements after a poem of [[Gottfried Benn]], Bote & Bock, 1988
=== Sacred music === * ''De profundis clamavi ad te, Domine, Psalm 129 für gemischten Chor a capella'', Bärenreiter, 1951 * ''Historie der Verkündung'', chamber oratorio for three female voices, mixed choir and 13 instruments, Bärenreiter, 1955 * ''Ihr Töchter von Jerusalem, weinet nicht über mich'', Passion music for tenor, mixed choir and percussion, Bärenreiter, 1963 * ''Magnificat'' for soprano, mixed choir and orchestra, Bärenreiter/Alkor, 1966 * ''Requiem'' for soprano and bass, mixed choir and percussion, [[Breitkopf & Härtel]], 1969 * ''Canticum Simeonis'' for mixed choir and flute, Bärenreiter, 1976 * ''Historie vom Propheten Jona'', chamber oratorio, after the [[Old Testament]] and texts of [[Hilde Domin]] for alto, tenor and 6 instruments, Bärenreiter, 1979 * ''Drei geistliche Gesänge'' after Baroque poetry for baritone and organ, Bärenreiter, 1981/83
== References == {{Reflist | 30em}}
== Sources == * [[Fred K. Prieberg]]: Handbuch Deutsche Musiker 1933–1945, CD-Rom-Lexikon, Kiel 2004, p. 7.389–7.390 * Ernst Klee: Das Kulturlexikon zum Dritten Reich. Wer war was vor und nach 1945. S. Fischer, Frankfurt am Main 2007, {{p.|632}}
{{Authority control}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Adriane Garcia | birth_name = Adriane Garcia | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1981|9|19}} | birth_place = [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|RJ]], Brazil | death_date = | nationality = Brazilian | occupation = [[Television presenter|TV show presenter]], actress, singer-songwriter | years_active = 2000–present | television = ''Sucesso''
''Só Visto'' }} '''Adriane Garcia''' (September 19, 1983) is a Brazilian TV presenter, actress and former pop singer-songwriter. She has lived in [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]] since 2005. ==Career== Since she was a child, Adriane Garcia has always been passionate about music. At 14 she began a career as a model, but it was only years later that her life changed. After she had some interests in soap operas and mini-TV-series, Adriane was a reporter at [[SporTV]] in Brazil. In 2002 she joined [[Sistema Brasileiro de Televisão|SBT]] reality show ''Casa dos Artistas 3''. Adriane was chosen to live in the house, where she stayed for 45 days. Her obvious interest in pursuing a career in music, Adriane was probed by Building Records[http://www.buildingrecords.com.br/?/artista/perfil/20362 Profile Adriane Garcia on Building Records webpage] retrieved May 12, 2012 (pt) to record some demo songs. As a result, the label approved her work and the same year Adriane began recording her first album. Later Garcia took part in the third session of the Brazilian reality show ''Casa dos Artistas''.{{cite web|url=http://www.terra.com.br/exclusivo/noticias/2002/10/16/017.htm|title=Mion ataca de DJ e Fabiana Saba aparece acompanhada em festa|date=October 16, 2002|work=[[ISTOÉ]]|language=Portuguese|accessdate=December 23, 2010}} She then released her debut album, ''Vem Ficar Comigo'', in early 2004. In 2007 she was chosen as the presenter for the [[Rede Record|Record Internacional]]'s TV show ''Sucesso'', in Portugal. As the first Brazilian at all she is working now as TV Presenter for [[Rádio e Televisão de Portugal]]. In April 2012 she posed for fashion magazine [[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]] in Portugal.[http://www.magxone.com/maxim/adriane-garcia-maxim-portugal-april-2012/ Adriane Garcia Maxim Portugal April 2012] retrieved April 4, 2012 ==Filmography== {|class="wikitable" |+Television ! Year ! Title ! Role ! 2013–present | ''Só Visto'' |align="center"| Herself / Reporter
Herself / Presenter | |- | 2011 | ''[[Maternidade]]'' |align="center"| Solange | Season 1 |- | 2011–present | ''Cinco Sentidos'' |align="center"| Herself / Presenter | |- | 2012 | ''7 Maravilhas'' |align="center"| Herself / Presenter | |- | 2014 | ''3 Por Uma'' |align="center"| Herself / Presenter | |- | 2014–present | ''[[Água de Mar]]'' |align="center"| Gabi | |- |} {|class="wikitable" |+Films ! Notes |- | 2008–2009 | ''Programa Adriane Garcia'' | Rádio Tropical FM |- | 2013–present | ''A Hora da Dri'' | Record Europa FM |- |} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |+ List of albums ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"| Title ! scope="col" style="width:16em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''Vem Ficar Comigo'' | * Release: December 15, 2003{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/vem-ficar-comigo-r974595|title=Lançamento do álbum Vem Ficar Comigo|work=Allmusic|date=August 30, 2011}} * Label: Building Records * Formats: CD, digital download |- ! scope="row"| ''Lança Perfume'' | * Release: Setembro 20, 2006{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/ca/album/id184534873 |title=Lançamento do álbum Lança Perfume|work=iTunes|date=August 30, 2011}} * Label: NZ Produções * Formats: CD, digital download |- |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" border="1" ! scope="col"| Song ! scope="col"| Year ! scope="col"| Album |- ! scope="row"| "Amor Perfeito" | 2002 | rowspan="4"|''Vem Ficar Comigo'' |- ! scope="row"| "Vem Ficar Comigo" |rowspan="2"| 2003 |- ! scope="row"| "Diversão" |- ! scope="row"| "Me Leva Pra Casa" | 2004 |- ! scope="row"| "Lança Perfume" | 2006 | ''Lança Perfume'' |- |} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|3475258|Adriane Garcia}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Garcia, Adriane}} [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:Brazilian dance musicians]] [[Category:Brazilian television presenters]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Singers from São Paulo]] [[Category:Musicians from Rio de Janeiro (city)]] [[Category:21st-century Brazilian singers]] [[Category:21st-century Brazilian women singers]] [[Category:Brazilian women television presenters]]
